Parts_Used: The most commonly used parts of Astragalus plants are the roots, leaves, flowers, and gum. The roots are the primary medicinal part, while the leaves, flowers, and gum are also used for various purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Astragalus species are adapted to a wide range of climates, from dry, arid regions to more temperate areas. They generally prefer well-drained, sandy or rocky soils and full sun exposure. Many Astragalus species are drought-tolerant and can thrive in areas with low rainfall.
Chemical_Properties: Astragalus plants contain a variety of bioactive compounds, including polysaccharides, saponins, flavonoids, and triterpenes. The root is particularly rich in these compounds, which are believed to contribute to the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Astragalus plants are typically herbaceous perennials, with pinnately compound leaves and pea-like flowers that can be white, yellow, purple, or pink. The fruits are legumes or pods that contain small seeds. The roots can be thick and fleshy, sometimes with a woody base.
Medicinal_Value: In traditional Chinese medicine, Astragalus has been used for centuries to support the immune system, improve circulation, and treat a variety of conditions, including respiratory infections, diabetes, and kidney disorders. Modern research suggests that Astragalus may have antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Astragalus species are found throughout the Northern Hemisphere, with the highest diversity in Asia, particularly in China, Mongolia, and Central Asia. They are also found in Europe, North America, and parts of North Africa.

Description: Aconitum heterophyllum, also known as Ativisha or Atees, is a species of flowering plant in the genus Aconitum. It is an important medicinal herb used in traditional Indian systems of medicine like Ayurveda. Aconitum heterophyllum is a small perennial herb with a straight stem, sometimes branched, growing up to 20 cm in height. The leaves are dark green, heteromorphous, and have a spiral (alternate) arrangement. The flowers are large, hooded, and white-violet in color, appearing in slender racemes or lax leafy panicles from August to October.
Parts_Used: The tuberous roots of Aconitum heterophyllum are the primary parts used medicinally. The roots are whitish-grey in color, 2-7.5 cm long, and 0.4-1.6 cm thick at the upper end, tapering towards the bottom. The leaves and stems are also sometimes used.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Aconitum heterophyllum prefers a sub-alpine to alpine climate and grows well at elevations between 2,500-4,200 m. It requires sandy loam or slightly acidic soil with a pH around 6, abundant moisture during the summer months, and open sunny sites.
Chemical_Properties: Aconitum heterophyllum contains a variety of bioactive secondary metabolites, primarily aconite alkaloids such as aconitine, mesaconitine, hypaconitine, benzoylaconine, benzoylmesaconine, and benzoylhypaconine. It also contains carbohydrates, proteins, amino acids, saponins, glycosides, flavonoids, and terpenoids.
Morphological_Features: The plant has a simple or branched stem, dark green heteromorphous leaves with long petioles, and large hooded white-violet flowers. The tuberous roots are whitish-grey, 2-7.5 cm long, and 0.4-1.6 cm thick at the upper end.
Medicinal_Value: Aconitum heterophyllum has been used traditionally to treat a variety of conditions, including dysentery, diarrhea, fever, malaria, cough, cold, colic, headache, piles, hysteria, throat infections, dyspepsia, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diabetes. The roots also have expectorant, febrifuge, anthelmintic, anti-diarrheal, anti-emetic, and anti-inflammatory properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Aconitum heterophyllum is found naturally in the sub-alpine and alpine regions of the Himalayas, particularly in the Indian states of Jammu & Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand, as well as in Pakistan and Nepal. It grows at elevations between 2,500-4,200 m.

Description: Solanum melongena, commonly known as eggplant or aubergine, is a perennial plant widely cultivated for its edible fruit. Solanum melongena is a tender perennial often grown as an annual in temperate climates. The plant typically reaches a height of 2 to 4 feet and features a multi-stemmed, erect habit. Its leaves are large, lobed, and can be prickly, while the flowers are star-shaped, usually purple with a yellow center, and bloom in clusters. The fruit, which is a berry, varies in color from green to purple-black and can measure between 4 to 8 inches in length. The immature fruit is edible, while mature fruit can become bitter and stringy.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Solanum melongena used are the fruit and leaves. The fruit is commonly consumed in various culinary preparations, including frying, baking, and stewing. The leaves, although toxic when ingested, have been used in traditional medicine for external applications, such as poultices for treating burns and abscesses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Eggplants thrive in warm, sunny environments. They require full sun exposure, ideally receiving at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. The plants are sensitive to cold and should be planted after the last frost in temperate regions. Optimal temperatures for growth range from 70°F to 85°F (21°C to 29°C). They prefer well-drained, loamy soil with a pH below 6.0 and benefit from good moisture levels.
Chemical_Properties: The fruit of Solanum melongena is rich in various nutrients, including vitamins C and K, potassium, and dietary fiber. It contains phytochemicals such as nasunin (an antioxidant found in the skin), which is known for its potential health benefits, including lowering cholesterol levels and supporting heart health. However, the leaves contain toxic compounds and should not be ingested.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Solanum melongena exhibits several distinct features bright green or purplish, simple, alternate leaves, and ovate to oblong, measuring 8 inches long and 4 inches wide leaves. Purple, funnel-shaped flowers with 5-6 lobes, typically blooming in clusters. Glossy, egg-shaped berries fruits that can be purple, white, or green, containing numerous small seeds.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally, Solanum melongena has been used in various cultures for its medicinal properties. It has been employed as a treatment for conditions such as diabetes, bronchitis, and skin infections. The fruit is believed to help lower blood cholesterol levels and is often included in diets for managing hypertension. The leaves have been used externally for treating burns and abscesses, although they are toxic if ingested.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Solanum melongena is cultivated globally, with its origins traced back to South-Central China and Southeast Asia. It is widely grown in tropical and subtropical regions, including India, Bangladesh, and various parts of Africa. In temperate regions, it is often grown as an annual crop during the warmer months. The plant is adaptable and can be found in diverse agricultural systems worldwide, particularly in areas with warm climates.

Description: Avocado is a medium-sized, evergreen tree that grows 9-20 m tall with a trunk diameter of 0.3-0.6 m. The leaves are 8-25 cm long and alternately arranged. The tree produces thousands of small, inconspicuous flowers each year that lack true petals. The fruit is a large, pear-shaped berry that can weigh 100-1000 g, with a single large seed.
Parts_Used: The edible fruit is the primary part used, with the flesh having a buttery, rich flavor. The leaves, pits, and plant itself are also sometimes used, though the pits can be mildly toxic.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Avocados require a warm, frost-free climate to grow well. They thrive in full sun and prefer rich, well-drained soils. The Mexican race is the most cold-hardy, while the West Indian race is the most tropical in nature.
Chemical_Properties: Avocados are high in monounsaturated fats and provide vitamins A, B, and C. The pits and leaves may contain mildly toxic compounds.
Morphological_Features: Avocado trees have elliptic to egg-shaped leaves and produce small greenish flowers in dense clusters. The fruit has a large central seed surrounded by edible flesh that turns buttery when ripe.
Medicinal_Value: The pulp can be used externally to soothe skin and treat wounds, while the pits have been used to induce abortion. However, the pits may also be mildly toxic.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Avocados are native to Mexico, Central America, and South America. Major commercial production occurs in Mexico, the Dominican Republic, Peru, Indonesia, and Colombia, as well as in California, Florida, and other warm regions worldwide.

Description: Ayapana (Eupatorium triplinerve) is an evergreen perennial plant native to South America. It is a tropical shrub commonly known as water hemp. The plant has long, slender leaves which are used to make herbal medicinal extracts. The stem is hairless and reddish in color, while the leaves are purple and occur in corymbose inflorescence.
Parts_Used: The leaves and whole plant of Eupatorium triplinerve are used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Ayapana is adapted to tropical climates and grows well in regions with high humidity and temperatures between 25-30°C.
Chemical_Properties: Ayapana is a rich source of naturally occurring coumarin chemicals. Coumarin has clinical value as the precursor for several anticoagulant drugs, most notably warfarin.
Morphological_Features: Ayapana is a shrub with hairless, reddish stems. The leaves are long, slender, purple in color, and occur in corymbose inflorescence. The plant is glabrous (hairless).
Medicinal_Value: The paste of the ayapana leaf is applied over bleeding external pile mass to control bleeding and reduce the size of the pile mass. Cold infusion of Ayapana is given in a dose of 30-40 ml to control asthma and treat cough associated with phlegm. The decoction of the plant is given for the treatment of indigestion, cough, rhinitis, fever, and dysmenorrhea. Ayapana exhibits antimicrobial, antinociceptive, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anthelmintic activities.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Ayapana grows in South America (Brazil, Peru, Ecuador), Puerto Rico, Hawaii, and India

Description: Tagetes erecta, commonly known as the Aztec marigold, Mexican marigold, or African marigold, is a species of flowering plant in the genus Tagetes. It is native to Mexico and Guatemala but is widely cultivated commercially for its ornamental and medicinal uses. The plant grows as a herbaceous annual or perennial, reaching heights of between 20 and 90 cm (7.9 and 35.4 in).
Parts_Used: The parts of the plant used for medicinal purposes include the leaves, flowers, and essential oil. The flowers are used for various rituals and culinary purposes as a coloring agent. The leaves are used to prepare pastes and infusions for treating various ailments.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Tagetes erecta requires mild climate conditions for luxuriant growth and flowering. It thrives in temperatures ranging from 14.5° to 28.6°C (58° to 83.5°F) during the growing period. Higher temperatures can adversely affect flower production. The plant is adaptable to different types of soil conditions but prefers deep, fertile, friable soil with good water holding capacity and near-neutral pH (7.0 – 7.5).
Chemical_Properties: The whole plant contains an essential oil with major components such as limonene, ocimene, linalyl acetate, linalool, tagetone, and n-nonyl aldehyde. The flowers contain lutein esters of dipalmitate, dimyristate, and monomyristate. The fresh petals contain tagetin and hydroxyflavones. These chemical constituents contribute to the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Marigold is a small hairy herb growing to a height of 3-4 feet. The flowers are dark yellow or orange colored and are cultivated for their decorative purposes. The plant has a cylindrical, pivoting root with a fibrous and shallow branching system. The stem is striated, sometimes reddish, and the leaves are pinnately divided with linear lanceolate leaflets.
Medicinal_Value: The plant has various medicinal properties, including being bitter (rasa), astringent (kashaya), light for digestion (laghu), dry in nature (ruksha), and cold (sheeta). It is used to reduce vitiated kapha and pitta dosha (kaphapitta shamaka). The plant is used to treat boils, carbuncles, muscle pain, rheumatism, bronchitis, asthma, cough, external piles, and wounds. It is also used for nasal administration in epistaxis and to control bleeding in piles and menstruation.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Marigold is native to Mexico and Guatemala but has spread to various regions worldwide, including Africa and many parts of Asia. It is widely cultivated in temperate climates for its ornamental and medicinal uses. The plant can be grown three times a year in different seasons, including the rainy, winter, and summer seasons.

Plant_Name: Babool / Indian Gum / Kikar / Samagh arabi
Description: Acacia arabica, also known as babul, kikar, and samagh arabi, is a thorny tree native to North Africa and parts of Asia. It is a tree that grows 5-20 m high with a dense, spherical crown. It has dark to black colored, fissured bark and a grey-pinkish inner bark that exudes a reddish, low-quality gum.
Parts_Used: The bark, root, gum, leaves, pods, and seeds of Acacia arabica have medicinal properties and are used. The tender twigs are also used as natural toothbrushes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Acacia arabica grows well in dry, sandy regions and is adapted to arid and semi-arid climates. It is native to parts of Africa and Asia, including Egypt, the Maghreb, Sahel, Arabian Peninsula, and the Indian subcontinent.
Chemical_Properties: Acacia arabica is a rich source of polyphenols, alkaloids, volatile essential oils, phenols and phenolic glycosides, resins, oleosins, steroids, tannins, and terpenes. Two new antiprotozoal diterpenes have been isolated from the root bark.
Morphological_Features: The tree has thin, straight, light grey spines in axillary pairs, usually 3-12 pairs, that are 5-7.5 cm long on young trees but commonly absent on mature trees. The bipinnate leaves have 3-6 pairs of pinnulae and 10-30 pairs of leaflets that are tomentose (covered in fine, soft hairs). The bright golden-yellow flowers are globular and 1.2-1.5 cm in diameter, arranged either axillary or whorled on 2-3 cm long peduncles at the ends of branches. The pods are strongly constricted, hairy, white-grey, thick, and softly tomentose.
Medicinal_Value: The bark, root, gum, leaves, and flowers of Acacia arabica have been used traditionally to treat a variety of conditions, including skin diseases, diarrhea, dysentery, cough, diabetes, eczema, wound healing, burning sensations, and as an astringent, demulcent, and anti-asthmatic. The gum is also used as a tonic for women after childbirth and to treat diabetes.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Acacia arabica is native to parts of Africa, from Senegal to Egypt and down to South Africa, and in Asia from Arabia eastward to India, Burma, and Sri Lanka. It has also become naturalized in other regions, such as Zanzibar and Australia.

Description: Acacia nilotica, commonly known as the babul or gum arabic tree, is a versatile and ecologically significant species that thrives in various environments. Below is a detailed overview of its description, parts used, weather conditions required for growth, chemical properties, morphological features, medicinal value, and worldwide regions that support its growth. Babul is a medium to large deciduous tree, typically reaching heights of 15 to 20 meters. It has a dense, spreading crown and is characterized by its thorny branches and rough, dark gray bark. The leaves are bipinnate, with small leaflets, and the tree produces fragrant yellow flowers arranged in spherical heads. The fruit is in the form of flat, brown pods that contain several seeds.
Parts_Used: The Babul plant has various parts that are utilized for different purposes. The leaves and pods are commonly used as fodder for livestock and in traditional medicine. The bark is employed in treating ailments such as dysentery and cough. The gum, known as gum arabic, has historically been used in medicines and dyes. Additionally, the wood of the Babul plant is valued for its durability and is used in construction and tool making.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Acacia nilotica thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. It prefers average annual temperatures ranging from 15°C to 28°C and can withstand maximum temperatures up to 50°C. The species is frost-sensitive when young and typically grows in areas with high clay content but can adapt to sandy loam. It is commonly found near waterways and tolerates salinity well. Germination occurs during the wet season, and the tree can grow at altitudes up to 2000 meters.
Chemical_Properties: The plant is rich in various phytochemicals, including alkaloids, tannins, phenolic compounds, and terpenes. Notably, it contains condensed tannins, gallic acid, and flavonoids, which contribute to its medicinal properties. Some parts of the plant exhibit antioxidant, anti-cancer, and anti-inflammatory activities, making it a subject of interest in pharmacological studies.
Morphological_Features: The babul plant, also known as Vachellia nilotica, is distinguished by several unique morphological characteristics. It typically reaches a height of 5 to 20 meters, with a dense and spherical crown. The bark is dark and fissured, often exhibiting a grey-pinkish hue in younger trees. The plant is also notable for its thin, straight thorns, which are light grey and usually appear in pairs. The flowers are bright golden-yellow, forming in globular heads, while the pods are deeply constricted, hairy, and thick.
Medicinal_Value: Babul has a long history of medicinal use in various cultures. It is recognized for its anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, and anti-bacterial properties. The leaves, bark, and fruits are used in traditional medicine to treat ailments such as dysentery, cough, and ulcers. The Maasai people, for example, consume the inner bark and fruit pulp for medicinal purposes.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Babul is native to regions spanning from Egypt through the Maghreb and Sahel, south to Mozambique and KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa, and east through the Arabian Peninsula to the Indian subcontinent and Burma. It has also been naturalized in areas like Australia and Zanzibar. The species is commonly found in tropical and subtropical environments, particularly in regions with seasonal flooding.

Description: Terminalia bellirica, also known as the Belleric Myrobalan, is a tree species that belongs to the Combretaceae family. Terminalia bellirica is a large deciduous tree that can grow up to 30 meters tall. It has a straight, cylindrical trunk and a spreading crown. The bark is dark grey or brown in color and deeply fissured.
Parts_Used: The most commonly used parts of the Terminalia bellirica tree are the fruits, also known as "Bibhitaki" or "Bahera". The fruits are large, oval-shaped drupes that turn from green to yellow or brown when ripe.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Terminalia bellirica thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. It requires 15-35°C temperature, 800-2000 mm annually rainfall, well-drained, loamy to sandy loam soils. The tree can tolerate a wide range of soil types but prefers slightly acidic to neutral pH levels. It is also drought-tolerant to some extent.
Chemical_Properties: The fruits of Terminalia bellirica contain a variety of phytochemicals, including gallic acid, ellagic acid, chebulic acid, and various tannins. These compounds contribute to the medicinal properties of the plant.
Morphological_Features: The leaves are simple, oblong-elliptic in shape, and measure 10-25 cm in length. The flowers are small, greenish-yellow, and arranged in terminal spikes. The fruits are large, oval-shaped drupes that turn from green to yellow or brown when ripe
Medicinal_Value: Terminalia bellirica has been used extensively in traditional medicine systems, particularly in Ayurveda. The fruits are known to have astringent, laxative, expectorant, and antioxidant properties. They are used to treat a variety of ailments, including cough, asthma, constipation, and liver disorders.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Terminalia bellirica is native to the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia. It is found in countries such as India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Thailand, and Malaysia. The tree is also cultivated in other tropical regions of the world, including parts of Africa and South America.

Description: Sida cordifolia, also known as Bala or Country Mallow, is a medicinal plant that has been used in traditional Indian medicine for centuries. Sida cordifolia is an annual or perennial herb or small shrub that grows 2-5 feet tall. It has a branched, softly hairy stem covered in stellate (star-shaped) hairs. The leaves are cordate (heart-shaped), ovate-oblong, 1-3 inches long and 1-2 inches wide, with smooth margins and stellate hairs.
Parts_Used: The whole plant, including the roots, leaves, flowers, and seeds, is used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Sida cordifolia is found throughout the tropical and subtropical regions of India, where it grows wild along roadsides and is also cultivated. It prefers warm, humid climates and can tolerate a wide range of soil types.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains alkaloids, flavonoids, sterols, and other phytochemicals that contribute to its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The flowers are yellow or white, with 5 sepals and 5 petals. The fruit is a schizocarp (splitting fruit) about 6-8 mm in diameter, containing small black seeds.
Medicinal_Value: In Ayurvedic medicine, Sida cordifolia is considered a Rasayana (rejuvenative) herb and is used to treat a variety of conditions, including respiratory disorders, nervous system disorders, pain, inflammation, and more. It has analgesic, anti-inflammatory, anti-asthmatic, and neuroprotective effects.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Sida cordifolia is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, Africa, and Australia, and is cultivated and naturalized in many parts of the world.

Plant_Name: Balm / Bee Balm / Common Balm / Lemon Balm / Melissa / Sweet Balm
Description: Melissa officinalis is a perennial herbaceous plant in the mint family (Lamiaceae) and is native to south-central Europe, the Mediterranean Basin, Iran, and Central Asia. It is also naturalized in many other regions around the world. The plant grows bushy and upright, reaching a height of 60 to 100 cm. The leaves are soft, hairy, and heart-shaped, with a rough, veined surface and scalloped edges. The leaves have a mild lemon scent and are used as a herb, in teas, and as a flavoring agent.
Parts_Used: The leaves and flowers of lemon balm are the primary parts used. The leaves are used fresh or dried in various culinary and medicinal preparations. The flowers are also used, particularly in the production of honey and as a source of essential oil.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Lemon balm grows easily from seed, preferring rich, moist soil. The seeds require light and a minimum temperature of 20 °C (68 °F) to germinate. The plant grows in clumps and spreads vegetatively, as well as by seed. In mild temperate zones, the plant stems die off at the start of the winter but shoot up again in spring.
Chemical_Properties: Lemon balm contains a variety of chemical compounds, including eugenol, tannins, and terpenes. The essential oil extracted from the leaves is rich in geranial (citral), which contributes to its lemon scent and various pharmacological effects.
Morphological_Features: Melissa officinalis has soft, hairy leaves that are 2 to 8 cm long and dark green in color. The leaves are heart-shaped with a rough, veined surface and scalloped edges. The flowers are small, white, or pale pink, and appear during summer. The plant has a hairy root system, making it adaptable to different environmental conditions.
Medicinal_Value: Lemon balm has been used in traditional medicine around the world for its various pharmacological effects. It is known to have antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antiviral properties. The plant is used to treat anxiety, insomnia, and digestive issues. Its essential oil is also used in perfumery and as a furniture polish.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Lemon balm is native to Europe, central Asia, and Iran, but it is now naturalized in many regions around the world. It grows well in temperate climates and is cultivated in various parts of Europe, particularly in Hungary, Egypt, and Italy. The plant is also grown in the Americas and other regions where the climate is suitable.

Description: Bambusa vulgaris, commonly known as common bamboo, is a large, evergreen, clump-forming bamboo species native to southern China and Madagascar. It grows 10–20 m (30–70 ft) tall with stems 4–10 cm (2–4 in) thick. The stems are lemon-yellow with green stripes and dark green leaves.
Parts_Used: Every part of the Bamboo plant has potential medicinal uses, including the rhizome, culm shavings, leaves, roots, shoots, and seeds.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: B. vulgaris grows best in tropical and subtropical climates. It tolerates a wide range of climatic conditions and soil types up to 1,200 m altitude. It can survive low temperatures down to -3°C and has high adaptability to semi-arid areas, degraded and flooded lands.
Chemical_Properties: The average chemical composition of B. vulgaris is cellulose 41–44%, pentosans 21–23%, lignin 26–28%, ash 1.7–1.9%, and silica 0.6–0.7%.
Morphological_Features: Bamboo forms moderately loose clumps with no thorns. The stems are not straight, not easy to split, inflexible, thick-walled, and initially strong. Leaves are narrow lanceolate. Flowering is infrequent, and there are no seeds. Fruits are rare due to low pollen viability.
Medicinal_Value: Bamboo has excellent medicinal potential. Extracts exhibit analgesic, antihyperglycemic, antipyretic, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antimicrobial, antiviral, hepatoprotective, and anti-amnesic activities. The leaves are used to treat diarrhea, tuberculosis, fever, hematuria, kidney troubles, and as an abortifacient.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Bamboo is native to Cambodia, China, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, Vietnam and introduced into Bangladesh, Benin, Brazil, Burkina Faso, Bhutan, and many other countries in Africa, Asia, the Americas, and the Caribbean.

Description: Clerodendrum indicum, also known as Turka or Turmeric Clerodendrum, is a perennial shrub native to India and Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Lamiaceae (mint) family and is valued for its medicinal properties.
Parts_Used: The leaves, roots, and flowers of Clerodendrum indicum are commonly used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Turka thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. It prefers well-drained, moist soil and partial shade to full sun exposure. The plant can tolerate a wide range of soil types but performs best in loamy, nutrient-rich soils.
Chemical_Properties: Bamunhati contains various bioactive compounds, including iridoids, flavonoids, terpenoids, and phenolic compounds. These compounds contribute to the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Bamunhati is a shrub that can grow up to 2-3 meters tall. It has simple, opposite leaves that are ovate to lanceolate in shape, with a serrated margin. The flowers are white or pink, tubular, and arranged in terminal clusters
Medicinal_Value: Clerodendrum indicum has been used in traditional medicine to treat a variety of ailments, including fever, inflammation, pain, and respiratory disorders. The plant is known to possess anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antimicrobial, and antioxidant properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Clerodendrum indicum is native to India and Southeast Asia, including countries such as Bangladesh, Myanmar, Thailand, and Indonesia. It is also cultivated in other tropical and subtropical regions around the world.

Description: Musa paradisiaca, commonly known as the banana, is an elongated, edible fruit produced by several kinds of large herbaceous flowering plants in the genus Musa. It is botanically classified as a berry and is highly variable in size and shape. The fruit is typically yellow or green, with a protective outer layer and numerous long, thin strings (vascular bundles) running lengthwise between the skin and the edible inner portion. The inner part of the common yellow dessert variety can be split lengthwise into three sections that correspond to the inner portions of the three carpels by manually deforming the unopened fruit
Parts_Used: Fruit, Leaves, Stem, Flowers and Corm
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Bananas grow best in the humid lowland tropics within 30 degrees of the equator. They require at least 60 centimeters (2.0 ft) deep soil with good drainage and are not compacted
Chemical_Properties: Bananas are rich in potassium, vitamin C, and dietary fiber. They also contain phosphorus, calcium, and other essential nutrients. Banana peels are rich in potassium, phosphorus, and calcium, making them suitable for composting and creating organic fertilizer
Morphological_Features: The above-ground part of the plant is a "false stem" or pseudostem, consisting of leaves and their fused bases. Each pseudostem can produce a single flowering stem. The leaves are spirally arranged and may grow up to 2.7 meters (8.9 ft) long and 60 cm (2.0 ft) wide. The base of the petiole widens to form a sheath, which makes up the pseudostem. The inflorescence contains many petal-like bracts between rows of flowers. Female flowers appear in rows further up the stem from the rows of male flowers.
Medicinal_Value: Bananas are not typically used for medicinal purposes, but their nutritional properties contribute to overall health. They are beneficial for maintaining heart health, regulating blood pressure, and improving digestion
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Bananas are native to Southeast Asia and grow best in the humid lowland tropics within 30 degrees of the equator. They are cultivated in many tropical regions worldwide, including South Asia, Central America, and Africa

Description: Abutilon hirtum is a shrub that can grow up to 2.5 meters tall. It has ovate or heart-shaped leaves that are 5-18 cm in length and width, with coarsely-toothed, wavy margins. The leaves, stems, flowers, and young parts of the plant are covered in dense hairs, making them slightly sticky. The flowers are yellow with a bright red center, about 3 cm in diameter with 1-1.5 cm long petals and a dense tuft of stamens at the center. The flowers are bisexual and capable of self-pollination, as well as being pollinated by wind and insects. The plant produces abundant seedpods that resemble ruff collars from the 16th century, with separate compartments for each seed.
Parts_Used: The stems, leaves, flowers, and young parts of the plant are all used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Barakanghi grows well in warm, tropical weather with moderate rainfall. It is commonly found in open areas, roadsides, hillsides, forest margins, and pastures.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains analgesic (pain-relieving) and aphrodisiacal (sexual stimulant) properties.
Morphological_Features: The leaves are 5-18 cm long and wide, with coarsely-toothed, wavy margins. The flowers are about 3 cm in diameter, with 1-1.5 cm long petals and a dense tuft of stamens at the center. The seedpods resemble ruff collars used in the 16th century, with separate compartments for each seed. They are initially green, turning brown and almost black when mature, with small button-like seeds that are pointy at both ends.
Medicinal_Value: Barakanghi has many medicinal uses in traditional herbal medicine. It is used to treat fever, headaches, ulcers, kidney stones, leprosy, urinary bladder diseases, cough, tooth pain, and abscesses. It also has analgesic (pain-relieving) and aphrodisiacal (sexual stimulant) properties
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Hairy Indian Mallow is found in warm, tropical regions, mostly in Asia and Oceania. It is considered an invasive species in these areas.

Description: Adhatoda vasica Nees, commonly known as Vasaka , is a small evergreen shrub native to northern India. It is a dense, much-branched plant with large, lance-shaped leaves
Parts_Used: The leaves, flowers, roots, and the whole plant of Adhatoda vasica are used for medicinal purposes. The leaves are of great importance and are used to treat various ailments.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Vasaka grows prominently in the lower Himalayan region of India. It occurs throughout the plains and in the lower regions of the Himalayas.
Chemical_Properties: Basak leaves contain various phytochemicals such as alkaloids, tannins, saponins, phenolics, and flavonoids. The key chemical constituents include aasicine, a quinazoline alkaloid, An essential oil and other chemicals like Luteolin, Tritriacontane, B-Sitosterol, Kaempferol, Adhatodic acid, Vitamin C.
Morphological_Features: Basak  is a tall, much-branched, dense, evergreen shrub with large, lance-shaped leaves. The flowers are present in dense, short spikes with leaf-like structures called bracts that are conspicuously veined.
Medicinal_Value:
The plant is expectorant as it softens thick sputum and facilitates its removal, providing relief in bronchitis. It is antispasmodic, helps in treating asthma, bronchitis, and tuberculosis
Alterative, diuretic, and germicide. It is used to treat cough, asthma, bronchitis, tuberculosis, fever, and rheumatism. The fresh leaf juice is taken with honey and long pepper for cough and phthisis
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Adhatoda vasica is native to northern India and occurs throughout the plains and in the lower regions of the Himalayas. It is used in Ayurvedic, Siddha, Homeopathy, and Unani systems of medicine.

Description: Ocimum basilicum, commonly known as sweet basil or holy basil, is an annual herbaceous plant in the family Lamiaceae. It is known for its ornamental and therapeutic importance. The plant has a strong, sweet, and slightly peppery flavor, which is often used in cooking and traditional medicine
Parts_Used: The various parts of the plant, including leaves, stems, flowers, roots, seeds, and the whole plant, are used in different applications. The leaves are the most commonly used part for culinary and medicinal purposes
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Basil thrives in warm and humid conditions. It prefers temperatures between 80°F and 90°F (27°C to 32°C) and requires moist but well-drained soil
Chemical_Properties: Ocimum basilicum contains volatile oils such as eugenol and linalool, which contribute to its antibacterial properties. The plant also contains other phytochemicals with various medicinal properties, including cardiac stimulants, expectorants, and anti-inflammatory compounds
Morphological_Features: The plant grows to a height of about 30 inches (76 cm) and has a compact, bushy habit. The leaves are green, oval-shaped, and have a serrated margin. The flowers are small, white, and grow in clusters
Medicinal_Value:
Ocimum basilicum has been used in traditional medicine for various conditions, including:
Expectorant (helps to loosen phlegm and ease breathing) , Cardiac Stimulant (supports heart function) , Treatment for Gastric Disorders (relieves symptoms of indigestion and stomach ulcers) , Bronchitis and Asthma (helps to alleviate symptoms of these respiratory conditions) , Antibacterial Properties , May help lower blood sugar and blood pressure levels
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth:
Basil is widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions around the world, including:
Asia , India, China, and Southeast Asia , Europe , Mediterranean regions and parts of Eastern Europe , North America , California, Florida, and other warm regions , South America , Brazil and other tropical areas

Description: Arctostaphylos uva-ursi, also known as bearberry or bear grape, is a low-growing (20 inches tall) perennial shrub with creeping stems. It has small, dark, fleshy leaves; the flowers are bell-shaped, white or pink. Its dull reddish-orange berries are favorites of bears, hence its name "uva ursi" (grape of the bear).
Parts_Used: Only the leaves, not the berries, are used in herbal medicine.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Uva ursi grows in temperate regions and thrives in alpine forests. It grows slowly but succeeds in places where other plants cannot, such as the walls of canyons.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains phytochemicals, including glucoside (arbutin), methylarbutin, eriolin, ursone, gallic acid, ellagic acid, hydroquinones (mainly arbutin, up to 17%), tannins (up to 15%) and phenolic glycosides and flavonoids.
Morphological_Features: The plant's height is 5–30 centimeters (2–12 inches). The leaves are shiny, small, and feel thick and stiff, about 4 cm (1+1⁄2 in) long and 1 cm (1⁄2 in) wide, with rounded tips tapering back to the base. Terminal clusters of small urn-shaped flowers, white to pink, blooming from May to June. Round, fleshy or mealy, bright red to pink fruits called drupes, about 1⁄4 to 1⁄2 inch (6 to 13 mm) in diameter.
Medicinal_Value: Uva ursi has been used medicinally since the 2nd century. It is primarily used to treat urinary tract infections (UTIs) and cystitis (bladder inflammation). It contains chemicals like arbutin and hydroquinone that have antibacterial properties, helping to fight infections. However, it can be toxic, especially due to hydroquinone, which can cause serious liver damage.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Uva ursi is found in North America, Europe, the Iberian Peninsula, Siberia, and the Himalayas.

Description: Perilla frutescens, commonly known as perilla or Korean perilla, is an annual herbaceous plant belonging to the mint family, Lamiaceae. This plant is native to Southeast Asia and the Indian highlands, and it is traditionally cultivated in countries such as Korea, China, Japan, and India. Perilla is characterized by its aromatic leaves, which have a strong mint-like scent, and it is often used in culinary dishes as well as for medicinal purposes. Perilla frutescens typically grows to a height of 60–90 cm (24–35 in) and features hairy, square stalks. The leaves are opposite, measuring 7–12 cm (3–4.5 in) long and 5–8 cm (2–3 in) wide, with a broad oval shape, pointed tips, serrated margins, and long petioles. The upper surface of the leaves is green, while the underside may show purple hues. The plant produces raceme flowers in late summer, with a calyx consisting of five sepals and a corolla that is 4–5 mm long. The fruit is a schizocarp, approximately 2 mm in diameter, with seeds that can vary in color from white to dark brown and contain about 38-45% lipid content.
Parts_Used: In traditional medicine, various parts of Perilla frutescens are utilized, including the leaves, stems, and seeds. The dried leaves are often used in herbal remedies, while the seeds are consumed for their nutritional benefits and oil extraction. Each part of the plant has distinct therapeutic applications, making it a valuable resource in herbal medicine.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Perilla thrives in warm, temperate climates, preferring full sun to partial shade. It requires well-drained, fertile soil with a pH between 6.0 and 7.0. The plant is sensitive to frost, making it essential to plant after the last frost date in spring. Optimal growth occurs with moderate rainfall, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot.
Chemical_Properties: The chemical composition of Perilla includes various volatile oils, flavonoids, and phenolic compounds. Notably, it contains perillaldehyde, which is responsible for its distinct aroma and is believed to have antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. The seeds are rich in omega-3 fatty acids, contributing to their nutritional value and health benefits.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Perilla is recognized for its distinctive square stems, opposite leaves, and raceme flower arrangement. The leaves exhibit a serrated margin and can display a range of colors, contributing to the plant's ornamental appeal. The seeds are small and globular, with a reticulate pattern on their surface, which aids in identification.
Medicinal_Value: Perilla leaves are used for their antioxidant, anti-allergic, antimicrobial, anti-tumor, and anti-cancer effects due to the presence of phenolic compounds. The seeds are also used for their medicinal properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Perilla frutescens is widely cultivated in Asian countries such as China, Japan, South Korea, and India. It has also been grown in Russia's Far East since the 1930s. In the United States, perilla is considered an invasive weed pest that is toxic to cattle.

Description: Beta vulgaris, commonly known as the beet, is a herbaceous biennial or perennial plant that can grow up to 120 cm (rarely 200 cm) in height. The cultivated forms are mostly biennial. The roots of cultivated beets can be dark red, white, or yellow and are moderately to strongly swollen and fleshy. The stems grow erect or procumbent in the wild forms, and are simple or branched in the upper part with a ribbed and striate surface. The basal leaves have long petioles that may be thickened and red, white, or yellow in some cultivars. The leaf blades are oblanceolate to heart-shaped, dark green to dark red, slightly fleshy, and have a prominent midrib with an entire or undulate margin, typically 5-20 cm long on wild plants but often much larger in cultivated plants.
Parts_Used: The edible parts of Beta vulgaris include the roots, leaves, and stems. The roots are the most economically important part, used to produce table beets, sugar beets, and animal feed (mangel-wurzel). The leaves and stems are also edible, often used as a leafy vegetable (chard or spinach beet).
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Beets grow best in temperate to cool regions or during the cooler seasons, with a growing season of about 8 to 10 weeks in favorable climates. They require deep, loose soils high in organic matter and respond well to chemical fertilizers and manures. Beets can tolerate relatively high soil salt content but are sensitive to high acidity and low boron content.
Chemical_Properties: Beets are a good source of riboflavin, folate, manganese, and the antioxidant betaine. The red pigment in beets is due to betalains, a class of nitrogen-containing pigments.
Morphological_Features: Beta vulgaris is a diploid plant with 18 chromosomes. The flowers are produced in dense spike-like inflorescences, with very small hermaphroditic flowers sitting in one- to three- (rarely eight-) flowered glomerules in the axils of short bracts or in the upper half of the inflorescence without bracts. The fruits (utricles) are enclosed by the leathery and incurved perianth, with a lenticular, 2-3 mm horizontal seed containing an annular embryo and copious perisperm
Medicinal_Value: Historically, beets have been used medicinally by the ancient Greeks and Romans, primarily for their leaves. Modern research suggests potential health benefits from beets, such as their antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, but more clinical studies are needed to confirm specific medicinal uses.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Beta vulgaris is native to the Atlantic and Mediterranean coasts of Europe. It is widely cultivated globally, with major production in temperate regions of Europe, North America, and Asia.

Plant_Name: Ben Nut / Benzolive Tree / Drumstick Tree / Horseradish Tree / Jacinto / Moringa / West Indian Ben
Description: Moringa oleifera, also known as the "drumstick tree," "horseradish tree," or "miracle tree," is a fast-growing, drought-resistant, multi-purpose tree that can reach heights of 5-10 meters, sometimes up to 15 meters. It has a light, feathery canopy and is native to the northern foothills of India, Pakistan, and Nepal.
Parts_Used: All parts of the moringa tree are used, including the leaves, fruits, immature pods, and flowers, which are commonly incorporated into traditional foods for human consumption. The leaves are used as vegetables and for herbal medicine, while the oil from the seeds can be used for cooking, cosmetics, and water purification.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Moringa thrives in warm, semi-arid tropical climates with rainfall ranging from 250-3000 mm per year and at altitudes below 600 meters, although it has been recorded growing at up to 2000 meters. It can tolerate a wide range of environmental factors, including infertile soils, extreme heat, droughts, and moderate frosts, with an optimal temperature range of 25-35°C. Moringa prefers well-drained sandy or sandy loam soils but can also tolerate clayey soils, although it cannot withstand prolonged water accumulation.
Chemical_Properties: Moringa is known for its antifungal, antidepressant, anti-inflammatory, and antiviral properties, which aid in protecting cells from damage and boosting the body's immune system. The leaves contain a variety of proteins, vitamins, and minerals, while the oil from the seeds can restore liver enzymes to normal levels by reducing oxidative stress and increasing protein content in the liver.
Morphological_Features: Moringa has a light, feathery canopy and a spreading leaf canopy that makes it useful in intercropping agroforestry systems where shade is needed. The fruit is typically a 3-valved capsule, up to 10 to 60 cm in length, and is often identified as a "pod" that looks like a drumstick. The mature fruit splits open along each angle to expose the seeds, which are rounded and oily.
Medicinal_Value: Moringa has been used for decades and centuries because of its health benefits and medicinal properties. The leaves are used for herbal medicine, which aids in protecting the liver from damage caused by oxidation and toxicity. The oil from the seeds can also be used for water purification.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Moringa is widely grown in Nigeria, the Pacific Islands, the Caribbean, the Philippines, South Africa, Asia, Florida, and Latin America, in addition to its native range in India. It can adapt to regions affected by climate change, such as the Mediterranean basin, due to its great resistance to high temperatures and drought.

Description: Ziziphus nummularia, commonly known as jujube or ber, is a shrub or small tree of the Rhamnaceae family. It is characterized by its thorny branches and edible fruits.
Parts_Used: The fruits, leaves, seeds, and bark are utilized for various purposes including food and traditional medicine.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers arid to semi-arid climates with well-drained sandy or loamy soils. It thrives under full sun exposure with minimal water requirements once established.
Chemical_Properties: The fruit contains flavonoids, saponins, tannins, and alkaloids which contribute to its health benefits.
Morphological_Features: Ziziphus nummularia typically grows up to 3 meters tall with dense foliage. Its leaves are small and oval-shaped while the fruits are roundish drupes that turn yellow when ripe.
Medicinal_Value: Known for its nutritional value; the fruit is rich in vitamins C and B complex. It has been used traditionally for treating respiratory issues, digestive problems, and skin diseases
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This species is widely distributed across India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, and parts of Africa where it adapts well to dry conditions.

Description: Stachys officinalis, commonly known as betony, is an herbaceous perennial plant in the mint family (Lamiaceae). It has a clump-forming growth habit with medium green, puckered leaves that have scalloped edges. In summer, upright flower stalks rise above the basal foliage and produce purple, pink, or white-pink flowers.
Parts_Used: Betony leaves are the primary parts used medicinally. They are typically harvested when the plant is in bloom between July and August.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Betony thrives in sunny to semi-shady locations with humus-rich, loamy to clayey, well-drained soil. It is drought tolerant but prefers moderate moisture. Betony is hardy down to -5°C (-25°F) and does not require winter protection.
Chemical_Properties: The leaves of Stachys officinalis contain up to 15% tannins, which contribute to its bitter taste.
Morphological_Features: Stachys officinalis is a clump-forming perennial that grows 1.5-2 feet tall. It has medium green, puckered leaves with scalloped edges. Upright flower stalks produce purple, pink, or white-pink flowers in the summer.
Medicinal_Value: Betony leaves are traditionally used to support haemostasis, digestion, and liver function. They have also been used to treat headaches, toothaches, gallbladder or kidney stones, gastrointestinal issues, and respiratory conditions like asthma. In homeopathy, betony is used for gastrointestinal complaints and to support liver and pancreas function.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Stachys officinalis is native to Europe, Asia, and parts of North Africa. It grows equally well in North America and is found throughout England and Wales, though it is generally absent from Scotland and rare in Ireland.

Plant_Name: Bharangi / Blue glory / Blue butterfly bush
Description: Clerodendrum serratum, also known as the blue butterfly bush, is a flowering shrub native to parts of Asia. It is a member of the Lamiaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive blue or purple flowers that resemble the shape of a butterfly. The plant typically grows to a height of 1-3 meters and has simple, serrated leaves.
Parts_Used: The most commonly used parts of Clerodendrum serratum for medicinal purposes are the leaves, roots, and flowers.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Clerodendrum serratum thrives in warm, humid climates and prefers well-drained, fertile soil. It can tolerate partial shade but performs best in full sun. The plant is generally hardy and can withstand temperatures ranging from 15-35°C (59-95°F).
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains various phytochemicals, including iridoids, flavonoids, terpenoids, and alkaloids. Some of the key chemical constituents identified in Clerodendrum serratum include Iridoids (Serratin, 8-O-acetylharpagide, harpagide), Flavonoids (Luteolin, apigenin, quercetin), Terpenoids (Ursolic acid, oleanolic acid), Alkaloids (Clerodendrum alkaloids). These compounds contribute to the plant's medicinal properties and biological activities.
Morphological_Features:
Clerodendrum serratum is a perennial shrub with the
Erect, branched, and woody stem, simple, opposite, serrated, ovate to lanceolate in shape leaves, tubular, blue or purple color flowers, arranged in terminal cymes and drupe-like, containing 4 nutlets fruits.
Medicinal_Value: Clerodendrum serratum has been used in traditional medicine systems, particularly in India, for its various therapeutic properties. The plant has been used to treat conditions anti-inflammatory like arthritis, gout, and other inflammatory disorders. The phytochemicals in Clerodendrum serratum exhibit potent antioxidant activity, which may contribute to its health benefits. The plant's ability to protect the liver from damage and support liver function. Clerodendrum serratum has shown antimicrobial activity against various pathogens, including bacteria and fungi.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Clerodendrum serratum is native to parts of Asia, including india, nepal, bangladesh, myanmar, thailand and china. The plant can also be found in cultivation or naturalized in other tropical and subtropical regions around the world

Description: Semecarpus anacardium, commonly known as the marking nut tree, is a deciduous tree native to India. It is closely related to the cashew tree. The fruit is composed of two parts - a reddish-orange accessory fruit that is edible and sweet when ripe, and a black drupe that contains a toxic, irritant juice. The nut inside the black drupe, known as godambi, is edible when properly prepared.
Parts_Used: The different parts of the Semecarpus anacardium tree that are used include the fruit, nut, and seed. The red-orange accessory fruit is collected, dried in the sun, and consumed. The black drupe and its seed are also used, but require careful preparation to remove the toxic, irritant compounds.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Semecarpus anacardium is found in the outer Himalayas to the Coromandel Coast of India. It grows well in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring areas with moderate rainfall and well-drained soil.
Chemical_Properties: The nuts and seeds of Semecarpus anacardium contain a variety of biologically active compounds, including biflavonoids, phenolic compounds, bhilawanols, minerals, vitamins, and amino acids. These compounds contribute to the plant's diverse medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Semecarpus anacardium is a moderate-sized deciduous tree. The fruit is composed of a reddish-orange accessory fruit and a black drupe that grows at the end. The nut inside the black drupe is about 25 mm long, ovoid and smooth lustrous black.
Medicinal_Value: In Ayurvedic medicine, Semecarpus anacardium is used to improve sexual power, increase sperm count, cure digestive disorders, balance phlegm (kapha dosha), and induce abortion. The nut and fruit extracts also exhibit antiatherogenic, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antimicrobial, and anticarcinogenic properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Semecarpus anacardium is native to India and found in the outer Himalayas to the Coromandel Coast. It is also cultivated in other parts of Southeast Asia.

Plant_Name: Bhojpatra / cao pi hua / Himalayan birch
Description: Betula utilis is a deciduous tree native to the Western Himalayas, growing at elevations up to 4,500 m (14,800 ft). It typically forms forests, growing as a shrub or tree reaching up to 20 m (66 ft) tall. The leaves are ovate, 5 to 10 cm (2.0 to 3.9 in) long, with serrated margins and slightly hairy. The thin, papery bark is very shiny, reddish brown, reddish white, or white, with horizontal lenticels. The bark peels off in broad, horizontal belts, making it very usable for creating even large pages for texts.
Parts_Used: The bark, leaves, and wood of the Betula utilis tree are used. The bark is the most widely utilized part, having been used for centuries in India as paper for writing lengthy texts. The wood is very hard, heavy, and brittle.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Betula utilis depends on moisture from snowmelt rather than monsoon rains. It grows best in full sun to part shade, in moist, acidic, well-drained loams, and is adapted to cool northern climates. It suffers in humid, hot summers and is sensitive to the bronze birch borer pest.
Chemical_Properties: The bark of Betula utilis contains triterpenoids such as betulin, betulinic acid, and lupeol.
Morphological_Features: Betula utilis has ovate leaves, 5-10 cm long, with serrated margins. The bark is thin, papery, and peels off in broad, horizontal belts. Flowering occurs from May-July, with male catkins and short, single or paired female catkins. The fruits ripen in September-October.
Medicinal_Value: The bark of Betula utilis is reported to have antiseptic and carminative properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Betula utilis is widely distributed in Central Asia, from Kazakhstan through Afghanistan and the Himalayas of Pakistan, India, Nepal, Bhutan to central China.

Description: Eclipta alba, also known as bhringraj or false daisy, is a species of flowering plant in the family Asteraceae. It is a trailing herb with cylindrical, grayish roots and solid, circular, purplish stems covered in white fine hairs. The leaves are arranged in opposite pairs, hairy on both sides, lanceolate in shape, and serrated along the edges, measuring 2–12.5 cm long and 5-35 mm wide.
Parts_Used: The whole plant of Eclipta alba is used in traditional medicine.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Eclipta alba grows well in warm, moist environments and is commonly found in damp wastelands, low waterlogged areas, roadsides, paddy fields, and other crop fields. It can grow in a variety of soil types from sandy to clay, and is found at elevations up to 2000 meters.
Chemical_Properties: Eclipta alba contains various phytochemicals such as coumestans, polypeptides, polyacetylenes, thiophene derivatives, steroids, sterols, triterpenes, and flavonoids.
Morphological_Features: The plant has solitary flower heads that are 6–8 mm in diameter, with white florets. The achenes (fruit) are compressed and narrowly winged.
Medicinal_Value: In Ayurvedic medicine, Eclipta alba is used to treat a variety of health conditions and is believed to prevent greying of hair.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Eclipta alba is widely distributed throughout India, Nepal, China, Thailand, Bangladesh, and Brazil, growing in warm temperate to tropical areas worldwide.

Description: Bidens pilosa is an annual, branched forb that can grow up to 1.8 meters tall. It has opposite, pinnately compound leaves with 3-5 serrated, ovate-lanceolate leaflets. The plant produces small flower heads with white ray florets surrounding yellow disc florets, which develop into barbed, black fruits about 1 cm long with 2-3 stiff awns. The fruits form burr-like infructescences that easily attach to clothing, fur, and feathers, allowing for effective seed dispersal.
Parts_Used: The leaves, stems, and entire aerial parts of Bidens pilosa are commonly used.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Bidens  grows best in moist, shady locations and can tolerate a wide temperature range of 15-40°C. It is widely distributed in tropical and warm temperate regions worldwide.
Chemical_Properties: Bidens contains a variety of bioactive compounds, including polyacetylenes, flavonoids, phenylpropanoid glucosides, diterpenes, and essential oils rich in compounds like β-caryophyllene and τ-cadinene. These contribute to its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and other medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Bidens has branched, ridged stems; opposite, pinnately compound leaves; small yellow flower heads with white ray florets; and barbed, black fruits that form burr-like infructescences.
Medicinal_Value: Bidens pilosa has been used traditionally to treat inflammation, hypertension, ulcers, diabetes, and other conditions. Its extracts and compounds exhibit anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, anti-diabetic, and other potentially beneficial biological activities.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Bidens pilosa is native to tropical America but is now widely naturalized and considered invasive in many tropical and warm temperate regions globally, including Africa, Asia, Australia, and the Pacific Islands.

Plant_Name: Bitter melon / Balsam pear / Bitter gourd / Karon Akhaba / Karela
Description: Momordica charantia, commonly known as bitter melon, is a tropical and subtropical vine belonging to the Cucurbitaceae family. It is widely grown in Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean for its edible fruit. The plant has several varieties that differ in the shape and bitterness of the fruit.
Parts_Used: The entire plant of Momordica charantia is used for medicinal and culinary purposes, including the fruit, leaves, seeds, and roots.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Bitter melon thrives in warm, humid climates and requires full sun exposure. It grows best in temperatures between 20-35°C (68-95°F) and can tolerate a wide range of soil types, but prefers well-drained, fertile soil.
Chemical_Properties: Bitter melon contains a variety of bioactive compounds, including polypeptide-P, charantin, cucurbitacins, and vicine. These compounds are believed to contribute to the plant's hypoglycemic, antioxidant, and anticancer properties.
Morphological_Features: Bitter melon is a climbing vine with tendrils. The leaves are alternate, palmately lobed, and have a distinctive warty appearance. The fruit is oblong, green, and covered in bumps or spines, with a bitter taste. The seeds are red in color.
Medicinal_Value: Bitter melon has been used in traditional medicine systems to treat a variety of conditions, including diabetes, digestive issues, wounds, and more. Studies suggest it has hypoglycemic, antibacterial, antiviral, and anticancer properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Karela is native to Africa and is widely cultivated in Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean. It is particularly popular in the cuisines of East Asia, South Asia, and Southeast Asia.

Description: Citrus aurantium, commonly known as bitter orange or sour orange, is an evergreen tree that can grow up to 10 m tall. It has a spreading crown and angled branchlets, some of which bear slender spines. The leaves are simple, alternate, subcoriaceous, dotted with glands, and aromatic when bruised. The petiole is 2-3 cm long with a narrowly to broadly winged upper half, and the blade is broadly ovate to elliptical, 7-12 cm long and 4-7 cm wide.
Parts_Used: The most commonly used parts of Citrus aurantium are the peels and flowers, which have been the focus of extensive research for their medicinal properties. The leaves have not yet been studied extensively, but a study on the essential oil of bitter orange leaves from Algeria found it to be rich in linalool, linalyl acetate, and α-Terpineol.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Citrus aurantium requires a warm climate with an optimum average annual temperature of 22-24°C, but it can tolerate temperatures up to 45°C, provided soil moisture is adequate. It performs best at altitudes below 500 m, with optimal growth up to 300 m. Cold weather may cause damage, especially to trees weakened by diseases or pests, and frost can be fatal.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil extracted from Citrus aurantium peels is rich in limonene, while the flowers contain linalool and linalyl acetate as the main components. The leaves have not been studied as extensively, but a study found that the essential oil from Algerian bitter orange leaves contains a high percentage of linalool, linalyl acetate, and α-Terpineol.
Morphological_Features: Citrus aurantium is a tree with a rounded crown and much-branched stems. The young twigs are angled and bear slender short spines, while older branches have stout spines up to 8 cm long. The flowers are axillary, single or in fascicles of 2-3, very fragrant, and usually bisexual, with 5-12% male flowers. The fruit is a depressed-globose hesperidium, 5-8 cm in diameter, with 8-12 segments, a thick, smooth to warty, strongly aromatic peel, and very acid and slightly bitter pulp. The seeds are numerous and polyembryonic.
Medicinal_Value: Citrus aurantium has a wide array of medicinal properties. The peels and flowers have been extensively studied and found to have many therapeutic applications. The essential oil from the leaves has shown interesting levels of elastase and collagenase inhibition, suggesting potential as an anti-aging agent. Sweet orange is also active as an anti-diabetic, anti-obesity, and hypocholesterolemic agent.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Citrus aurantium is commonly cultivated in warm regions worldwide. It is native to Southeast Asia, possibly Cochinchina, and was introduced to Europe in the 11th century, becoming one of the first Citrus species introduced to the New World. Large-scale studies on Citrus aurantium have been conducted in Tunisia and Greece.

Description: Solanum nigrum, also known as black nightshade, is an annual or perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe. It grows between 0.1 m and 1 m in height and can vary widely in its growth form, with stems that are either erect or spreading and occasionally prostrate. The leaves are elliptic to oval with pointed tips, 3 to 7 cm in length, sometimes edged with coarse irregular teeth and wavy margins, and generally dark green to purple-green in color. The flowers are white with five petals fused at the base and yellow centers, 8 to 12 mm across. The fruit is a shiny berry that is dark green when initially produced and changes to purple-black when ripe, between 5 and 13 mm in diameter.
Parts_Used: The parts of black nightashade used include the leaves, stems, and berries. The leaves and stems are used as a vegetable after boiling to remove toxins, and the berries are consumed after ripening. The young leaves and shoots are boiled several times to remove toxins and are then used as a vegetable similar to spinach.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Black nightshade can grow in a variety of weather conditions, including tropical and subtropical agro-climatic regions. It can be sown from April to May in fertilized nursery beds and is adapted to a range of soil types, including dry, shallow, stony, or deep soils. It is susceptible to frost and usually dies in winter but can survive in relatively mild conditions.
Chemical_Properties: Solanum nigrum contains solanine, a toxic compound that is most concentrated in the unripe green berries. Solanine poisoning symptoms include fever, sweating, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, confusion, and drowsiness. The plant is rarely fatal, but large amounts can cause cardiac arrhythmias and respiratory failure. The toxins are water-soluble and are destroyed by boiling.
Morphological_Features: The plant has elliptic to oval leaves with pointed tips, 3 to 7 cm in length, sometimes edged with coarse irregular teeth and wavy margins, and generally dark green to purple-green in color. The flowers are white with five petals fused at the base and yellow centers, 8 to 12 mm across. The fruit is a shiny berry that is dark green when initially produced and changes to purple-black when ripe, between 5 and 13 mm in diameter.
Medicinal_Value: While black nightshade contains toxic compounds, some parts of the plant have been used medicinally. The young leaves and shoots are boiled several times to remove toxins and are then used as a vegetable similar to spinach. The plant has been used in ethnobotanical accounts for its nutritional value, and the cooked leaves are a source of many useful nutrients.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Solanum nigrum is native to Europe and can grow in tropical and subtropical regions. It is commonly found throughout the eastern and midwestern United States and is a pest of soybean and other vegetable crops. It can grow in a variety of soil types and is capable of surviving in relatively mild conditions.

Description: Black pepper (Piper nigrum) is a climbing perennial plant in the family Piperaceae. It is mainly grown for its fruit, which is processed to create black, white, and green peppercorns, commonly used as a spice in cooking. The plant features simple, alternating leaves with an oval shape and produces clusters, or spikes, of 50 to 150 flowers. These flowers give rise to small, spherical green fruits that ripen to red. Each stem has the potential to produce 20-30 of these spikes. While black pepper can grow to a height of 10 meters (33 feet) in the wild, under cultivation, it is usually maintained at a more manageable 3-4 meters (10-13 feet). Black pepper is a perennial plant with a lifespan of over 30 years, and it typically has a commercial lifespan of 12–20 years. This versatile spice is native to south and southeast Asia.
Parts_Used: The parts of the black pepper plant used are the fruit, which is processed to create black, white, and green peppercorns. The distinct types of pepper are obtained by harvesting at different stages of ripeness and applying different processing techniques. Black pepper is the result of drying the fruit to produce the familiar black peppercorns. White pepper is produced by soaking the fruits in water for about a week to recover the seed from the decomposed fruit. Green pepper is produced by drying unripe fruit in a way that retains its green color. Green peppercorns are often preserved by pickling.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Black pepper thrives in specific climatic conditions, which are crucial for its successful cultivation. It grows best in well-draining soils rich in organic matter. The ideal soil pH for black pepper is around 5.5 to 6.5. It requires good soil aeration and texture for healthy root development. Black pepper is a tropical crop and prefers warm temperatures. The ideal temperature range for black pepper is 23°C to 32°C, with an average of 28°C. Adequate spacing is crucial for black pepper vines to grow well. Typically, black pepper vines need about 3-4 meters of spacing between them, as they are climbers and require room to spread and climb. Black pepper plants require partial to full sunlight for healthy growth.
Chemical_Properties: Black pepper seeds contain various components, including essential oil, piperine, chavicine, piperidine, fatty oils, resin, starch, and water. The alkaloid piperine is primarily responsible for the sharp taste associated with pepper. Black pepper packs vitamins (K, E, A, B) and minerals (manganese, copper, iron) for bone health, immunity, energy, and more. The main component of black pepper is piperine, which has a complex phyto-chemistry that includes volatile oil, alkaloids, and oleoresins. Piperine has a therapeutic potential against a number of diseases and is used in herbal medicine due to its free-radical scavenging properties.
Morphological_Features: Black pepper plants may have either vining or bushy, woody stems. The plant features simple, alternating leaves with an oval shape. It produces clusters, or spikes, of 50 to 150 flowers. These flowers give rise to small, spherical green fruits that ripen to red. Each stem has the potential to produce 20-30 of these spikes. The plant develops three types of aerial shoots: primary stems with long internodes, runner shoots originating from the base of the vine, and top shoots or orthotropes, which grow laterally and produce adventitious roots at the nodes.
Medicinal_Value: Black pepper and its active components have therapeutic potential against a number of diseases. The bioactive components contained in black pepper are extremely important due to their therapeutic potential. Piperine, the main component of black pepper, has been shown to have anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anti-cancer properties. It is used in herbal medicine and is classified as a functional food because it provides physiological benefits and helps to avoid chronic illness.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Black pepper is native to south and southeast Asia and is grown in various tropical and subtropical regions worldwide. It is cultivated in countries such as India, Malaysia, Indonesia, and tropical Africa. The plant is indigenous to the tropical forests of the Western Ghats of South India and is grown in about 1.36 lakhs ha land with an annual production of 32 thousand tonnes, largely distributed in Kerala (94%), Karnataka (5%), the rest being Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, and north eastern states especially Assam.

Description: Juglans nigra, commonly known as the eastern black walnut, is a deciduous tree native to North America that grows 30-40 m (100-150 ft) tall with a trunk 3-6 ft in diameter. It has a rounded crown, alternate odd-pinnately compound leaves, and produces edible nuts. The tree has a very characteristic pungent or spicy odor in most parts including the leaves, stems, and fruit husks.
Parts_Used: The edible nuts, wood, and yellow dye from the fruit husks are the main parts used. The nuts are used in candy-making, cleaning abrasives, and explosives. The heartwood is highly valued for furniture, cabinets, veneer, and gun-stocks.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Black walnut prefers full sun, moist well-drained soils, and grows best in rich bottom lands, moist coves, and lower slopes. It is intolerant of shade and drought. The tree is hardy in USDA zones 5-9.
Chemical_Properties: The tree contains juglone, a chemical that inhibits the growth of some plants like azaleas, peonies, tomatoes, apples, and blueberries beneath the tree's dripline. An edible oil can be obtained from the seeds but it tends to go rancid quickly.
Morphological_Features: Black walnut has an upright spreading open form, with an ovoid crown, tall trunk, and very deep taproot. The leaves are 2-4 inches long, green, deciduous, and turn yellow in fall. The fruit is a round nut 1-3 inches long with a green to black husk.
Medicinal_Value: Historically, Native Americans used the tree medicinally, but it is now considered a scarce native hardwood.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: The tree is native to a broad swath of central and eastern North America, from southern Ontario west to southeast South Dakota, south to Georgia, northern Florida and southwest to central Texas. It grows naturally in riparian zones and may be confined to floodplains near the western edge of its range.

Description: Ribes nigrum, commonly known as the black currant, is a deciduous shrub native to central and northern Europe and northern Asia. It typically grows to a height of 1.5 meters. The plant is self-fertile.
Parts_Used: The leaves and fruits of the black currant plant are used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Black currants are favored by cool climates and are widely cultivated in cooler parts of the temperate zone, especially in Europe and northern Asia. Higher latitudes (66°34'N vs 60°23'N) in Finland were found to produce berries with higher volatile compound content.
Chemical_Properties: Monoterpene hydrocarbons and oxygenated monoterpenes were found to be the major classes of volatile compounds in black currant berries. Higher radiation and temperatures during the last month before harvest were negatively correlated with volatile content.
Morphological_Features: Black currant is a deciduous shrub. The leaves are used medicinally.
Medicinal_Value: The leaves of black currant are astringent. The plant can be used in disorders involving corticotropic, cortico-somatotropic or cortico-gonadotropic activity.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Black currants are widely cultivated in cooler parts of the temperate zone, especially in Europe and northern Asia.

Description: Caulophyllum thalictroides, commonly known as blue cohosh, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to eastern North America. It is a member of the barberry family (Berberidaceae). The plant grows 30-60 cm tall and has distinctive blue-green, trifoliate leaves and small, greenish-yellow flowers that bloom in early spring. The most distinctive feature is the spherical, blue berry-like fruits that develop later in the season and are held stiffly above the foliage.
Parts_Used: The rhizome (underground stem) and roots of the blue cohosh plant are the parts most commonly used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Blue cohosh prefers consistently moist, well-drained soils and partial to full shade conditions. It is found naturally in floodplains, forests, and other shaded, moist habitats across its native range.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains several bioactive alkaloids, including methylcytisine, anagyrine, baptifoline, and magnoflorine. It also contains steroidal saponins like caulosaponin and caulophyllosaponin.
Morphological_Features: Blue cohosh is an herbaceous perennial with trifoliate, blue-green leaves. The small, greenish-yellow flowers bloom in early spring and develop into distinctive spherical, blue berry-like fruits later in the season.
Medicinal_Value: Blue cohosh has a history of use by Native Americans as a general tonic and to treat a variety of conditions, including menstrual cramps, muscle spasms, inflammation, and to induce labor. However, its safety and efficacy for many of these uses is not well-established.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Blue cohosh is native to eastern North America, ranging from Quebec and Ontario south to Georgia and Alabama. It is found in the wild across this region, particularly in moist, shaded forest habitats.

Plant_Name: Blue gum / Eucalyptus / Tasmanian blue gum / Southern blue gum
Description: Eucalyptus globulus, commonly known as the Tasmanian blue gum or southern blue gum, is a tall, evergreen tree that can grow up to 70 meters in height and have a diameter of 4 to 7 feet. It is a member of the Myrtaceae family and was first discovered on the island of Tasmania in 1792.
Parts_Used: The different parts of the Eucalyptus globulus tree, including the leaves, buds, and essential oils, have been used for various purposes. The leaves and essential oils are particularly valuable for their medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Eucalyptus globulus thrives in temperate climates and requires well-drained soil. It is adapted to a wide range of climatic conditions and can grow in areas with moderate to high rainfall. The tree is also relatively drought-tolerant.
Chemical_Properties: Eucalyptus globulus is rich in phytochemical constituents, including 1,8-cineole, cryptophane, and various esters, carboxylic acids, and aldehydes. These compounds contribute to the tree's medicinal and therapeutic properties.
Morphological_Features: Eucalyptus globulus is a tall, evergreen tree with a straight, cylindrical trunk and a spreading, open canopy. The leaves are long, narrow, and blue-green in color, with a distinctive waxy coating. The tree also produces white, cup-shaped flowers.
Medicinal_Value: Eucalyptus globulus has a wide range of medicinal properties, including anti-inflammatory, analgesic, anti-nociceptive, antimicrobial, antifungal, antiviral, and antioxidant activities. The essential oils and extracts from the tree have been used to treat various ailments, such as respiratory infections, skin conditions, and insect infestations.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Eucalyptus globulus is native to southeastern Australia, particularly the island of Tasmania. However, it has been introduced and cultivated in many other parts of the world, including the Mediterranean region, South America, and parts of Africa and Asia.

Plant_Name: Blue spur flower/ Indian Coleus / Woolly plectranthus
Description: Plectranthus barbatus, commonly known as woolly plectranthus or blue spur flower, is a tropical perennial plant belonging to the Lamiaceae family. It is characterized by its large, bushy structure and produces deep blue to purple flowers. The plant can grow up to 5-8 feet tall and wide, making it a striking addition to gardens. It is notable for its medicinal properties, particularly its ability to produce forskolin, a compound with various pharmaceutical applications.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Plectranthus barbatus utilized in traditional medicine are its roots and leaves. The roots are particularly valued for their therapeutic properties, while the leaves can also be used for various herbal applications.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Plectranthus barbatus thrives in USDA hardiness zones 9 to 11, preferring full sun to partial shade.
