It is drought-tolerant but benefits from regular irrigation for optimal growth. The plant is not frost-tolerant; however, it can resprout after frost damage if temperatures do not drop below 20 to 25 °F. It prefers well-draining soil and can tolerate short periods of drought due to its ability to store water in its stems.
Chemical_Properties: The plant is known for its phytochemical constituents, including various terpenoids and flavonoids, which contribute to its medicinal and therapeutic properties. Research has highlighted its potential anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antimicrobial effects, making it significant in traditional medicine practices.
Morphological_Features: Plectranthus barbatus exhibits a robust structure with thick stems and large, hairy leaves that have serrated margins. The flowers are typically pink to white and appear in clusters, adding to the plant's ornamental appeal. Its growth habit is bushy, making it suitable for use as a hedge or backdrop in garden settings.
Medicinal_Value: This plant is widely recognized in traditional medicine, particularly in Ayurvedic practices, where it is referred to as Gandhmoolika. It is used for treating various ailments, including respiratory issues and digestive disorders. The roots are consumed for their health benefits, and the plant is also noted for its potential use in modern herbal medicine due to its bioactive compounds.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Plectranthus barbatus is native to a broad range that includes regions in Pakistan, India, Nepal, and parts of East Africa. It has been naturalized in various countries, including Brazil and Sri Lanka, due to its adaptability and the demand for its medicinal properties. The plant is cultivated in many tropical and subtropical regions worldwide, where it is appreciated for both its aesthetic and functional uses.

Description: Eupatorium perfoliatum, commonly known as boneset, is a large, hairy, clump-forming perennial native to eastern and central North America. It typically grows 4-6 feet tall with wrinkled, lance-shaped leaves that have bases that join to surround the hairy stems (hence the name "perfoliatum" meaning "through the foliage"). The plant produces flat-topped clusters of small, fluffy white flowers in late summer to fall.
Parts_Used: The leaves, flowers, and stems of Eupatorium perfoliatum have been traditionally used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Eupatorium perfoliatum prefers moist, wet soils and full sun to partial shade. It grows well in a variety of soil types including clay, loam, and sandy soils. The plant requires constant moisture and may flop in rich, fertile soils.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains various phytochemicals including volatile oils, caffeic acid derivatives, flavonoids, sesquiterpene lactones, and tannins. It also contains potentially toxic pyrrolizidine alkaloids.
Morphological_Features: Eupatorium perfoliatum is a large, clump-forming perennial with hairy, wrinkled leaves that have bases that join around the stem. The small white flowers are arranged in flat-topped clusters at the top of the stems.
Medicinal_Value: Historically, Eupatorium perfoliatum has been used in traditional medicine to treat a variety of conditions including fevers, colds, flu, and rheumatism. Research indicates the plant may have anti-inflammatory, antiplasmodial, and immunomodulating properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Eupatorium perfoliatum is native to eastern and central North America, ranging from Canada to the southeastern United States.

Description: Bacopa monnieri is a perennial, creeping herb native to the wetlands of southern and Eastern India, Australia, Europe, Africa, Asia, and North and South America. It is known by common names such as water hyssop, waterhyssop, brahmi, thyme-leafed gratiola, herb of grace, and Indian pennywort. Bacopa monnieri is a non-aromatic herb with succulent, oblong leaves that are 4–6 mm thick and arranged oppositely on the stem. The small, white flowers have four to five petals.
Parts_Used: The whole plant of Bacopa monnieri is used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Bacopa monnieri commonly grows in marshy areas and can even tolerate slightly brackish conditions. It is found throughout India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, China, Pakistan, Taiwan, Vietnam, tropical and southern Africa, on Madagascar, in Australia, in the Caribbean, and in Middle and South America. It used to be found growing wild in freshwater swamps of Singapore and nearby regions known as beremi.
Chemical_Properties: The best characterized phytochemicals in Bacopa monnieri are dammarane-type triterpenoid saponins known as bacosides, with jujubogenin or pseudo-jujubogenin moieties as aglycone units. Other compounds include alkaloids like brahmine, nicotine, and herpestine, as well as D-mannitol, apigenin, hersaponin, monnierasides, cucurbitacin, and plantainoside B.
Morphological_Features: Bacopa monnieri is a non-aromatic herb with succulent, oblong leaves that are 4–6 mm thick and arranged oppositely on the stem. The small, white flowers have four to five petals.
Medicinal_Value: Bacopa monnieri has been used in Ayurvedic traditional medicine for centuries, with beliefs that it may improve memory and treat various other ailments. Preliminary research suggests it may improve cognition, specifically memory and learning, although the effect is only measurable after several weeks of use. However, the FDA has warned against unproven claims that Bacopa monnieri can treat or prevent diseases like Alzheimer's, stomach issues, and anxiety.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Bacopa monnieri is one of the most widespread Bacopa species, commonly growing in marshy areas throughout India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, China, Pakistan, Taiwan, Vietnam, tropical and southern Africa, on Madagascar, in Australia, in the Caribbean, and in Middle and South America. It is also found in Florida, Louisiana, Texas, and Hawaii in the United States.

Description: Brihati is a medicinal plant belonging to the Solanaceae family.
Parts_Used: The whole plant, especially the roots and fruits, is used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Solanum indicum requires a warm, preferably dry climate with abundant sunshine. The optimal temperature range is 21-27°C. In northern India, the plant can be adversely affected by frost during December-January, but it recovers in the spring season.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains alkaloids such as carpesterol, solanocarpine, solasonine, solamargine and β-solamargine.
Morphological_Features: Brihati is a perennial shrub that grows 60-250 cm in height. The stems are greenish-yellow or purple in color and covered with straight or curved yellow, purple spines. The leaves are ovate to oblong in shape, 5-15 cm long, and have a wavy margin.
Medicinal_Value: The plant has anthelmintic, bronchitis-relieving, fever-reducing, thirst-quenching, and diuretic properties. The leaves are used to treat piles, and the fruits are laxative.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Solanum indicum is found in Asia, Africa, Australia and India.

Description: Dodonaea viscosa, known as the broadleaf hop bush, is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 7 meters tall. It has a bushy appearance with leathery leaves that are alternate and simple.
Parts_Used: The leaves, stems, and roots are used for various medicinal preparations. The leaves are often utilized in traditional remedies.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers warm temperate to tropical climates and thrives in well-drained soils. It can tolerate drought conditions but flourishes with adequate moisture.
Chemical_Properties: Phytochemical analysis reveals the presence of flavonoids, alkaloids, terpenoids, saponins, and tannins which contribute to its medicinal properties
Morphological_Features: Dodonaea viscosa features inconspicuous flowers that lack petals; they are dioecious, meaning male and female flowers occur on separate plants. Its fruits are distinctive winged capsules that mature from green to red.
Medicinal_Value: This plant is noted for its anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and analgesic properties. It is traditionally used for treating rheumatism, skin infections, gastrointestinal issues, and as an antipyretic
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Originally native to Australia, it has spread throughout tropical regions including Africa, the Americas, southern Asia, and Australasia

Description: Broccoli is a green vegetable that belongs to the cabbage family, Brassicaceae. It is known for its edible flowering head, which is typically dark green and arranged in a tree-like structure branching out from a thick, light green stalk. The leaves surrounding the head are also edible. Broccoli is highly nutritious and valued for its health benefits.
Parts_Used: Flowering heads , Stalks , Leaves (sometimes used in culinary dishes)
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Broccoli prefers cool weather and grows best in temperatures between 65-75°F (18-24°C). It can tolerate light frost but not high temperatures, which can cause it to bolt (flower prematurely). It Requires well-drained soil with a pH of 6.0 to 7.0. Adequate sunlight (at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day).
Chemical_Properties: Broccoli is a rich source of antioxidants, including vitamins C, K, and A. It also contains several important minerals, including potassium, calcium, and iron. These antioxidants help protect the body from oxidative stress and reduce inflammation. The major compounds were linoleic acid, palmitic acid. linolenic acid, oleic acid, stearic acid and myrestic acid. It contains significant amounts of vitamin A, folate, and dietary fiber. High in sulforaphane, a compound believed to have potent anti-cancer properties. Contains various antioxidants and phytonutrients like lutein, zeaxanthin, and beta-carotene.
Morphological_Features: The plant has a thick, fibrous stalk that branches out into several green flower heads. Leaves are broad, green, and slightly wavy with a waxy texture. Broccoli heads are clusters of tightly packed flower buds, which are harvested before they bloom.
Medicinal_Value: Broccoli contains glucosinolates, which the body can convert into substances that may help fight cancer. Broccoli's fiber, fatty acids, and vitamins may help regulate blood pressure, lower cholesterol, and protect blood vessels. Broccoli is rich in vitamin C, which is essential for immune function and may help prevent and treat illnesses. It also contains sulfur, which may support gut health and help protect against infection. Broccoli contains nutrients that may help with bone formation and prevent bone density loss. Broccoli may help protect the retina and eye lens, and reduce the risk of macular degeneration and cataracts.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Broccoli is widely grown in temperate climates across the world. Major producers include China, India, the United States, Italy, and Spain. It is also grown in regions with similar climates in Europe, Australia, and Canada.

Description: Sarothamnus scoparius, commonly known as Scotch broom or common broom, is a deciduous leguminous shrub native to western and central Europe. It typically grows 1-3 meters (3-10 feet) tall, with main stems up to 5 cm (2 inches) thick, rarely reaching 4 m (13 ft) in height.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of the plant, including the stems, leaves, flowers, and seed pods, are used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Sarothamnus scoparius is adapted to Mediterranean and coastal climates, and its range is limited by cold winter temperatures. It also adapts to windy oceanic climates. The plant prefers sunny sites on dry, sandy soils at low altitudes and can tolerate very acidic soil conditions.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains toxic alkaloids such as cytisine that depress the heart and nervous system. It also contains biogenic amines, flavonoids, isoflavones, and quinolizidine alkaloids like sparteine, lupanine, and scoparin.
Morphological_Features: Sarothamnus scoparius has green, ridged stems and small, deciduous trifoliate leaves 5-15 mm long. In spring and summer, it is covered in profuse golden yellow flowers 20-30 mm long and 15-20 mm wide. The seed pods are 2-3 cm long, 8 mm broad, and 2-3 mm thick, with long hairs only along the seams. The pods burst open forcefully, throwing the seeds from the parent plant.
Medicinal_Value: Despite serious safety concerns, Sarothamnus scoparius has been used traditionally for heart problems, fluid retention, poor circulation, low blood pressure, fast heartbeat, and irregular heartbeat. It has also been used for bleeding disorders, gout, muscle/joint pain, nerve disorders, gallstones, kidney stones, and other conditions, though evidence for its effectiveness is insufficient.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Sarothamnus scoparius is native to western and central Europe, including Great Britain and Ireland. Outside its native range, it has become an invasive species in grasslands, shrublands, and woodlands in other parts of the world.

Description: Kalanchoe pinnata is a succulent, perennial plant that grows up to 1 m (39 in) tall. It has fleshy cylindrical stems and young growth with a reddish tinge. The leaves are thick, fleshy, elliptical in shape, curved, with a crenate or serrated margin, often reddish. The leaves are simple at the base of the stem and imparipinnate at the top, 10–30 cm (4–12 in) long, with three to five pairs of fleshy limb lobes.
Parts_Used: The leaves and leaf extracts are the most commonly used parts of Kalanchoe pinnata for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Kalanchoe pinnata can be found in warm and temperate climates from sea level to 2,600 m (8,500 ft), occupying sites on rock in tropical evergreen and dry deciduous forests, as well as montane forests.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains various phytochemicals such as flavonoids, bufadienolides, and organic acids, which contribute to its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The leaves are remarkable for their ability to produce bulbils. At their margin, between the teeth, adventitious buds appear, which produce roots, stems, and leaves. The terminal inflorescence is a panicle, with many pendent, red-orange flowers. The calyx is formed of a long tube, red at the base, veined with yellowish green (or green spotted with reddish brown), with four very small triangular lobes at the end. The tubular corolla, with a pronounced constriction separating the subspherical part of the ovoid part, is terminated by four lobes which reaches 5 cm (2.0 in) in length. It is yellowish in color with red-purple streaks.
Medicinal_Value: Kalanchoe pinnata has been used in traditional medicine for the treatment of various ailments, including headaches, cuts, wounds, eye diseases, stomach disorders, jaundice, pain, fever, diarrhea, and cutaneous lesions.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Kalanchoe pinnata is native to Madagascar and has become naturalized in tropical and subtropical areas, including parts of Asia, Africa, Australia, New Zealand, the West Indies, Bermuda, Macaronesia, the Mascarenes, Brazil, Suriname, the Galapagos Islands, Melanesia, Polynesia, and Hawaii.

Description: Agathosma betulina, commonly known as round-leaf buchu, is a flowering plant native to the lower elevation mountains of western South Africa, particularly in fynbos habitats near streams. This evergreen shrub typically grows to about 2 meters (6.7 feet) tall and features opposite, rounded leaves that are glossy and fragrant, measuring approximately 20 mm (0.79 inches) in length and width. The flowers are white or pale pink, comprising five petals, while the fruit is a five-part capsule that opens to release seeds.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of buchu utilized for medicinal and culinary purposes are its leaves. These leaves are rich in essential oils and are used to create various preparations, including teas, tinctures, and oils. The essential oils extracted from the leaves contain key compounds such as isomenthone and diosphenol, which contribute to the plant's flavor and therapeutic properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Agathosma betulina thrives in well-drained, acidic soil with a pH range of 3.5 to 6.5. It prefers full sun to partial shade and requires moderate watering, particularly in winter, while being able to withstand periods of drought once established. The plant is sensitive to soil disturbance and benefits from mulching to maintain root moisture and temperature.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oils of buchu contain several significant compounds, including isomenthone, diosphenol, limonene, menthone, and l-pulegone. These compounds are responsible for the plant's characteristic aroma and flavor, as well as its medicinal effects. The oil has been noted for its antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties, making it valuable in traditional medicine.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Agathosma betulina is characterized by its evergreen shrub form, reaching heights of up to 2 meters. The leaves are rounded, glossy, and aromatic, contributing to the plant's distinctive fragrance. The flowers are solitary and star-shaped, typically white or pale purple, and the fruit is a five-parted capsule.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally, Agathosma betulina has been used by indigenous South African peoples for various medicinal purposes, particularly for treating urinary tract infections and digestive issues. The leaves are often made into teas or tinctures and have been used as a natural flavoring agent. Its essential oils are also employed in cosmetics and other products due to their therapeutic properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Buchu is primarily found in the Cape region of South Africa, where it grows in fynbos ecosystems. While it is cultivated for commercial use, particularly for its essential oils, its natural habitat remains crucial for its sustainability. Efforts are being made to cultivate this species due to concerns about overharvesting in the wild.

Description: Rhododendron falconeri is an evergreen shrub or small tree native to the Himalayas. It can reach heights of up to 10 meters.
Parts_Used: The leaves and flowers are primarily used for their medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant thrives in cool, moist environments with acidic soils. It prefers partial shade and high humidity.
Chemical_Properties: Rhododendron falconeri contains flavonoids, tannins, and other phenolic compounds that exhibit antioxidant properties.
Morphological_Features: It features large leathery leaves with a glossy surface and produces beautiful trumpet-shaped flowers that range from white to pale yellow.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used in herbal medicine for its anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects, it is also believed to support respiratory health.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This species is found primarily in the Himalayas but can also be cultivated in similar temperate regions around the world.

Description: Cissampelos pareira, is a climbing shrub belonging to the Menispermaceae family. This plant features slender, pubescent stems and can grow as a lofty climber, often reaching heights that allow it to twine around other vegetation. The leaves are typically orbicular or broadly ovate, measuring between 2.5 to 12 cm in length and 2.5 to 11.5 cm in width. They are characterized by a cordate or truncate base and may exhibit a tomentose texture on both surfaces. The flowers are small and greenish-yellow, with male and female flowers occurring in distinct clusters. The fruit is a globose drupe, which is hairy and scarlet when fresh, turning black upon drying.
Parts_Used: The medicinal properties of Cissampelos pareira are derived from various parts of the plant, including roots, bark, leaves. These parts are utilized in traditional medicine for their diverse therapeutic benefits.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Pareira thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. It prefers warm, humid conditions and is typically found at elevations up to 4,000 feet, with some occurrences noted as high as 6,000 feet in India. The plant is adaptable to various soil types but flourishes best in well-drained, fertile soils that retain moisture.
Chemical_Properties: The plant is rich in bioactive compounds, particularly isoquinoline alkaloids, which contribute to its medicinal properties. Notable alkaloids identified include cycleanine, hayatidin, hayatinin, and hayatin. These compounds are associated with various pharmacological activities, including anti-inflammatory, antipyretic, and antimicrobial effects. The chemical profile of Cissampelos pareira also includes flavonoids and fatty acids, which further enhance its therapeutic potential.
Morphological_Features:
The morphological characteristics of pareira includes slender, pubescent, capable of climbing stem; peltate, broadly ovate to orbicular leaves, with a mucronate tip.
Small, greenish-yellow flowers, with male flowers clustered in leaf axils and female flowers on solitary racemes. A globose drupe, approximately 4-6 mm long, with a hairy surface that changes color from scarlet to black upon drying.
Medicinal_Value: Pareira is revered in traditional medicine systems such as Ayurveda and Traditional Chinese Medicine. It is used for a variety of ailments, including fever, diarrhea, urinary diseases, dyspepsia, skin diseases, chronic ulcers. Research indicates its potential in treating conditions like malaria, inflammation, and various infections due to its antioxidant and immunomodulatory properties. The plant's extracts have shown efficacy in preclinical studies for conditions such as gastric ulcers and rheumatism
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cissampelos pareira is predominantly found in Tropical and subtropical regions of India, Southeast Asia, East Africa, Parts of the Americas. It is commonly found in moist, forested areas and is known to thrive in the valleys of regions such as Simla and Dun in India. The plant has also been reported in various countries across Asia, including Thailand and Nepal.

Plant_Name: Ca-A-E / Stevia / Sweet Leaf of Paraguay
Description: Stevia rebaudiana Bertoni is a perennial shrub native to Paraguay, recognized for its leaves that contain sweet compounds known as steviol glycosides, primarily stevioside and rebaudioside A. These compounds are approximately 250-300 times sweeter than sucrose, making Stevia a popular sugar substitute globally
Parts_Used: The primary parts used from Stevia rebaudiana are the leaves, which are harvested for their high content of sweet glycosides. The leaves can be consumed fresh, dried, or processed into extracts for various culinary and medicinal applications
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Stevia rebaudiana thrives in warm, temperate to tropical climates. It prefers well-drained soil with a pH between 6.0 and 7.0 and requires full sunlight for optimal growth. The plant is sensitive to frost and performs best in temperatures ranging from 20°C to 30°C (68°F to 86°F)
Chemical_Properties: The leaves of Stevia contain over 30 different steviol glycosides, with stevioside and rebaudioside A being the most prevalent. These compounds exhibit various biological activities, including anti-diabetic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant effects. Stevioside is a diterpene glycoside composed of glucose molecules linked to a steviol backbone
Morphological_Features: Stevia rebaudiana typically grows to about 60-120 cm in height. The plant has broad green leaves that are serrated and can measure up to 4 cm long. The flowers are small and white, appearing in clusters during the flowering season
Medicinal_Value: Research indicates that Stevia rebaudiana has multiple health benefits, including anti-cancer properties, blood sugar regulation, and potential improvements in kidney function. Its extracts have shown promise in reducing oxidative stress and inflammation. Additionally, stevioside has been studied for its insulinotropic effects, making it beneficial for diabetic patients
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Stevia rebaudiana is cultivated in various regions worldwide, including Japan, Brazil, China, India, and the United States. Its commercial cultivation has expanded due to increasing demand for natural sweeteners as alternatives to sugar and artificial sweeteners

Description: Melaleuca cajuputi, commonly known as cajeput or cajuput, is a tree belonging to the Myrtaceae family, native to Australia and Southeast Asia. This species is notable for its medicinal properties and its adaptability to various environmental conditions. Melaleuca cajuputi is a medium to large tree that typically reaches heights of 10 to 20 meters, although it can grow up to 40 meters under ideal conditions. The trunk can have a diameter of up to 1.2 meters. The bark is distinctive, grey-white, and peels off in papery sheets. The leaves are elongated, leathery, and arranged alternately, measuring up to 10 cm in length. The flowers are small, typically about 10 mm in diameter, and are clustered in dense spikes that can be white, cream, or greenish-yellow in color. The tree produces urn-shaped capsules that contain numerous tiny seeds.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Melaleuca cajuputi used for medicinal purposes are the leaves and the essential oil extracted from them. The essential oil, known as cajeput oil, is derived through steam distillation and contains compounds such as cineole, which is known for its antiseptic properties. The bark and wood are also utilized for various applications, including construction and as firewood.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Melaleuca cajuputi thrives in humid tropical lowland climates, typically in frost-free areas. It prefers annual temperatures ranging from 19 to 35°C and requires annual rainfall between 900 to 4000 mm. The tree is often found in low, swampy coastal plains and can tolerate seasonal flooding. It grows well in heavy clay soils and can withstand brackish and acidic conditions.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil of Melaleuca cajuputi is characterized by its high content of cineole (eucalyptole), which imparts antiseptic and anti-inflammatory properties. This oil is used in various medicinal applications, including treatments for respiratory issues, skin ailments, and as a counterirritant for muscle pain. The oil is also utilized in personal care products, such as toothpaste and lotions, due to its fragrance and therapeutic benefits.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Melaleuca cajuputi exhibits a stout trunk with a heavily branched crown that is pyramidal when young and becomes rounded with age. The leaves are simple and glabrous with a dull green color, featuring longitudinal lines. The flowers are notable for their long white filaments, and the tree produces small, woody seed capsules that are cup-shaped, aiding in seed dispersal.
Medicinal_Value: Cajuputi has a long history of medicinal use. The essential oil is effective for treating coughs, colds, and respiratory infections when inhaled or applied topically. It is also used as an antibacterial and anti-inflammatory agent, making it beneficial for skin conditions. In traditional medicine, it has been utilized for its vermifuge properties and as a treatment for infections of the genitourinary system.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Melaleuca cajuputi is cultivated in various regions, including southern China, Taiwan, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, and Papua New Guinea. Its natural habitat extends from northern Australia to the Philippines and the Moluccas. The tree is often found in coastal areas and is commonly planted for ornamental purposes, as well as for its ecological benefits in providing shade and habitat.

Description: Lagenaria siceraria, also known as the bottle gourd or calabash, is a vigorous, annual, running or climbing vine that belongs to the Cucurbitaceae family. It is characterized by large leaves, a lush appearance, and a thick, furrowed stem. The vine is branched and climbs by means of tendrils along the stem. The foliage is covered with soft hairs and has a foul, musky odor when crushed
Parts_Used: All parts of the Lagenaria siceraria plant, including the ripe fruits, leaves, stem, and flowers, can be used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Lagenaria siceraria can be grown anywhere in frost-free regions during the year. It prefers full sun exposure and can be grown in USDA hardiness zones 2a to 11b.
Chemical_Properties: Lagenaria siceraria contains various phytochemicals, including polysaccharides, proteins, and other bioactive compounds. These compounds have been found to possess a wide range of pharmacological activities, such as antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and anticancer properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant is a vigorous, annual vine with large, lobed leaves and a lush appearance. The flowers are white and attractive, up to 4 inches in diameter, with spreading petals. The fruit can vary greatly in size, shape, and color, ranging from 2 to 12 inches in diameter and 4 to 40 inches in length. The fruit can have a sterile (seedless) neck and the seed-containing portion can be flat, round, cylindrical, club-shaped, or long and narrow.
Medicinal_Value: Lagenaria siceraria has been used in traditional medicine systems to treat a variety of ailments. The plant has been reported to possess immunomodulatory, antioxidant, hepatoprotective, anti-stress, cardioprotective, adaptogenic, anti-inflammatory, antihyperlipidemic, and analgesic activities, among others.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Lagenaria siceraria is widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions, including parts of Africa, Asia, and the Americas. It is believed to have originated in western tropical Africa and spread to other parts of the world in pre-Columbian times.

Plant_Name: Calamus / Flagroot / Myrtle Flag / Sweet Calamus / Sweetflag / Sweetroot
Description: Acorus calamus, commonly known as sweet flag or calamus, is a wetland plant known for its aromatic rhizome.
Parts_Used: The rhizome is primarily used for medicinal purposes and flavoring.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Sweet flag prefers wet soils and can grow in shallow water or marshy conditions. It thrives in temperate climates.
Chemical_Properties: The rhizome contains essential oils rich in beta-asarone which contribute to its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: This plant can reach heights of up to 1 meter with long sword-like leaves that grow from the base.
Medicinal_Value: Acorus calamus has been traditionally used for digestive disorders and as a sedative.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: It is found across North America, Europe, and Asia in wetlands.

Description: Calendula officinalis is an annual herbaceous plant that grows 30-60 cm tall. It has branching stems, oblong-lanceolate leaves, and large yellow or orange flower heads 4-7 cm in diameter with ray and disc florets.
Parts_Used: The dried petals and pollen of the marigold flower are the parts used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Calendula officinalis thrives in sunny locations and can grow in almost any soil type. It is native to Mediterranean countries but is now cultivated as an ornamental plant worldwide.
Chemical_Properties: The petals and pollen of Calendula officinalis contain triterpenoid esters, carotenoids like flavoxanthin and auroxanthin, as well as other compounds like flavonol glycosides, triterpene oligoglycosides, saponins, and essential oils.
Morphological_Features: Marigold is an annual or short-lived perennial plant with hairy, waxy stems and leaves. The large flower heads have yellow or orange ray florets surrounding central disc florets. The fruit is a curved achene.
Medicinal_Value: Calendula has been used traditionally to treat stomach issues, menstrual cramps, and skin conditions. Marigold may have anti-viral, anti-inflammatory, and wound healing properties when applied topically.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Calendula officinalis is native to the Mediterranean region but is now widely cultivated and naturalized in warm temperate regions around the world, including Europe, Western Asia, and North America.

Description: The California poppy (Eschscholzia californica) is a perennial wildflower native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It has feathery, blue-green foliage and showy, cup-shaped flowers that bloom in brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow. The flowers are usually pale yellow, orange, or cream in the wild, but cultivated varieties are available in whites and various shades of red and pink.
Parts_Used: The entire plant, especially the aerial parts and roots, is used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: California poppies thrive in warm, sunny conditions and well-drained, nutrient-poor soils. They are drought-tolerant and can bloom most heavily from March to May, with the bloom period extended by supplemental water.
Chemical_Properties: The California poppy contains alkaloids such as californidine, which contribute to its analgesic, sedative, and anxiolytic effects.
Morphological_Features: California poppies have feathery, highly-dissected, blue-green leaves that clasp the 1-2 ft. stems. The showy, 1-3 in. wide, four-petaled flowers are solitary and long-stalked. Each of the satiny petals has a deep-orange spot at its base.
Medicinal_Value: California poppy has been used traditionally as a medicine for its analgesic and sedative properties. It possess sedative, anxiolytic, and analgesic effects due to the presence of alkaloids.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: California poppies are native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. They have become naturalized in parts of southern Europe, Asia, and Australia.

Description: Cinnamomum camphora is a large, broadleaf evergreen tree that is often used as a shade tree in warm, humid locations. The camphor typically grows 15-30 meters tall, with a diameter of up to 3 meters. It can reach heights of 40-50 feet tall and 50-70 feet wide. Its bark is tough, light brown or greyish-brown, scaly or fissured, with a strong aromatic odor. Alternately arranged leaves, bright green and glossy on the upper surface, paler green and duller on the lower surface. Leaves are oval to broadly egg-shaped, with entire margins that are often wavy. They have three distinct veins spreading from their bases.
Parts_Used: Leaves of camphor used for their camphor scent when bruised. They are also used in traditional African medicine for colds, fever, flu, and stomach pains. Its bark is distilled to extract natural camphor, which has antiseptic, rubefacient, and analgesic properties. The wood of camphor is ussed for timber production and has an insect-repellent quality.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Camphor prefers warm temperatures, typically growing best in areas with a mean annual temperature of 14-27°C. It requires high humidity, similar to its native regions in Japan and China and needs full sun to partial shade, with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. It prefers well-draining, fertile soil, but can adapt to a wide range of soil types, including acidic, neutral, and basic pH levels.
Chemical_Properties: A white crystalline substance (camphor) obtained from the tree. It has been used for centuries as a culinary spice, component of incense, and medicine. It is also an insect repellent and flea-killing substance. The tree contains six different chemical variants (chemotypes) - camphor, linalool, 1,8-cineole, nerolidol, safrole, and borneol. The chemotype composition varies by country of origin.
Morphological_Features: The bark of the camphor is thick, rough, and deeply fissured, with a grid-like pattern. Alternately arranged leaves, with leaf stalks 15-40 mm long. Leaves are 4.5-11 cm long and 2.4-6 cm wide, varying from oval to broadly egg-shaped.
Medicinal_Value: Camphor is used as a medicine for its antiseptic, rubefacient, and analgesic properties and its bark is used in traditional African medicine for colds, fever, flu, and stomach pains.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth:
Camphor native regions are China, India, Japan, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, and Vietnam.
Its inntroduced regions are Cuba, Dominican Republic, and other countries where it has been planted.

Description: Cirsium arvense, commonly known as creeping thistle, is a perennial flowering plant in the Asteraceae family. It is native to Europe and western Asia, and has become widely invasive worldwide. Cirsium arvense is a C3 carbon fixation plant that can grow up to 150 cm tall. It forms extensive clonal colonies from its thickened roots that send up numerous erect shoots during the growing season. The plant is dioecious, meaning it has separate male and female individuals, although some plants may produce bisexual flowers. It has slender, green, freely branched stems that are mostly smooth and without spiny wings. The leaves are alternate, very spiny, lobed, and up to 15-20 cm long and 2-3 cm broad.
Parts_Used: The entire plant, including the roots, stems, leaves, and flowers, can be used. The roots are particularly important as they are responsible for the plant's vegetative growth and spread.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Creeping thistle thrives in areas with moderate sunlight intensity, moderate temperatures, and plentiful ground water. It is shade intolerant and prefers disturbed or agricultural sites over wooded areas. The plant can tolerate a range of soil types but does best in moist, fertile soils.
Chemical_Properties: Cirsium arvense contains various chemical compounds including sesquiterpene lactones, flavonoids, and phenolic acids. These compounds contribute to the plant's defense mechanisms and ability to adapt to different environments.
Morphological_Features: The plant has slender, green, freely branched stems that are mostly smooth and spineless. The leaves are alternate, spiny, lobed, and up to 15-20 cm long. The pink-purple flowers are produced in compound cymes and are typically dioecious. The seeds have a feathery pappus that aids in wind dispersal.
Medicinal_Value: Creeping thistle has been used in traditional medicine to treat various ailments, though its medicinal properties are not well-studied. It has  potential anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antimicrobial effects.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cirsium arvense is native to Europe and western Asia, but has been introduced and become invasive in many other parts of the world, including North America, northern Africa, and Australia.

Plant_Name: Cancer Herb / Copperleaf / Indian Acalypha / Indian Nettle / Three-Seeded-Mercury
Description: Acalypha indica, commonly known as Indian acalypha, Indian mercury, Indian copperleaf, Indian nettle, or three-seeded mercury, is an herbaceous annual plant that grows up to 75 cm tall. It has oval leaves measuring 2-8 cm in length, containing three visible veins. Small male flowers grow on the tips of leaves, while larger triangular female flowers form. The small fruits are covered in trichomes.
Parts_Used: The various parts of the plant, including leaves, roots, seeds, and seed oil, are widely used in traditional medicine to treat a variety of ailments.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Acalypha indica grows well in tropical and subtropical regions. It occurs widely throughout the Old World tropics, including Africa, India, South East Asia, Yemen, and Oceania. It has been introduced to the New World Tropics as well.
Chemical_Properties: The aerial parts of Acalypha indica contain a cyanogenic glycoside called acalyphin (a 3-cyanopyridone derivative), as well as flavonoids such as kaempferol glycosides mauritianin, clitorin, nicotiflorin, and biorobin. Tannins, β-sitosterol, acalyphamide, aurantiamide, succinimide, and flindersin (a pyranoquinolinone alkaloid) have also been isolated. The chemicals that attract cats are the iridoid compounds isodihydronepetalactone and isoiridomyrmecin.
Morphological_Features: Acalypha indica is an annual upright aromatic plant with catkin-like inflorescences and cup-shaped involucres surrounding the minute flowers. It has oval leaves measuring 2-8 cm in length, containing three visible veins. Small male flowers grow on the tips of leaves, while larger triangular female flowers form. The small fruits are covered in trichomes.
Medicinal_Value: Acalypha indica has been used in traditional medicine to treat various ailments. The leaves are used in Malaysia to treat headache, fever, and flu, while the roots are boiled to wash hemorrhoids. In the western parts of Africa, the plant is used in the form of decoction. The juice extracted from the leaves is applied to skin infections. The plant is also used in homeopathy to treat obstinate constipation in children and scabies.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Acalypha indica occurs widely throughout the Old World tropics, including Africa, India, South East Asia, Yemen, and Oceania. It has been introduced to the New World Tropics as well. It is found in the plains of India as a weed in gardens, waste lands, and beside roadsides. It is also grown in the hills of Orissa at an altitude of 210 m.

Plant_Name: Cane Reed / Crepe Ginger / Ketaki / Wild Ginger
Description: Costus speciosus, also known as Crepe Ginger or Insulin Plant, is an erect perennial herb that can grow up to 2.7 meters tall. It has a tuberous rootstock and a sub-woody stem at the base. The leaves are large, measuring 15-30 × 5.7-7.5 cm, dorsally silky, sub-sessile, oblong, and spirally arranged. The plant produces white, shell-shaped flowers that open during the night, clustered in dense spikes with large, shiny brown or red bracts.
Parts_Used: Almost all parts of the Costus speciosus plant are used in traditional medicine to treat various disorders. The rhizomes, leaves, and flowers are the most commonly used parts.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Costus speciosus grows well in subtropical climates with rainfall between 1000-1500 mm. It is generally found in northwest Himalayas and a few localities in Uttar Pradesh, India.
Chemical_Properties: The rhizomes of Costus speciosus contain the steroidal sapogenin diosgenin, which has potential as an alternative source for commercial production of steroidal hormones. The plant also contains various other phytochemicals, including alkaloids, flavonoids, glycosides, phenols, saponins, steroids, and tannins.
Morphological_Features: Costus speciosus is an erect plant with a height of up to 2.7 meters. The root stock is tuberous, and the stem is sub-woody at the base. The leaves are large, measuring 15-30 × 5.7-7.5 cm, dorsally silky, sub-sessile, oblong, and spirally arranged. The plant produces white, shell-shaped flowers that open during the night, clustered in dense spikes with large, shiny brown or red bracts.
Medicinal_Value: Costus speciosus has been found to possess many pharmacological activities, including antibacterial, antifungal, anticholineesterase, antioxidant, antihyperglycemic, anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antipyretic, antidiuretic, larvicidal, antistress, and estrogenic activity. The rhizomes are used to treat various disorders, such as pneumonia, rheumatism, dropsy, urinary diseases, and jaundice. The leaves are used in mental disorders.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Costus speciosus is generally found in northwest Himalayas and a few localities in Uttar Pradesh, India. Its distribution is restricted to these areas, and the plant is on the verge of extinction due to over-harvesting from its natural habitat.

Description: Atractylodes lancea, commonly known as cang zhu, is a perennial herb belonging to the Asteraceae family. It typically grows up to 1 meter tall and features a rhizome that is thick and fleshy.
Parts_Used: The primary parts used are the rhizomes, which are harvested in late summer to early autumn when they are mature.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant thrives in warm, humid climates with well-drained, fertile soil. It prefers partial shade and requires consistent moisture.
Chemical_Properties: Atractylodes lancea contains various bioactive compounds, including essential oils, sesquiterpenes, and flavonoids, which contribute to its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has alternate leaves that are deeply lobed and a flowering head that produces small, white flowers. The rhizome is the most notable feature due to its medicinal value.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used in Chinese medicine, Atractylodes lancea is known for its anti-inflammatory, digestive, and diuretic properties. It is often used to treat gastrointestinal disorders and enhance immune function.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This plant is primarily found in East Asia, particularly in China, where it is cultivated extensively for medicinal use.

Description: Elettaria cardamomum is a pungent, aromatic, herbaceous, perennial plant in the ginger family, growing to about 2–4 m (6 ft 7 in – 13 ft 1 in) in height. It has alternate, linear-lanceolate leaves up to 60 cm (24 in) long with a long pointed tip. The flowers are white to lilac or pale violet, produced in a loose spike 30–60 cm (12–24 in) long. The fruit is a three-sided yellow-green pod 1–2 cm (0.39–0.79 in) long, containing several (15-20) black and brown seeds.
Parts_Used: The dried seeds inside the green seed pods are the most widely used part of the plant. The seeds are used whole or ground in Indian and other Asian cuisines.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Dalchini requires tropical, humid conditions with consistent moisture and temperatures rarely dipping below 72°F. It thrives in the shade of tall trees in tropical rainforests with about 150 inches of rainfall per year. Direct sun must be avoided. Sudden changes in temperature, moisture, or sun exposure will harm the plant.
Chemical_Properties: The primary volatile components of cardamom are terpinyl acetate and eucalyptol.
Morphological_Features: Dalchini has fleshy, knobby rhizomes and cane-like stems. Depending on the variety, the flowering stems grow horizontally, vertically upwards, or in between.
Medicinal_Value: Cardamom has been used in Ayurvedic medicine since at least the 4th century BC. It is believed to reduce inflammation and is used to treat sore throat, skin conditions, and other disorders.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to southern India, E. cardamomum is cultivated widely in tropical regions including Nepal, Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand, Sri Lanka, and Central America. It has reportedly naturalized in Réunion, Indochina, and Costa Rica.

Plant_Name: Carrot / Wild carrot / Queen Anne's lace
Description: Daucus carota, commonly known as wild carrot or Queen Anne's lace, is a flowering, herbaceous plant of biennial origin that can reach a height of 1m (3 feet) and a spread of 30cm (1 foot). It is distinguished by a mix of tripinnate leaves, fine hairs on its solid green stems and leaves, a root that smells like carrots, and occasionally a single dark red flower in the center of the umbel.
Parts_Used: Unlike the edible carrot, the tap root of wild carrot is not consumed. The parts that are above ground and the oil obtained from its seeds have therapeutic benefits and are used for the treatment of various ailments in Ayurveda and modern science.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Daucus carota grows well in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soil. It can tolerate a variety of soil types but thrives in sandy or gravelly soils. The plant is hardy and can withstand cold temperatures, making it suitable for cultivation in temperate climates.
Chemical_Properties: The seed oil of wild carrot is the primary source of medication and mainly contains flavones like chypsin, apigenin, and luteolin. It also contains 5-methoxysoralen and 8-methoxysoralen, which are furanocoumins. The seed oil shows potent diuretic activity and is a renal irritant. The tuber of wild carrot consists of alpha and beta carotenes.
Morphological_Features: Daucus carota belongs to the family Apiaceae and is part of the Daucus genus, which is a polymorphic taxon with multiple species and subspecies. The plant is characterized by aromatic, flowering, and celery/parsley-like features. It is classified into twelve subspecies, with D. carota ssp. sativus (Hoffm.) Arcang. being the most well-known variety.
Medicinal_Value: In Ayurveda, Daucus carota is attributed with various therapeutic properties and is used to treat a wide range of ailments, including urinary tract disorders, digestive issues, jaundice, cough, skin disorders, diabetes, fever.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Daucus carota is widely distributed across Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It has been introduced and naturalized in North America, where it is commonly known as "Queen Anne's lace".

Description: Celery (Apium graveolens) is a biennial plant in the Apiaceae family that is commonly grown as an annual. It has a strong, earthy, slightly peppery taste. The plant can reach a height of about 1 m with rhombic leaves that grow in a rosette on a branched central stem.
Parts_Used: Both the stalks and leaves of the celery plant are commonly used as a vegetable. The seeds are also used to produce celery salt, which is used as a seasoning and in cocktails like the Bloody Mary.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Celery grows best in cool, moist climates with well-draining, fertile soil and a pH between 6.0 and 6.8. The optimal temperature range for growth is between 15–21°C (59–69.8°F). Celery requires constant moisture and can tolerate some shade but not heat.
Chemical_Properties: The seeds contain 2–3% essential oil and 17–18% fatty oil. The essential oil has d-selenene, sedlanolide and sedanoic acid anhydride contributing to its flavor, and 60% of d-limonene.
Morphological_Features: Celery has long, firm, pale green fibrous stalks that taper into a bouquet of leaves at the top. The plant produces creamy white flowers in dense umbels and broad oval seeds 1.5–2 mm (<0.1 in) long and wide.
Medicinal_Value: The seeds have carminative and nerve stimulant properties and are used as a neuro-tonic in domestic medicine.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Celery is grown in temperate regions around the world, including parts of Europe, the United States, and India.

Description: Achyranthes aspera is a species of plant in the family Amaranthaceae. It is distributed throughout the tropical world and is found in many places growing as an introduced species and a common weed. It is an invasive species in some areas, including many Pacific Islands environments
Parts_Used: Almost all parts of Achyranthes aspera, including the seeds, roots, and shoots, have been used for medicinal purposes. The leaves, roots, flowers, and fruits are particularly significant in traditional medicine.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Achyranthes aspera grows well in tropical and subtropical regions. It is commonly found in Asia, Africa, warmer regions of Australia, and parts of America. It can thrive in various climates, including those with high temperatures and moderate humidity.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains a variety of chemical compounds, including fatty acids, phenolic acids, alkaloids, saponins, and triterpenoids. These compounds contribute to its medicinal properties and nutritional value.
Morphological_Features: The Chaff Flower, also known as Latjira, is a wild, perennial, erect herb. Its stem is herbaceous but becomes woody at the base. It is cylindrical, solid, angular, hairy, and longitudinally striated. The stem is green, with violet or pink nodes, and features prominent nodes and internodes. The leaves are simple, exstipulate, and arranged in an opposite decussate pattern. They are petiolate, ovate or elliptic-obovate, yellowish below and green above. The leaves measure 8 to 10 cm in length and 7 to 8 cm in width, with a broad base and a pointed tip resembling an egg. The flowers of the Chaff Flower are yellowish-white and are arranged in axillary or terminal spikes. The plant flowers throughout the year. The fruit is an urticle, which falls off along with the bracteoles and perianths, containing a solitary seed. The fruiting also occurs year-round.
Medicinal_Value: The plant Chaff Flower has a rich history of traditional medicinal use. It has demonstrated potential as an anti-inflammatory and analgesic agent in preclinical studies, offering relief from pain and inflammation. Additionally, Chaff Flower exhibits hepatoprotective properties, helping to protect the liver from damage. It is also used in the treatment of respiratory disorders, showcasing its versatility in addressing various ailments. Furthermore, the plant possesses antifungal properties, effective against certain fungal strains, and is utilized in East Africa for wound healing and treating ringworm.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Chaff Flower or Latjira, is widely distributed across various regions. In Tropical Asia, it is abundant in plantations on hills and plains up to 1400 meters. In Africa, the plant is common in various parts, including South Africa and Eritrea. In Australia, it grows in warmer regions, while in America, it is found in certain parts. In India, Achyranthes aspera predominantly grows as a weed on roadsides and in fallow lands, ranging from plains to altitudes of 1400 meters.

Description: Matricaria chamomilla is an annual herb with thin, spindle-shaped roots. The branched, erect stem grows to a height of 10 to 80 cm. The narrow and long leaves are bi- to tripinnate. The flower heads are pedunculate, heterogamous, separately placed with a diameter of 10 to 30 mm. The golden yellow tubular florets with 5 teeth are 1.5 to 2.5 mm long, always ending in a glandulous tube. The 11 to 27 white plant flowers are 6 to 11 mm long, 3.5 mm wide, and arranged concentrically. The receptacle is 6 to 8 mm wide, flat in the beginning, and conical. The fruit is a yellowish-brown cypsela with 3–5 faint ribs.
Parts_Used: The flower heads are the main parts used medicinally. The essential oil present in the flower heads contains azulene and is used in perfumery, cosmetic creams, hair preparations, skin lotions, and tooth preparations.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Matricaria chamomilla can grow at temperatures ranging from 7 °C to 26 °C and requires an annual rainfall of 400 to 1400 mm per season. The plant can withstand cold weather but grows better in full sun and requires long summer days and high temperatures for optimum essential oil yield.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil of Matricaria chamomilla contains various compounds including azulene, chamazulene, α-bisabolol, and its oxides. The composition of the essential oil can vary depending on factors such as growing conditions and extraction methods.
Morphological_Features: Matricaria chamomilla is a diploid cell (2n = 18), allogamous in nature, and starts blooming from the second week of March. The plant exhibits wide segregation as a commercial crop.
Medicinal_Value: Matricaria chamomilla has been used traditionally for its anti-inflammatory, antispasmodic, and antimicrobial properties. The essential oil and extracts from the plant have been studied for their potential therapeutic applications.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Matricaria chamomilla is native to southern and eastern Europe and northern and western Asia. It has also been introduced and naturalized in many countries, including Britain, Australia, North America, Germany, Hungary, France, Yugoslavia, Russia, Brazil, New Zealand, and North Africa.

Description: Stellaria media, commonly known as chickweed, is an annual flowering plant in the family Caryophyllaceae. It is native to Eurasia and has naturalized throughout the world.
Parts_Used: The entire plant is edible, including the leaves, flowers, stems, and seeds. It can be used raw in salads or lightly cooked.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Stellaria media can grow full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day) or partial shade (direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours). It needs clay, high organic matter, loam (silt), and good drainage soil and soil pH as acidic (<6.0), neutral (6.0-8.0).
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains various chemical compounds, including alkaloids, saponins, fatty acids, cardiac glycosides, terpenoids and tannins
Morphological_Features: Stellaria media has 0.12 m (0 ft. 4 in. - 1 ft. 8 in.) height and 0.12 m (0 ft. 4 in. - 1 ft. 0 in.) weight. The flower is white with star-shaped, with 4-5 petals/rays and colored sepals. Its leaves are green and edible.
Medicinal_Value: Stellaria media has been used in folk medicine to treat itchy skin conditions, pulmonary diseases, mange, iron-deficiency anemia, skin diseases, bronchitis, rheumatic pains, arthritis and period pain.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Stellaria media is widespread in Asia, Europe, North America and other parts of the world.

Description: Cichorium intybus, commonly known as chicory, is a perennial herbaceous plant in the aster family (Asteraceae). It is native to Europe, central Asia, and North Africa, and has become naturalized in many parts of the world. Chicory is a cool-season crop that grows best in fertile, well-drained soils in full sun.
Parts_Used: The leaves, roots, and buds of chicory have all been used for various purposes. The young leaves can be eaten raw in salads or cooked to reduce bitterness, while the roots can be dried and used as a coffee substitute. The plant also has a history of medicinal use.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Chicory is a cool-season crop that tolerates only moderate summer temperatures. It grows best in full sun and prefers fertile, well-drained soils. The plant is hardy and can survive in USDA Hardiness Zones 3-9.
Chemical_Properties: Chicory is primarily composed of inulin, a type of prebiotic fiber that encourages the growth of healthy gut bacteria. The plant also contains various other compounds such as sesquiterpene lactones, coumarins, and polyphenols.
Morphological_Features: Chicory is a perennial herb that can grow up to 4 feet tall. It has lanceolate leaves that can reach 10 inches in length, with variable leaf margins ranging from toothed to deeply lobed. The stems are erect, branched, and somewhat hairy, with milky sap. The plant produces bright blue, pink, or white flowers that are up to 1.5 inches wide, with numerous strap-shaped petals.
Medicinal_Value: Chicory has a long history of medicinal use, though there is limited scientific evidence to support many of its purported health benefits. It has been used to treat conditions such as liver and heart health, constipation, and swelling, but more research is needed.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Chicory is native to Europe, central Asia, and North Africa, and has become naturalized in many parts of the world, including North America, South America, and Australia.

Plant_Name: Chinese chastetree / Huang ping / Five-leaved Chaste Tree / Nirgundi
Description: Vitex negundo, commonly known as the five-leaved chaste tree or Chinese chaste tree, is a large aromatic shrub or small tree that can grow 2 to 8 meters (6.6 to 26.2 feet) in height. It has reddish-brown bark and leaves that are digitate (palm-shaped) with 3-7 lanceolate leaflets, the central one being the largest. The leaf edges are toothed or serrated and the underside is covered in fine hairs. The plant produces numerous small, fragrant flowers that are typically lavender, blue, or white in color and arranged in loose panicles.
Parts_Used: The various parts of the Vitex negundo plant that are used medicinally include the leaves, roots, seeds, and bark. These parts contain numerous bioactive compounds and are used extensively in traditional medicine, particularly in South and Southeast Asia.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Vitex negundo thrives in hot, sunny conditions and prefers well-drained, slightly acidic to alkaline soils. It is hardy in USDA Hardiness Zones 6-9 and can tolerate a range of soil types including clay, sand, and loam. The plant is drought-tolerant once established.
Chemical_Properties: Vitex negundo contains a variety of phytochemicals including flavonoids, terpenoids, lignans, and iridoids. These compounds are responsible for the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Vitex negundo include its quadrangular, densely hairy stems, digitate leaves with serrated edges, and terminal panicles of small, fragrant flowers. The plant can take the form of a large shrub or small tree.
Medicinal_Value: Vitex negundo has a long history of use in traditional medicine systems. The leaves, roots, seeds, and bark are used to treat a wide range of conditions including inflammation, pain, fever, skin disorders, and respiratory problems. The plant exhibits anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antipyretic, and antimicrobial properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Vitex negundo is native to Asia, particularly South and Southeast Asia, and parts of Africa. It is widely cultivated and naturalized in these regions as well as in some parts of the Americas.

Description: Ephedra sinica, commonly known as ma huang, is a perennial evergreen shrub native to China. It grows up to 1 meter tall and has jointed green stems that resemble pine needles. The plant has no true leaves, but instead has small, scale-like structures at the nodes.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of E. sinica, particularly the stems and leaves, are the parts used medicinally. The roots may also be used in some preparations.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: E. sinica grows well in arid and semi-arid regions with low rainfall. It is highly resistant to drought and cold temperatures. The plant prefers sandy or rocky soils and can tolerate a wide range of soil types.
Chemical_Properties: E. sinica contains several alkaloids, including ephedrine and pseudoephedrine, which are the primary active constituents. Other chemical components include flavonoids, tannins, and volatile oils.
Morphological_Features: E. sinica has jointed, green stems that are photosynthetic. The stems are slender and branched, with small, scale-like leaves at the nodes. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers and produces small, winged fruits.
Medicinal_Value: E. sinica has been used in traditional Chinese medicine for over 5,000 years as a stimulant and for the treatment of asthma, allergies, and other respiratory conditions. The ephedrine and pseudoephedrine alkaloids are responsible for the plant's medicinal properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: E. sinica is primarily distributed in northern China, including the provinces of Liaoning, Jilin, and Inner Mongolia. The plant is also found in other parts of Asia, including Mongolia, Korea, and Japan.

Plant_Name: Chinese Ginseng / Ginseng / Korean Ginseng / Oriental Ginseng
Description: Panax ginseng, commonly known as ginseng, is a perennial plant belonging to the Araliaceae family. It has been revered in traditional medicine for its potential health benefits, particularly in East Asia and North America. Ginseng is characterized by its fleshy, tuberous roots and palmate leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30 to 60 cm and has a distinctive flowering structure, producing small greenish-white flowers that develop into red berries. The roots contain various bioactive compounds, primarily ginsenosides, which are believed to contribute to its medicinal properties.
Parts_Used: The primary part of ginseng used for medicinal purposes is the root. Both fresh and dried roots are utilized in herbal preparations. The leaves and berries are also sometimes used, but the root is the most sought after due to its concentrated levels of active compounds.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Ginseng thrives in temperate climates with cool, moist conditions. It prefers shaded environments, typically found in deciduous forests. Optimal growth conditions include well-drained, loamy soil with a pH between 5.5 and 6.5. The plant is sensitive to high temperatures; prolonged exposure to temperatures above 30 °C can inhibit growth and cause leaf burn.
Chemical_Properties: The root of Panax ginseng is rich in ginsenosides, which are steroidal saponins that exhibit various pharmacological effects. Other significant compounds include polysaccharides, peptides, and phenolic compounds, which contribute to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. The specific composition of these compounds can vary based on the plant's growing conditions and processing methods.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Panax ginseng is recognized for its fleshy roots, which can be long and forked. The leaves are compound and palmate, typically with five to seven leaflets. The flowering structure is a compound umbel, and the fruit is a small red berry containing seeds. The plant's growth cycle typically spans several years, with the roots becoming more potent as they mature.
Medicinal_Value: Ginseng is widely used in traditional medicine for its adaptogenic properties, believed to enhance the body's resilience to stress. It is commonly used to improve cognitive function, boost energy levels, enhance sexual function, and support immune health. Research suggests that ginseng may also have potential benefits in managing conditions like diabetes, fatigue, and respiratory infections. However, scientific evidence supporting some of these uses remains limited.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Panax ginseng is primarily found in East Asia, particularly in Korea, China, and Siberia. It is also cultivated in parts of North America, especially in cooler regions. The plant prefers shaded, forested areas and has been successfully grown in various locations that mimic its native habitat, including parts of India and the Himalayas.

Description: Swertia chirayita is a bitter tonic, carminative, laxative, anti-pyretic, febrifuge, anti-periodic, anti-inflammatory, stomachic, and anti-helmintic herb. It is an annual or biennial herb that grows up to 1-2 meters tall. The plant has a slender, erect, and branched stem with opposite, sessile, lanceolate leaves.
Parts_Used: The whole plant, including the roots, stems, leaves, and flowers, is used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Swertia chirayita grows in the temperate Himalayan regions at altitudes between 1,200 and 2,100 meters. It prefers moist, shady slopes with cool, humid conditions.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains various bioactive compounds such as amarogentin (the most bitter compound isolated), swerchirin, swertiamarin, and other phytochemicals. These compounds are responsible for the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Swertia chirayita is an erect, branched annual or biennial herb with a slender stem. The leaves are opposite, sessile, and lanceolate in shape. The flowers are small, four-petaled, and yellow or greenish-white in color.
Medicinal_Value: Swertia chirayita has a long history of use in traditional medicine systems, particularly in India and Nepal, to treat a variety of ailments. It is used as a bitter tonic, carminative, laxative, anti-pyretic, febrifuge, anti-periodic, anti-inflammatory, stomachic, and anti-helmintic.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Swertia chirayita is native to the temperate Himalayan regions, including parts of India, Nepal, Bhutan, and Pakistan, where it grows at high altitudes between 1,200 and 2,100 meters.

Description: Plumbago zeylanica is a perennial herb or subshrub that can grow up to 1-2 meters tall. It has slender, erect, and branched stems. The leaves are simple, alternate, and oblong to lanceolate in shape.
Parts_Used: The roots and the milky juice of the plant are the main parts used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Plumbago zeylanica prefers a warm and humid climate. It can grow in a wide range of soil types but thrives best in well-drained, fertile soils. It requires moderate rainfall and full sun exposure.
Chemical_Properties: The plant is rich in phytochemicals like flavonoids, alkaloids, glycosides, saponins, steroids, tannins, triterpenoids, coumarins, and phenolic compounds. The root contains the bioactive compound plumbagin, which is responsible for many of its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has small, white to pinkish-white flowers arranged in terminal spikes. The fruit is a capsule containing a single seed.
Medicinal_Value: Plumbago zeylanica has a wide range of therapeutic applications. It is used as an anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antibacterial, antifungal, antidiabetic, anticancer, and wound-healing agent. It is also used to treat conditions like ulcers, liver problems, and cardiovascular disorders.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Plumbago zeylanica is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, Africa, and Australia. It is widely cultivated in India, China, and other parts of the world for its medicinal and commercial value.

Description: Allium schoenoprasum, commonly known as chives, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Amaryllidaceae family. It typically grows to a height of 30–50 cm (12–20 inches) and features slender, conical bulbs that cluster at the roots. The plant has hollow, tubular scapes that can reach up to 50 cm in length. Chives produce grass-like leaves that are shorter than the flowering stems, also hollow and round in cross-section. The flowers are pale purple and star-shaped, with six petals, forming dense clusters known as umbels.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Allium schoenoprasum utilized in culinary and medicinal applications are its leaves and flowers. The leaves are commonly used fresh or dried as a seasoning for various dishes, including soups, salads, and eggs. The flowers, which are also edible, can be used in salads or for making vinegars.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Chives thrive in temperate climates and prefer full sun to partial shade. They require well-drained soil rich in organic matter and can tolerate a range of soil types but flourish best in loamy soils. Chives are hardy plants that can survive frost and prefer temperatures between 15°C to 25°C (59°F to 77°F). They require regular watering but should not be overwatered to prevent root rot.
Chemical_Properties: Chives contain a variety of bioactive compounds, including organosulfur compounds such as allicin, which is known for its antimicrobial and antioxidant properties. They also contain vitamins A and C, calcium, iron, and other trace elements that contribute to their health benefits. These compounds play a significant role in the plant's antioxidant and anticarcinogenic properties.
Morphological_Features: Chives exhibit several distinctive morphological characteristics. Their leaves are hollow and tubular, typically shorter than the flowering stems. The plant produces pale purple, star-shaped flowers with six petals, which grow in dense clusters. At the base of the plant, small, elongated bulbs form in clusters. Additionally, chives produce seeds in small, three-valved capsules that mature during the summer.
Medicinal_Value: Chives have been recognized for their medicinal properties, including potential benefits for cancer prevention, digestive health, and bone health. They are used in traditional medicine for their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects. The bioactive compounds found in chives may help reduce the risk of chronic diseases by improving overall health and supporting immune function.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Allium schoenoprasum is native to Eurasia but is widely cultivated across North America and Europe. It is commonly found in gardens, woodland edges, and cultivated beds globally. Chives adapt well to various climates but are particularly prevalent in temperate regions where they can grow year-round.

Description: Cinnamomum verum is an evergreen tropical tree that can grow up to 17 m tall in the wild. It has a stout trunk, 30-60 cm in diameter, with thick grey bark and low-set branches. The leaves are stiff, opposite, and variable in size and shape, typically 5-18 cm long and 3-10 cm wide, with 3-5 conspicuous longitudinal veins at the base. The young leaves are reddish, turning dark green above with paler veins and pale glaucous beneath as they mature. The small, pale yellow flowers have a foetid smell and are borne in lax axillary and terminal panicles. The fruit is a fleshy, black ovoid drupe 1.5-2 cm long.
Parts_Used: The inner bark (quills) and essential oils extracted from the leaves and bark are the primary parts used. The bark is dried and ground into a powder to be used as a spice, while the oils are used for flavoring and in perfumes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cinnamomum verum requires a warm, wet tropical climate with no extreme heat or cold. It prefers an average annual rainfall of over 2,000 mm and an average temperature around 27°C. The tree does not tolerate prolonged dry seasons, waterlogged or marshy conditions, or rocky/stony soils.
Chemical_Properties: Cinnamon bark and leaves contain volatile essential oils, including cinnamaldehyde, eugenol, and linalool, which contribute to its distinctive aroma and flavor. The bark also contains tannins and mucilage.
Morphological_Features: Cinnamomum verum is an evergreen tree with stiff, opposite leaves that have 3-5 conspicuous longitudinal veins at the base. The young leaves are reddish, turning dark green with pale veins as they mature. Small, pale yellow flowers with a foetid smell are borne in lax panicles, and the fruit is a fleshy, black ovoid drupe.
Medicinal_Value: Cinnamon has been used traditionally to treat a wide variety of medical conditions, including digestive issues, inflammation, and infections. The plant have antioxidant, antimicrobial, and anti-diabetic properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cinnamomum verum is native to Sri Lanka and southwest India. It is also cultivated in other tropical regions, including Brazil, Indonesia, Madagascar, and the West Indies.

Description: Syzygium aromaticum is an evergreen tree that grows up to 8-12 meters tall, with large leaves and crimson flowers grouped in terminal clusters. The flower buds initially have a pale hue, gradually turn green, then transition to a bright red when ready for harvest. Cloves are harvested at 1.5-2 cm long and consist of a long calyx that terminates in four spreading sepals, and four unopened petals that form a small central ball.
Parts_Used: The spice of commerce is the unopened flower bud on the terminal shoots of the twigs. The ripe fruits of cloves, called "mother cloves" (anthophylli), are also used. Clove oil is extracted from the plant parts by water distillation.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Syzygium aromaticum is commonly found in woodland and rainforest environments. It grows best in tropical regions at altitudes up to 1,000 m, with mean annual temperatures around 25°C and rainfall of 1,500-2,500 mm. It prefers loamy, humus-rich or deep, loose laterite soils.
Chemical_Properties: Cloves contain 14-20% essential oil, the principal component of which is the aromatic compound eugenol. Eugenol is used in various applications including as a local anesthetic, germicide, and flavor compound.
Morphological_Features: The clove tree has slender, brownish, rough stems with opposite, decussate branching. The leaves are small, simple, and opposite. Flowering begins around 5 years after planting, with each tree potentially yielding up to 34 kg of dried buds annually.
Medicinal_Value: Cloves have traditional medicinal applications for treating stomach upset, parasites, and toothaches. The essential oil and eugenol compound have various therapeutic uses.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cloves are native to the Maluku Islands (Moluccas) of Indonesia, but are now widely cultivated throughout the tropics. Major producers include Indonesia, Madagascar, Tanzania, and Sri Lanka.

Description: Cnidium monnieri is a perennial plant native to China that also grows in other parts of Asia. It has white flowers that bloom in clusters from spring to summer. The fruit, seed, and other plant parts are used medicinally.
Parts_Used: The fruit, seed, and other unspecified plant parts of Cnidium monnieri are used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cnidium prefers a temperate climate and grows well in areas with warm summers and mild winters. It requires well-drained, moist soil and full sun exposure.
Chemical_Properties: Cnidium contains several bioactive compounds, including the coumarins osthole, xanthotoxin, isopimpinellin, bergapten, and imperatorin. Osthole is considered one of the main active constituents.
Morphological_Features: Cnidium is a perennial herb that can grow up to 60 cm tall. It has finely divided, fern-like leaves and small white or yellow flowers that form umbrella-shaped clusters.
Medicinal_Value: In traditional Chinese medicine, Cnidium monnieri has been used to treat a variety of conditions, including sexual dysfunction, skin disorders, infections, and weak bones.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cnidium is native to China and can also be found in other parts of Asia, including Japan and Korea. It has also been reported to grow in the western United States, particularly in Oregon.

Description: Solanum sessiliflorum, commonly known as cocona, is a tropical shrub belonging to the Solanaceae family. This plant is characterized by its sturdy branches and large, serrated leaves, which can grow up to 95 cm in length. The leaves are downy with hard hairs on the upper surface and prominent veins on the underside. Cocona produces edible berries that can be red, orange, or yellow, and it resembles other relatives like naranjilla but lacks the characteristic spines and purple coloring associated with them. The flowers of cocona are similar to those of potatoes, featuring light green petals and typically appear in clusters.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Solanum sessiliflorum that are utilized include its fruit, leaves, and flowers. The fruit is consumed fresh or used in various culinary applications, while the leaves and flowers can also contribute to local diets. The ripe fruit pulp is moderately nutritious and is often incorporated into food products and beverages.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cocona thrives in tropical climates, particularly in regions with warm temperatures and high humidity. It can endure cool weather but is sensitive to frost, which can cause severe damage or death to the plant. Ideal growing conditions include well-drained soils and consistent moisture. While it can be grown indoors as an ornamental plant in temperate climates, it requires protection from dry air and pests like spider mites.
Chemical_Properties: The chemical properties of cocona fruit include a moderate nutritional profile, rich in vitamins and minerals. The pulp contains various phytochemicals that may contribute to its medicinal value, although specific chemical analyses are limited in the literature. The fruit and other parts of the plant may also contain compounds typical of the Solanaceae family, which can have both beneficial and toxic effects depending on the concentration and preparation.
