Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Solanum sessiliflorum is a perennial shrub that can reach heights of 1 to 2 meters. The plant has a much-branched structure that becomes woody with maturity. The flowers, which are approximately 2.5 to 4 cm wide, have five dark green sepals and pale greenish-yellow petals, forming a star shape. The fruit varies in shape from ovoid to spherical and can measure 5 to 10 cm in diameter. The leaves are large, with a scalloped margin and a petiole length of 2 to 5 cm.
Medicinal_Value: Cocona has been traditionally used for its nutritional properties and is considered a valuable genetic resource. While specific medicinal uses are not extensively documented, the fruit's consumption is linked to various health benefits associated with its vitamin content and potential antioxidant properties. The plant's phytochemicals may also contribute to its health-promoting effects, although further research is needed to substantiate these claims.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Solanum sessiliflorum is native to the Andean regions of South America, particularly around the Amazon rainforest and Orinoco river regions. It is cultivated in countries such as Peru, Colombia, and Brazil, where it is used both as a fruit and vegetable. The plant has also been successfully grown in other tropical regions with similar climatic conditions, including some trials in Central America.

Description: Columbine is a bushy, upright perennial that grows 18-36 inches tall. It has delicate, nodding flowers in shades of blue, violet, pink, or white with spreading sepals and short, hooked spurs. The leaves are gray-green, rounded, and divided into lobed leaflets.
Parts_Used: The entire plant, including the flowers, leaves, stems, and roots, is considered toxic and should not be consumed.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Aquilegia vulgaris prefers partial shade to full sun and moist, well-drained soil. It is hardy in USDA Zones 3-8.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains toxic compounds such as ranunculin, which can cause skin irritation and gastrointestinal issues if ingested.
Morphological_Features: It is a clump-forming perennial with a bushy, upright growth habit. The flowers have five spreading sepals and a short, hooked spur at the back.
Medicinal_Value: This plant have many medicinal values including anti-asthmatic, astringent, stimulant, cardio-tonic, febrifuge, jaundice, and dyspepsia.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Aquilegia vulgaris is native to Europe but has naturalized in parts of North America. It grows well in temperate regions with cool summers and cold winters.

Description: Symphytum officinale, commonly known as comfrey, is a perennial flowering plant in the family Boraginaceae. It is native to Europe and has been naturalized throughout North America. Comfrey can grow up to 1.2 meters (4 feet) tall, with large, hairy, broad leaves that feel rough to the touch. The flowers are small, bell-shaped, and typically cream or purplish in color. The plant has a black, turnip-like root.
Parts_Used: The medicinal parts of Comfrey plant are the root and the leaves. The root is large, branching, and black on the outside with a creamy white interior containing slimy mucilage. The leaves are thick, somewhat succulent, and veined.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Comfrey grows well in rich, moist, low meadows or along ponds and river banks, where it may reach a height of 1.2 m. It prefers damp, often shady localities such as meadows and woods, especially near streams and rivers.
Chemical_Properties: Symphytum officinale contains a variety of chemical constituents, including Allantoin (0.75–2.55%), Caffeic acid, Carotene (0.63%), Chlorogenic acid (0.037%), Choline, Lithospermic acid, Rosmarinic acid, Silicic acid. The plant also contains vitamins A and B12, as well as high levels of calcium, potassium, and phosphorus.
Morphological_Features: Comfrey has a large, branching, black root with a creamy white interior. The hollow, erect stems are covered in bristly hairs. The thick, somewhat succulent, veined leaves are dark green on top and light green underneath, with the lower leaves being ovate-lanceolate and the upper ones lanceolate and broad. The small, bell-shaped flowers are mauve to violet and form in dense, hanging clusters.
Medicinal_Value: Symphytum officinale has been used in traditional medicine for the treatment of various disorders, particularly those related to bone injuries, fractures, and slow-healing wounds. It is commonly used for conditions associated with bone injuries, fractures, and slow-healing wounds, as well as ailments related to eye injuries or conditions, dental issues, and bruises. Symphytum can be beneficial for symptoms characterized by sharp, shooting pains, soreness, and a slow or delayed healing process.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Symphytum officinale is native to Europe and has been naturalized throughout North America. It is very common in all of Europe, especially in damp soils. The plant has also been introduced and grown in other regions, such as Asia.

Description: Crataegus monogyna, commonly known as the common hawthorn or single-seeded hawthorn, is a shrub or small tree characterized by thorny branches.
Parts_Used: The flowers, leaves, and berries (haws) are used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: It prefers temperate climates with well-drained soil; it can tolerate poor soil conditions but requires full sun.
Chemical_Properties: Rich in flavonoids and proanthocyanidins which contribute to its cardiovascular benefits
Morphological_Features: The plant features lobed leaves with white flowers that bloom in spring followed by red berries in autumn.
Medicinal_Value: Commonly used for heart-related conditions such as angina and hypertension due to its vasodilatory effects
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Europe but widely naturalized across North America and Asia.

Description: Asclepias syriaca, commonly known as common milkweed, is a clonal perennial forb that can grow up to 1.8 m (5 ft 11 in) tall. It is native to southern Canada and much of the eastern United States. The plant grows from rhizomes and all parts produce a white latex when cut. The simple leaves are opposite, sometimes whorled, and broadly ovate-lanceolate in shape, growing 10-28 cm (4-11 in) long and 4-12 cm (1.5-4.75 in) wide with reddish main veins. The highly fragrant, nectariferous flowers occur in umbellate cymes and vary in color from white to pinkish and purplish. The seeds have long, white flossy hairs and occur in large follicles.
Parts_Used: The young shoots, stems, flower buds, immature fruits, and roots of common milkweed have been used as a vegetable by various indigenous groups in eastern and midwestern North America. The bark and fibers have been used to make cords, ropes, and coarse cloth. The sap has been used to remove warts, treat ringworm, and for bee stings.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Common milkweed grows best in full sun and prefers moist but well-drained soils, though it is tolerant of dry conditions and clay soils. It is winter hardy in USDA Hardiness Zones 3-9.
Chemical_Properties: All parts of the common milkweed plant contain resinoids, glycosides, and a small amount of alkaloids, which can be toxic if ingested in large quantities.
Morphological_Features: Common milkweed has a clonal growth habit, spreading aggressively from rhizomes. The flowers have five horn-like hoods and five pollinia. The seeds have long, white flossy hairs that aid in wind dispersal.
Medicinal_Value: The Cherokee used common milkweed root for a variety of medicinal purposes, including as a laxative, antidote for gravel and dropsy, and an infusion for mastitis and venereal diseases. The Chippewa used a cold decoction of the root to increase postpartum milk flow.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Common milkweed is native to southern Canada and much of the eastern United States, ranging from North Carolina to Maine and west to the Rocky Mountains.

Description: Satureja vulgaris, commonly known as summer savory, is an aromatic herb belonging to the Lamiaceae family. It features slender stems with small green leaves and produces white or pale pink flowers during summer.
Parts_Used: The leaves and flowering tops are primarily used for culinary purposes as a spice or seasoning.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Summer savory prefers well-drained soil with full sun exposure. It thrives best in warm conditions typical of USDA zones 5-9.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains essential oils rich in carvacrol and thymol, which contribute to its flavor profile and potential health benefits such as antimicrobial properties
Morphological_Features: Summer savory grows upright with a bushy appearance. Its small leaves are lanceolate and aromatic when crushed; flowers form dense clusters at the tips of stems.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for digestive issues and respiratory ailments due to its carminative properties; it may also have antimicrobial effects due to its essential oil content
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to southern Europe but cultivated globally; it adapts well to various temperate climates.

Description: Thymus vulgaris is a perennial herb belonging to the mint family (Lamiaceae). It features small, gray-green leaves and produces tiny purple flowers.
Parts_Used: The main parts used are the leaves, both fresh and dried, which are widely used in cooking and herbal medicine.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Thyme prefers well-drained soil and full sun exposure. It thrives in Mediterranean climates but can adapt to various conditions as long as there is good drainage.
Chemical_Properties: Thyme contains essential oils rich in compounds like thymol and carvacrol, which have antimicrobial properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has a low-growing habit with woody stems. Leaves are small (1-2 cm), oval-shaped, and aromatic.
Medicinal_Value: Thyme has been traditionally used for its antimicrobial, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties. It is also known for aiding respiratory conditions.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to southern Europe, thyme is cultivated globally, especially in regions with similar climates like the Mediterranean basin

Plant_Name: Common Yew / European Yew / English Yew
Description: Taxus baccata, commonly known as the common yew, is an evergreen tree belonging to the Taxaceae family. This species is native to a wide range of areas, including Western, Central, and Southern Europe, as well as parts of Northwest Africa, northern Iran, and Southwest Asia. It is recognized for its ornamental value and is often used in landscaping and topiary due to its dense foliage and ability to withstand severe pruning.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of yew that are utilized include the leaves, bark, and seeds. However, it is crucial to note that most parts of the plant are toxic, containing alkaloids that can be harmful if ingested. The fleshy aril surrounding the seeds is edible, but the seed itself is not.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Common yew thrives in a variety of soil types, including shallow chalk soils, and is tolerant of shade. It prefers well-drained soils and cannot withstand waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. The tree is also resilient to urban pollution and can endure both cold and heat, making it adaptable to different climates. However, it grows slowly, taking about 20 years to reach a height of approximately 4.5 meters (15 feet).
Chemical_Properties: The chemical composition of Taxus baccata includes various alkaloids, with taxine being the most notable. Taxine is responsible for the plant's toxicity and can lead to severe health issues if ingested. The plant's medicinal properties have been studied, particularly for its potential use in cancer treatment, as it contains compounds that can inhibit cell division.
Morphological_Features: Comon yew typically grows to a height of 10 to 30 meters (about 35 to 100 feet) and features spreading branches with slightly drooping branchlets. The bark is reddish-brown and flaky, becoming deeply fissured in older specimens. The leaves are flat, dark green, and arranged spirally, contributing to the tree's dense appearance. The species produces cones, which are relatively small and mature into fleshy arils.
Medicinal_Value: The medicinal value of Taxus baccata primarily lies in its alkaloids, particularly taxol, which has been extensively researched for its anticancer properties. Traditional uses include treating various ailments, although caution is advised due to the plant's toxicity. In some cultures, extracts from the tree have been utilized in traditional medicine, but modern applications focus more on isolated compounds for therapeutic use.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Common yew is found throughout Europe, extending north to Norway and south to Morocco and Algeria. It is also present in parts of Asia, including northern Iran. The species has been successfully cultivated in various regions around the world, particularly in temperate climates where it is valued for its ornamental qualities.

Plant_Name: Conessi / Kurchi / Nagalkudo / Tellicherry bark / Zhi Xie Mu
Description: Holarrhena pubescens is a small deciduous tree or shrub that grows up to 8 m tall. It has a rough, pale brown bark that exfoliates in small flakes and contains milky white latex. The leaves are simple, opposite, broadly ovate to ovate-lanceolate in shape with an acute or acuminate apex, obtuse base, and entire margin. The creamy-white, slightly fragrant flowers appear in terminal and axillary corymbose cymes along with the new leaves. The calyx has 5 oblong-lanceolate, ciliate lobes that are glandular within at the base. The salver-shaped corolla has 5 oblong, obtuse lobes as long as the tube, which are puberulous with a ring of hairs at the mouth. There are 5 included stamens. The apocarpous carpels each contain many ovules, a 2 mm long style, and a fusiform, bifid stigma. The fruit consists of 2 terete elongated follicular mericarps.
Parts_Used: The bark, seeds, and leaves of the plant are used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Conessi grows in moist deciduous and dry deciduous forests, as well as in plains. It is found in the Indo-Malesian region.
Chemical_Properties: Chemical analysis of kurchi extracts has revealed the presence of several bioactive compounds, such as conessine, isoconnessine, conessimine, conimine, conessidine, conkurchicine, holarrhimine, conarrhimine, mokluangin A-D and antidysentericine.
Morphological_Features: Holarrhena pubescens is characterized by its erect growth habit, typically reaching heights of 1 to 2 meters. The leaves are lanceolate, glossy, and dark green, arranged oppositely on the stem. The plant produces white to pale yellow flowers, which are tubular in shape and grow in clusters. The fruit is a slender, elongated pod containing seeds that are dispersed by wind or animals.
Medicinal_Value: In Ayurveda, the bark of H. pubescens is useful in the treatment of piles, skin diseases, biliousness, and urinary troubles. The fresh juice of the bark is considered good for treating diarrhea. The bark is used externally for skin troubles, often mixed with cow urine and applied to the affected parts. In the treatment of urinary troubles, the bark is given with cow milk. The seeds have antidiabetic properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: H. pubescens is native to the Indian subcontinent, Indo-China, and Africa. It is also found in the Himalayas up to an altitude of 1500 m.

Plant_Name: Coral Beadplant / Crab's Eye / Indian Licorice / Jequerity / Jequirity Bean / Licorice Vine / Love Bean / Lucky Bean / Minnie-Minnies / Prayer Beads / Precatory Bean / Red Beadvine / Rosary Pea / Weatherplant / Weathervine
Description: Abrus precatorius, commonly known as jequirity bean, rosary pea, or crab's eye, is a perennial climbing plant belonging to the Fabaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, twining growth habit, long pinnate leaves, and striking seeds, which are often used in jewelry and traditional practices. However, the seeds are highly toxic due to the presence of abrin, a potent toxin that can be fatal if ingested. Abrus precatorius is a herbaceous perennial vine that can climb over trees and shrubs, reaching heights of up to 5 meters. The plant features compound leaves with 5 to 15 pairs of small leaflets, and its flowers are small, typically white to violet-pink, clustered in the leaf axils. The fruit is a legume pod that contains glossy seeds, which are bright red with a black eye, giving rise to its common names. The seeds are highly uniform in shape and have been historically used as a measure of weight in various cultures.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Abrus precatorius used in traditional medicine include the seeds, leaves, and roots. The seeds are noted for their toxicity and are used in various cultural practices. The leaves are sometimes applied topically for their anti-suppurative properties, while the roots have been used in traditional remedies for various ailments, including skin issues and as a contraceptive in some cultures.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Abrus precatorius thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring warm temperatures and high humidity. It is adaptable to a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained, fertile soils. The plant requires full sun exposure for optimal growth and can often be found in disturbed areas, where it has a tendency to become invasive.
Chemical_Properties: The most notable chemical property of Abrus precatorius is the presence of abrin, a highly toxic protein similar to ricin. Abrin is a dimeric protein composed of two subunits that inhibit protein synthesis in cells, leading to severe toxicity. Other compounds found in the plant include glycyrrhizin and various enzymes, which contribute to its medicinal uses.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Abrus precatorius has pinnately compound leaves, with 5 to 15 pairs of oval to oblong leaflets. Its flowers are mall, clustered, and typically pink or white. Pea-shaped fruit pods that curl back to reveal 3 to 8 hard-coated seeds, which are bright red with a black eye.
Medicinal_Value: While Abrus precatorius is primarily known for its toxicity, it has been used in traditional medicine for various purposes. The leaves are sometimes used in poultices for skin conditions, and the seeds have been employed in certain cultures for their contraceptive properties. However, due to the high toxicity of the seeds, their use is fraught with risk, and they should be handled with caution.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Abrus precatorius is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia and Australia. It has been introduced to various parts of the world, including Africa and the Americas, where it can become invasive. The plant is commonly found in disturbed habitats, roadsides, and open fields in regions with suitable climatic conditions.

Description: Coriander is an erect, soft, hairless annual plant that can grow up to 50 cm tall. It has variable-shaped leaves, with broadly lobed leaves at the base and slender, feathery leaves higher on the flowering stems. The small white or pale pink flowers are produced in umbrella-shaped clusters. The plant produces oval-shaped, yellow-brown fruits that contain two seeds.
Parts_Used: All parts of the coriander plant are edible, but the fresh leaves and dried seeds are most commonly used. The leaves are used as an herb, while the seeds are used as a spice.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Coriander grows best in areas with cool, damp springs and hot, dry summers, at temperatures between 17-27°C. It can tolerate light frost but will bolt (go to seed) in hot weather. The plant prefers well-draining soil and full sun.
Chemical_Properties: Coriander contains 0.1-0.5% essential oils in the var. vulgare, and 0.4-1.8% in the var. microcarpum. The main component is the compound coriandrol.
Morphological_Features: Coriander is an erect, soft, hairless annual plant that can grow up to 50 cm tall. It has variable-shaped leaves, with broadly lobed leaves at the base and slender, feathery leaves higher on the flowering stems. The small white or pale pink flowers are produced in umbrella-shaped clusters. The plant produces oval-shaped, yellow-brown fruits that contain two seeds.
Medicinal_Value: Coriander has been used medicinally for thousands of years, with its seeds used to make teas as a digestive aid and for their reputed sedative effects. The essential oil has also been used in ointments for rheumatic joints and muscles, and is believed to have cholesterol-lowering properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Coriander is native to southern Europe and Asia, but has spread to many other parts of the world, including North Africa, the Americas, and Australia. It has been cultivated for thousands of years in India, China, and the Middle East.

Description: Zea mays, commonly known as maize or corn, is an erect, robust, usually unbranched annual plant that can grow up to 6 metres tall but is more likely to be around 2 metres in height. It is a tall stout grass that produces cereal grain. Maize is a versatile crop that can grow in different varieties of soil, water, and climatic conditions.
Parts_Used: The entire maize plant is utilized, including the grain, leaves, stalks, and cobs. The grain is the primary product, used for food, animal feed, and industrial purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Maize is a warm-weather crop that grows well in regions with sufficient rainfall, typically ranging from 1200mm to 2500mm. It can adapt to regions receiving as little as 400 mm of rainfall. The crop requires warm temperatures between 15°C and 30°C and thrives in zones with altitudes ranging from 100 m to 2900 m ASL, depending on the variety. Maize is sensitive to moisture stress around tasseling time and during cob formation.
Chemical_Properties: Maize contains starch, which can be used to produce plastics, fabrics, adhesives, and many other chemical products. The corn steep liquor, a byproduct of the maize wet milling process, is used in the biochemical industry and research as a culture medium to grow microorganisms.
Morphological_Features: Maize is an erect, robust, usually unbranched annual plant with a shallow root system. It includes male and female flowers and produces cereal grain.
Medicinal_Value: The long, shiny fibers at the top of an ear of corn contain proteins, carbohydrates, vitamins, minerals, and fiber. They may also have antioxidant effects, reduce blood pressure, and alter blood sugar levels. Corn silk is used in Unani medicine for a variety of therapeutic properties, including anti-inflammatory, diuretic, astringent, antibacterial, and anti-diabetic. It's also used for urinary retention, kidney or urinary stones, chest pain, obesity, and other conditions, but there's not much scientific evidence to support these uses. Decoctions of maize silk, roots, leaves, and cob are used for bladder problems, nausea, vomiting, and stomach complaints. Zein, an alcohol-soluble prolamine found in maize endosperm, has potential applications in pharmaceuticals and nutraceuticals. Resistant starch (RS) from maize may reduce the risk of cecal cancer, atherosclerosis, and obesity-related complications.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Maize is grown worldwide, from 58° N latitude in Canada and Russia to 40° S latitude in South America. It is often regarded as a staple food and the most significant crop in the United States. In India, maize cultivation ranges from the humid hills of Assam and Bengal to the hot, desert Plains of Rajasthan and Gujarat. Maize is a staple food for almost half the population of sub-Saharan Africa.

Description: Cornus mas, commonly known as the cornelian cherry, is a deciduous shrub or small tree that can grow up to 25 feet tall and 20 feet wide. It has a rounded, bushy habit and produces small, bright yellow flowers in clusters on its bare branches in late winter to early spring, before the leaves emerge. The leaves are medium green and turn purple in the fall before dropping. The plant produces olive-shaped, red drupes (fruits) that ripen in mid-summer and are edible, though tart. The bark is scaly and exfoliating on mature trees.
Parts_Used: The edible fruits (drupes) of Cornus mas are the primary parts used, though the leaves, bark, and wood may also have uses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cornus mas prefers full sun to partial shade and moist, well-drained, rich soils. It is hardy in USDA Hardiness Zones 5-8.
Chemical_Properties: Cornus mas fruits are rich in vitamins, minerals, and bioactive compounds such as phenolics, flavonoids, iridoids, and carotenoids. The fruits contain high levels of ascorbic acid, citric acid, malic acid, and sugars.
Morphological_Features: Cornus mas is a deciduous shrub or small tree with a rounded, bushy habit. It has oval, medium green leaves that turn purple in the fall. The small, bright yellow flowers appear in clusters on bare branches in late winter to early spring. The plant produces olive-shaped, red drupes (fruits) that ripen in mid-summer.
Medicinal_Value: Cornus mas fruits and extracts have been studied for their potential health benefits, including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anti-diabetic, and lipid-modifying effects. The fruits and other plant parts may have traditional uses in folk medicine.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cornus mas is native to central and southern Europe, as well as western Asia. It is naturalized or cultivated in parts of North America, including Illinois, New York, and Pennsylvania.

Description: Centaurea cyanus, commonly known as the cornflower or bachelor's button, is an annual flowering plant native to Europe. It is a member of the Asteraceae family and grows to a height of 30-90 cm.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts, including the flowers, are used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cornflowers prefer well-drained soil and full sun exposure. They can tolerate a wide range of soil types but thrive in nutrient-rich, slightly alkaline soil. The ideal temperature range for growth is 15-25°C.
Chemical_Properties: Cornflowers contain various phytochemicals, including sesquiterpene lactones, flavonoids, and polyacetylenes. These compounds are believed to contribute to the plant's anti-inflammatory and wound healing properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has a slender, branching stem with linear, gray-green leaves. The flowers are solitary, terminal, and have a distinctive shape with a central disc surrounded by ray florets. The flowers can be blue, purple, pink, or white in color.
Medicinal_Value: In traditional medicine, cornflowers have been used to treat various conditions, such as eye inflammation, wound healing, and bleeding disorders. The decoction of the aerial parts has been used in Hungarian folk medicine for healing wounds in livestock.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cornflowers are native to Europe but have been introduced and naturalized in many parts of the world, including North America, Australia, and Asia. They are commonly found in disturbed areas, such as roadsides, fields, and waste places.

Description: Corydalis yanhusuo, also known as Corydalis tuber or Yanhusuo, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to China. It belongs to the Papaveraceae family and is closely related to the common poppy plant. The plant grows to a height of 20-50 cm and has finely divided, fern-like leaves.
Parts_Used: The primary medicinal part of the Corydalis yanhusuo plant is the underground tuber. The tubers are harvested in the autumn and dried for medicinal use.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Corydalis yanhusuo prefers cool, moist environments and grows well in partial shade. It thrives in well-drained, humus-rich soil. The plant is hardy and can tolerate temperatures down to around -10°C (14°F).
Chemical_Properties: The main active compounds in Corydalis yanhusuo are a group of alkaloids, including tetrahydropalmatine, dehydrocorydaline, and corydaline. These alkaloids are responsible for the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has a tuberous root system and produces finely divided, fern-like leaves. The flowers are small, yellow, and tubular in shape, arranged in clusters at the top of the plant.
Medicinal_Value: Corydalis yanhusuo has been used in traditional Chinese medicine for centuries to treat a variety of conditions, including pain, inflammation, insomnia, and depression. The alkaloids in the plant are believed to have analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and sedative effects.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Corydalis yanhusuo is native to China and is primarily cultivated in the central and eastern regions of the country. The plant can also be found growing wild in parts of Japan and Korea.

Description: Cosmos bipinnatus, commonly known as the garden cosmos or Mexican aster, is an annual flowering plant native to Mexico and Central America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family and is known for its showy, daisy-like flowers that come in a variety of colors including white, pink, purple, and red.
Parts_Used: The entire plant of cosmos is used for medicinal purposes, including the flowers, leaves, stems, and roots.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cosmos thrives in warm, sunny conditions and well-drained soil. It prefers full sun exposure and can tolerate a wide range of soil types, from sandy to clay. The plant is drought-tolerant and does not require high humidity levels.
Chemical_Properties: Cosmos bipinnatus contains various phytochemicals, including flavonoids, terpenes, and polyphenols. These compounds contribute to the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Cosmos is an herbaceous annual that can grow up to 1.2 meters (4 feet) tall. The plant has finely divided, feathery leaves and produces solitary, daisy-like flower heads that can reach 5-10 cm (2-4 inches) in diameter.
Medicinal_Value: Cosmos bipinnatus has been used in traditional medicine to treat a variety of ailments, including inflammation, pain, and digestive issues. The plant have anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antimicrobial properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cosmos bipinnatus is native to Mexico and Central America, but it is widely cultivated as an ornamental plant in many parts of the world, including North America, Europe, and Asia.

Description: Saussurea costus, also known as costus or kuth, is a perennial herb native to the Himalayas. It has a thick, fleshy root and large, hairy leaves. The plant produces purple or white flower heads in the summer.
Parts_Used: The primary part of Saussurea costus used for medicinal and commercial purposes is the root. The roots are harvested from the plant and dried for further processing.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Costus thrives in cool, moist climates at high elevations. It requires well-drained, acidic soil and grows best in areas that receive significant rainfall. The plant can tolerate some shade but prefers full sun exposure.
Chemical_Properties: The roots of Saussurea costus contain a variety of bioactive compounds, including sesquiterpene lactones, polysaccharides, essential oils, terpenoids, phenols, flavonoids, and acids. These compounds are responsible for the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Costus is a perennial herb that can grow up to 1.5 meters tall. It has large, hairy leaves and produces purple or white flower heads in the summer. The thick, fleshy roots can grow up to 30 cm long and 5 cm wide.
Medicinal_Value: Saussurea costus has been used in traditional medicine for centuries to treat a variety of ailments, including inflammation, respiratory issues, and digestive problems. The plant's bioactive compounds have been shown to have anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antioxidant properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Costus is cultivated in many parts of the world, including Asia, Europe, and North America. It is commonly found in temperate regions with suitable climate conditions.

Description: Mucuna pruriens is an annual climbing shrub with long vines that can reach over 15 metres (50 feet) in length. When young, it is almost completely covered with fuzzy hairs, but when older, it is almost free of hairs. The leaves are tripinnate, ovate, reverse ovate, rhombus-shaped or widely ovate with pointy tips. The flower heads take the form of axially arrayed panicles, 15–32 cm (6–13 in) long, with white, lavender, or purple flowers. The fruit is a 4–13 cm (2–5 in) long, 1–2 cm (3⁄8–3⁄4 in) wide, unwinged, leguminous pod covered in loose, orange hairs that cause severe itching. The shiny black or brown seeds are flattened uniform ellipsoids, 1–1.9 cm (3⁄8–3⁄4 in) long, .8–1.3 cm (3⁄8–1⁄2 in) wide and 4–6.5 cm (2–3 in) thick.
Parts_Used: The leaves, seeds, flower, and roots of Mucuna pruriens are used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Mucuna pruriens is a tropical legume that prefers warm, humid conditions. It is native to Africa and tropical Asia and is widely naturalized and cultivated in these regions.
Chemical_Properties: The seeds of Mucuna pruriens contain high levels of L-DOPA (levodopa), a precursor to the neurotransmitter dopamine. This compound is responsible for the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant is notorious for the extreme itchiness it produces on contact, particularly with the young foliage and seed pods. It also produces many medium-sized red swollen bumps along with the itching.
Medicinal_Value: Mucuna pruriens has been used for centuries in Ayurvedic medicine for the treatment of Parkinson's disease and various other symptoms and conditions. The seeds are the most commonly used part for medicinal purposes.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Mucuna pruriens is native to Africa and tropical Asia and is widely naturalized and cultivated in these regions. It can also be grown in other tropical and subtropical areas with suitable climate conditions.

Plant_Name: Cowgrass / Peavine Clover / Purple Clover / Red Clover
Description: Trifolium pratense, commonly known as red clover, is a herbaceous perennial plant belonging to the Fabaceae family. Red clover is characterized by its variable height, typically growing between 20 to 80 cm (8 to 31 inches). It features a deep taproot that enhances its drought tolerance and contributes positively to soil structure. The leaves are arranged alternately and are trifoliate, with each leaflet measuring 15 to 30 mm long and 8 to 15 mm wide. The leaflets are green with a distinctive pale crescent pattern. The flowers are dark pink, approximately 12 to 15 mm long, and are clustered in dense inflorescences, primarily attracting bumblebees for pollination.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Trifolium pratense utilized in various applications include the leaves and flowers. The leaves are often used in herbal remedies, while the flowers are harvested for their medicinal properties. The entire plant is also used as fodder for livestock, valued for its nutritional content and ability to fix nitrogen in the soil, thus improving soil fertility.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Red clover thrives in temperate climates and prefers well-drained soils. It is moderately tolerant of soil acidity and can withstand poor drainage conditions. The plant requires full sun to partial shade and typically blooms from spring to early fall. Ideal growing conditions include temperatures between 15°C to 25°C (59°F to 77°F) and adequate moisture without waterlogging.
Chemical_Properties: Trifolium pratense contains various bioactive compounds, including isoflavones such as genistein and daidzein, which are known for their estrogen-like properties. These compounds contribute to its medicinal value, particularly in treating menopausal symptoms. The plant also contains flavonoids, saponins, and phenolic acids, which possess antioxidant properties.
Morphological_Features: The morphological characteristics of red clover include its trifoliate leaves, which are often mottled, and its dense flower heads. The flowers can vary in color from red to purple and occasionally white. The plant's growth habit is erect, and it may lodge under heavy rainfall or when over-fertilized. The seeds are small, smooth, and round, typically dispersed by wind or water.
Medicinal_Value: Red clover is widely recognized in herbal medicine for its potential health benefits. It is often used to alleviate symptoms associated with menopause, such as hot flashes and mood swings, due to its isoflavone content. Additionally, it has been studied for its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, making it beneficial for cardiovascular health and skin conditions. The plant is also used in traditional medicine for respiratory issues and as a blood purifier.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Trifolium pratense is native to Europe, Western Asia, and northwest Africa but has been introduced and naturalized in many regions worldwide, including North America, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico. It is commonly found in meadows, pastures, and disturbed areas, thriving in various habitats across temperate climates.

Description: Vaccinium oxycoccus, commonly known as the cranberry, is a small, trailing evergreen shrub that is native to acidic bogs and wetlands in the Northern Hemisphere. It has small, dark green, oval-shaped leaves and produces small, red, edible berries.
Parts_Used: The primary part of the cranberry plant used for medicinal and culinary purposes is the fruit or berry. The leaves and stems may also have some minor uses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cranberries thrive in cool, acidic, and moist environments. They require full sun exposure and well-drained, sandy or peaty soil with a pH between 4.0 and 5.5. Cranberries are hardy and can tolerate cold temperatures, with some varieties able to survive winters down to -40°C.
Chemical_Properties: Cranberries are rich in various phytochemicals, including phenolic acids, flavonoids, and triterpenoids. They are particularly high in antioxidants, such as proanthocyanidins, which give them their characteristic tart and astringent flavor. Cranberries also contain vitamins C, E, and K, as well as minerals like manganese.
Morphological_Features: Vaccinium oxycoccus is a low-growing, trailing vine that can spread up to 2 meters wide. The leaves are small, oval-shaped, and evergreen. The flowers are pink or white and bell-shaped, and the berries are small (8-14 mm in diameter), round, and bright red when ripe.
Medicinal_Value: Cranberries have been used for centuries in traditional medicine to treat a variety of conditions. They are most well-known for their ability to prevent and treat urinary tract infections (UTIs) due to their high content of proanthocyanidins, which can inhibit the adhesion of bacteria to the urinary tract. Cranberries may also have anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antimicrobial properties that could be beneficial for other health conditions.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cranberries are native to North America, Europe, and Asia, and are commercially cultivated in the United States, Canada, Chile, and several European countries. They grow naturally in acidic, boggy areas of the Northern Hemisphere, including in the northeastern United States, eastern Canada, northern Europe, and Scandinavia.

Description: Andrographis paniculata, commonly known as the "King of Bitters," is a prominent medicinal herb belonging to the Acanthaceae family. This annual herbaceous plant is characterized by its erect growth, reaching heights of 30 to 110 cm. It features a slender, dark green stem with a square cross-section and longitudinal furrows. The lance-shaped leaves can grow up to 8 cm long and 2.5 cm wide, while the small flowers are typically pink, forming in loose racemes. The plant produces capsules that are about 2 cm long, containing numerous yellow-brown seeds.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Andrographis paniculata utilized in traditional medicine include the dried leaves and tender shoots. These parts are rich in bioactive compounds that contribute to the plant's medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Andrographis paniculata thrives in moist, shady environments, preferring well-drained soils. It can be found in a variety of habitats, including hedgerows, hill slopes, and waste grounds. The plant is adaptable but grows best in tropical and subtropical climates, where temperatures remain warm and rainfall is adequate.
Chemical_Properties: The major active compound in Andrographis paniculata is andrographolide, a bicyclic diterpenoid lactone. The plant also contains various other phytochemicals, including flavonoids and labdane diterpenoid lactones, which contribute to its wide spectrum of pharmacological activities. These include anti-inflammatory, anti-microbial, anti-diabetic, and immunostimulant effects.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Andrographis paniculata exhibits a branched, erect structure with dark green, hairless leaves. The flowers are small and pink, and the fruit is a capsule containing several seeds. The flowering period typically occurs from September to December, and the plant can be cultivated in gardens as well as in its natural habitats.
Medicinal_Value: Andrographis paniculata is renowned for its medicinal applications, particularly in traditional systems such as Ayurveda and Siddha. It is used to treat a variety of ailments, including fever, respiratory infections, liver disorders, and digestive issues. Its effectiveness against bacterial infections and as an anti-inflammatory agent has been documented in numerous studies, although some claims regarding cancer treatment lack substantial evidence.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This plant is native to India and Sri Lanka but is widely cultivated across Southeast Asia, including countries like Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia. It has also been introduced to regions in the Americas and the West Indies, where it adapts well to tropical climates. Its cultivation is prevalent in India, China, and parts of Africa, making it a globally recognized medicinal plant.

Description: Garden cress is an herbaceous annual plant in the Brassicaceae family. It grows up to 60 cm (23.6 in) tall and has many branches with narrow, oval-shaped leaves. The plant produces small pink to white flowers that form a clustered inflorescence. Garden cress is also known as pepper cress or Persian broadleaf cress, and it originates from Persia (Iran).
Parts_Used: The edible shoots, leaves, and seeds of the garden cress plant are used. The leaves and shoots are commonly used as a salad green or seasoning due to their peppery taste, while the seeds can be ground and used as a spice.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Garden cress is a cool-season annual that can tolerate some frost. It grows best in full sun or partial shade, in well-draining, nutrient-rich loamy soil with a pH between 6.0-6.7.
Chemical_Properties: Garden cress is a rich source of proteins, carbohydrates, vitamins, and minerals including calcium, phosphorus, and alkaline phosphatase.
Morphological_Features: Garden cress has a fast growth habit, with many branches and narrow, oval-shaped leaves. The small pink to white flowers are 2 mm (1/12 in) in diameter and form a clustered inflorescence.
Medicinal_Value: In traditional medicine, garden cress has been used to treat a variety of ailments including stomachaches, asthma, diabetes, pneumonia, bronchitis, pain, dysentery, uterine tumors, cough, ulcers, and more.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Garden cress is cultivated throughout the world, but is believed to have originated in Persia (Iran). It grows well in many temperate regions.

Description: Cucumis sativus, commonly known as the cucumber, is a widely cultivated annual vine plant that belongs to the Cucurbitaceae family. Cucumbers are soft, succulent vegetables with a high water content. They have large leaves that form a canopy over the fruit. The vines grow on stakes or trellises and the fruit is roughly cylindrical, elongated with tapered ends.
Parts_Used: The entire cucumber plant is edible, including the fruit, leaves, and vines. The fruit is the most commonly consumed part, typically eaten raw in salads or pickled.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cucumbers thrive in warm, humid climates with temperatures above 20°C. They are sensitive to frost and require consistent moisture throughout the growing season. Optimal soil conditions are well-drained, nutrient-rich soils.
Chemical_Properties: Cucumbers are a good source of vitamins A, C, K, and B6, as well as minerals like potassium, magnesium, and manganese. They also contain beneficial compounds like ascorbic acid, caffeic acid, and silica.
Morphological_Features: Cucumbers are monoecious annual vines or creepers with large leaves. The fruit is cylindrical with tapered ends and may grow up to 30 cm in length. The skin can be green, white, yellow, or even striped.
Medicinal_Value: Cucumbers have been used in traditional medicine to soothe skin irritations and reduce swelling due to their high water content and the presence of compounds like ascorbic acid and caffeic acid.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Cucumbers are widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions around the world, including Asia, Europe, and North America. They are a major vegetable crop globally, with significant production in countries like China, India, and the United States.

Description: Eryngium foetidum, commonly known as culantro, is a biennial herb indigenous to the tropical regions of the Americas and the West Indies. Culantro is a perennial herb that grows up to 30 cm tall. It has long, dark green, spiny leaves that can reach up to 30 cm in length. The leaves have a serrated edge and a strong, pungent aroma similar to that of cilantro. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers in umbels.
Parts_Used: The leaves of the culantro plant are the primary parts used, both as a culinary herb and for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Culantro thrives in warm, humid, and shaded environments. It prefers well-irrigated, heavy soils and does best in partial shade. The plant tends to bolt and flower profusely during hot, long summer days, but this can be mitigated by using gibberellic acid (GA3) sprays to maintain its vegetative state.
Chemical_Properties: Culantro leaves are rich in calcium, iron, carotenoids, and riboflavin. The plant also contains various volatile compounds, including aldehydes, alcohols, and terpenes, which contribute to its distinctive aroma and flavor.
Morphological_Features: Culantro is a biennial herb with a rosette growth habit. The leaves are long, dark green, and have a serrated edge. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers in umbels.
Medicinal_Value: Culantro has a history of medicinal use in its native regions. It has been used to treat conditions such as flu, diabetes, constipation, and fevers. The plant also have anti-convulsant properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Culantro is native to the tropical regions of the Americas and the West Indies, including the Caribbean, Latin America, and parts of the Far East. It is widely used in the cuisines of these regions but is relatively unknown in many other parts of the world.

Description: Annona reticulata, commonly known as bullock's heart or Ramphal, is a small tree belonging to the Annonaceae family, native to India and tropical regions. It typically grows to a height of 5 to 10 meters and features thick, leathery leaves that are dark green and glossy. The tree produces distinctive, heart-shaped fruits that are yellowish-brown when ripe, with a creamy white flesh that is sweet and aromatic. The fruit is characterized by a pointed central fibrous core and a distinctly reticulated skin
Parts_Used: Various parts of Annona reticulata are utilized in traditional medicine. The leaves are used to make teas and extracts that address a range of ailments, while the fruit is consumed fresh or incorporated into remedies. The bark and roots are often used in decoctions to treat conditions like dysentery and diarrhea.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Thriving in tropical climates, Annona reticulata grows best in temperatures between 20°C to 30°C, though it can survive as low as 3°C and goes dormant in winter. It requires a humid atmosphere and grows well in deep, rich, well-drained soils, especially in low-lying areas.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains potent phytochemicals. Acetogenins, such as annoreticuin and bullatacin, have cytotoxic effects against cancer cells, while phenolic compounds provide antioxidant benefits. Additionally, flavonoids and tannins contribute to the plant’s anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial activities.
Morphological_Features: Annona reticulata is distinct in appearance. The leaves are thick, leathery, and dark green with a glossy finish. The flowers have yellowish-green petals that emit a pleasant fragrance, and the heart-shaped fruits are thin-skinned, yellowish-brown when ripe, with creamy white, sweet flesh inside.
Medicinal_Value: This species offers numerous health benefits. Extracts demonstrate anticancer properties by inhibiting cancer cell growth and migration in colon and breast cancers. Traditionally, it has been used to treat bacterial infections, constipation, ulcers, fever, epilepsy, and dysentery, with the leaves often used to soothe colic in infants. Its pharmacological activities include anti-hyperglycemic, analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and CNS depressant effects.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Annona reticulata is cultivated across multiple continents. In Asia, it is commonly found in India and Southeast Asia, while in Africa, it is grown as a dooryard fruit tree. It is also cultivated in South America for its edible fruit. The species thrives at elevations up to 1220 meters in India but does not grow well above 915 meters in Sri Lanka.

Description: Angelica dahurica, known as Dahurian Angelica or Bai Zhi, is a biennial herb from the Apiaceae family. It features large compound leaves and produces white flowers arranged in umbels.
Parts_Used: The roots are primarily used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers cool temperate climates with well-drained soil rich in organic matter.
Chemical_Properties: Contains essential oils and coumarins that contribute to its medicinal effects.
Morphological_Features: This plant typically reaches a height of up to 1 meter, showcasing large, compound leaves that give it a robust appearance. The flowers are white and arranged in striking, umbrella-like clusters, adding an elegant touch to its morphology.
Medicinal_Value: Used traditionally for treating headaches, nasal congestion, and skin disorders due to its anti-inflammatory properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to East Asia, particularly China and Japan.

Description: Salvia miltiorrhiza is a deciduous perennial plant that grows 30 to 60 cm tall, with branching stems. It has widely spaced leaves that are both simple and divided.
Parts_Used: The dried root of Salvia miltiorrhiza, known as Danshen, is the most commonly used part in traditional Chinese medicine. The plant also contains useful compounds in its leaves and flowers.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Danshen prefers well-drained soil, with about half a day of sunlight. It is hardy to approximately −10 °C (14 °F). Most Salvia seeds have a higher germination rate when exposed to light, though it is not required.
Chemical_Properties: Chemical compounds isolated from danshen include salvianolic acid (or salvianolic acid B), dihydrotanshinone, miltirone, tanshinone I, and tanshinone IIA. Tanshinone IIA is one of the most abundant constituents of the root. The plant also contains polysaccharides, which have various pharmacological activities.
Morphological_Features: The 30 cm inflorescences are covered with hairs and sticky glands. Flowers grow in whorls, with light purple to lavender blue corollas that are approximately 2.5 cm long, with a dark purple calyx.
Medicinal_Value: In traditional Chinese medicine, Salvia miltiorrhiza is used alone or combined with other herbs to treat various cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases. It exhibits diverse biological functions, such as anti-tumor, anti-oxidative stress, anti-thrombosis, anti-inflammatory, anti-liver fibrosis and anti-diabetes activities.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to China and Japan, danshen grows at 90 to 1,200 m (300 to 3,940 ft) elevation, preferring grassy places in forests, hillsides, and along stream banks in the west and southwest provinces of China.

Description: Taraxacum officinale, commonly known as the common dandelion, is a perennial herbaceous plant that belongs to the Asteraceae family. It has a basal rosette of leaves and produces bright yellow flower heads that mature into spherical seed heads.
Parts_Used: All parts of the dandelion plant are edible and have medicinal properties, including the leaves, stems, flowers, and roots.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Dandelions are hardy plants that can grow in a wide range of soil types and climatic conditions. They thrive in full sun to partial shade and prefer well-drained soil. Dandelions are tolerant of drought and can grow in poor soil conditions.
Chemical_Properties: Dandelions contain various phytochemicals, including terpenoids, flavonoids, coumarins, and phenolic acids. The plant is a rich source of vitamins A, C, and K, as well as minerals such as iron, calcium, and potassium.
Morphological_Features: Dandelions have a basal rosette of deeply lobed leaves that can grow up to 30 cm long. The leaves are dark green with reddish veins. The flower heads are solitary and measure 2-5 cm in diameter. The fruits are achenes with a pappus that allows them to be dispersed by wind.
Medicinal_Value: Dandelions have been used in traditional medicine for centuries to treat various ailments. They are believed to have diuretic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties. Dandelion extracts have been studied for their potential to treat liver disorders, diabetes, and certain types of cancer.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Dandelions are found throughout the world, including Europe, Asia, Africa, and North and South America. They are considered a weed in many regions but are also cultivated as a vegetable and medicinal herb.

Description: Berberis aristata, commonly known as Indian barberry or Daruhaldi, is a spiny evergreen shrub native to the Himalayas. It can grow up to 3 meters tall and has yellow flowers and red berries
Parts_Used: The root, stem, and bark of Berberis aristata are commonly used in traditional medicine.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Berberis aristata thrives in cool, temperate climates and is found at high altitudes in the Himalayas.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains several important phytochemicals, including the alkaloid berberine, which is the key active ingredient found in the stem and root parts. Other compounds include tetrahydropalmatine, palmatine, and jatrorrhizine.
Morphological_Features: Berberis aristata is a woody, spiny shrub with yellow flowers and red berries. The leaves are simple, obovate, and spiny-toothed. The plant has yellow wood and a thick, furrowed bark.
Medicinal_Value: Berberis aristata has been used in traditional medicine to treat various ailments, including inflammation, irritation, wounds, skin infections, fever, diabetes, and cancer. The plant has antibacterial, antimicrobial, antihepatotoxic, antidiabetic, anticancer, antioxidant, and hypolipidemic properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Berberis aristata is native to the Himalayas and is found in India, Nepal, Bhutan, and Pakistan.

Description: Phoenix dactylifera, commonly known as the date palm, is a flowering plant species from the palm family Arecaceae. It can grow up to 30 meters tall with a single trunk topped by a crown of large feathery leaves.
Parts_Used: The fruit (dates), leaves, bark, and sap are all utilized for various purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Date palms thrive in hot desert climates with well-drained sandy soils. They require full sun exposure and minimal rainfall for optimal growth.
Chemical_Properties: Dates are rich in sugars (fructose), vitamins (especially B vitamins), minerals (potassium), and antioxidants which contribute to their health benefits.
Morphological_Features: The tree has a tall trunk with a crown of long pinnate leaves; dates grow in clusters hanging from the branches.
Medicinal_Value: Dates are known for their nutritional value; they provide energy and have health benefits such as improving digestion and providing antioxidants.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Date palms are predominantly cultivated in Middle Eastern countries but have also spread to North Africa, California (USA), and parts of South Asia

Description: Harpagophytum procumbens, commonly known as Devil's Claw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Africa. It is a member of the Pedaliaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive hooked fruits that cling to passing animals for seed dispersal.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of the Harpagophytum procumbens plant used for medicinal purposes are the secondary roots and tubers. These underground structures contain the active compounds responsible for the plant's therapeutic effects.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Harpagophytum procumbens thrives in hot, arid climates and is well-adapted to the Kalahari Desert region of southern Africa. It requires full sun exposure and well-drained, sandy soils to grow optimally.
Chemical_Properties: The secondary roots and tubers of Harpagophytum procumbens contain a variety of bioactive compounds, including iridoid glycosides (such as harpagoside), phenolic compounds, and triterpenoids. These compounds contribute to the plant's anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antioxidant properties.
Morphological_Features: Harpagophytum procumbens is a low-growing, trailing plant with a prostrate habit. It has large, lobed leaves and distinctive hooked fruits that resemble a claw, which aid in seed dispersal. The plant produces large, tuberous secondary roots that can extend several meters underground.
Medicinal_Value: Harpagophytum procumbens has a long history of traditional use in southern Africa for treating a variety of ailments, including fever, diabetes, diarrhea, and inflammatory conditions such as arthritis, tendinitis, and kidney inflammation. Modern research has confirmed the plant's anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antioxidant properties, supporting its traditional medicinal uses.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Harpagophytum procumbens is native to the Kalahari Desert region of southern Africa, including Namibia, Botswana, and South Africa. It can also be found in other parts of Africa with similar hot, arid climates.

Plant_Name: Devil's-tongue / Elephant-yam / Konjac / Konnyaku / Leopard Palm / Mo-yu / Snake Palm / Umbrella Arum
Description: Amorphophallus konjac, also known as Konjac, Voodoo Lily, Corpse Flower, Snake Plant, Snake Palm, and Devil's Tongue, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to warm subtropical to tropical eastern Asia. It is part of the Araceae family and grows from a subterranean tuber that can reach up to 50 pounds and a foot in diameter. The plant produces a single leaf from the tuber, which consists of a mottled pinkish-gray and olive green petiole and a deeply dissected leaf blade divided into numerous small leaflets. Large specimens can grow up to 4-6 feet tall with leaf blades up to 4 feet across.
Parts_Used: The starchy tubers of Amorphophallus konjac are edible and used as a food source in parts of Asia. The tubers are processed into a tasteless flour or stiff jelly, which can be used as a vegan substitute for gelatin. In Japan, the tubers are used to make shirataki noodles and a popular Asian fruit jelly snack.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Konjac requires warm conditions to grow, with a minimum temperature of 60°F during the growing season and an optimum range of 68-77°F. The plant grows best in moist but well-drained, humus-rich, fertile soil and dappled shade, and does not tolerate clay soil or hot, afternoon sun. It is drought tolerant and frost hardy.
Chemical_Properties: The tubers of Amorphophallus konjac contain calcium oxalate, which makes them toxic if consumed raw. The plant also produces an odor of rotten flesh when the flowers are ripe for pollination, which attracts carrion flies and midges.
Morphological_Features: Amorphophallus konjac produces a single leaf from the tuber each year, consisting of a mottled pinkish-gray and olive green petiole and a deeply dissected leaf blade divided into numerous small leaflets. The plant also produces a single inflorescence in late winter or spring before the leaf emerges. The inflorescence is made up of a dense, spike-like spadix bearing numerous small male and female flowers and a leafy, dark maroon to purple-brown spathe with ruffled margins.
Medicinal_Value: Konjac has been used as a traditional medicine in Asia. It also have  potential benefits for treating constipation in rats.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Konjac is primarily found in warm subtropical to tropical regions of eastern Asia, including Vietnam, Japan, China, and Indonesia. It can also be grown in cool to tropical climates.

Description: Woodfordia fruticosa is a shrub that can grow up to 3 meters tall. It has reddish-brown bark and produces clusters of bright red flowers.
Parts_Used: The flowers of Dhawaifool are commonly used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Woodfordia grows well in tropical and subtropical regions with moderate rainfall. It prefers well-drained soil and can tolerate a wide range of soil types.
Chemical_Properties: The flowers of Woodfordia fruticosa contain tannins, flavonoids, and other phytochemicals that contribute to its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Woodfordia fruticosa is a shrub with reddish-brown bark and clusters of bright red flowers. The leaves are simple, opposite, and lanceolate in shape.
Medicinal_Value: In traditional medicine, Woodfordia fruticosa has been used to treat various ailments, including diarrhea, dysentery, and menorrhagia. The flowers are known for their astringent, anti-inflammatory, and hemostatic properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Woodfordia fruticosa is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, including India, Sri Lanka, and parts of Southeast Asia. It can also be found in parts of Africa and Australia.

Description: Anethum graveolens, commonly known as dill, is an annual herb that belongs to the Apiaceae family. It is native to the Mediterranean region and western Asia.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of the plant, including the leaves, flowers, and seeds, are used for their medicinal and culinary properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Dill prefers warm, sunny conditions and well-drained soil. It can tolerate a wide range of soil types but thrives in fertile, slightly acidic soil.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil extracted from dill contains various compounds, including limonene, carvone, dihydrocarvone, and trans-carvone. These compounds contribute to the plant's antimicrobial, antioxidant, and anti-quorum sensing properties.
Morphological_Features: Dill is an aromatic herb that can grow up to 60 cm tall. It has finely divided, feathery leaves and yellow flowers that form flat-topped clusters. The seeds are oval-shaped and brown in color.
Medicinal_Value: Dill has been used in traditional medicine to treat various ailments, such as digestive disorders, insomnia, and respiratory problems. The essential oil and extracts from the plant have shown antimicrobial, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Dill is widely cultivated in many parts of the world, including Europe, North America, and Asia. It grows well in temperate climates and can be grown as an annual or biennial crop.

Plant_Name: East Indian Walnut / Frywood / Koko / Lebbek / Lebbek Tree / Siris Tree / Women's-Tongue Tree
Description: Albizia lebbeck, commonly known as Siris, is a large deciduous tree belonging to the Fabaceae family. It is native to tropical southern Asia but has been widely cultivated in other tropical and subtropical regions. Albizia lebbeck can grow up to 20 meters tall, featuring bi-pinnate leaves that are 10-20 cm long. The tree produces white, fragrant flowers arranged in clusters, followed by flat pods containing six to twelve seeds. The bark is grayish-brown and has a rough texture.
Parts_Used: The primary medicinal components of Albizia lebbeck are its pods, seeds, and bark. Pods are commonly used for their therapeutic benefits, seeds contribute to various health benefits, and bark extracts are utilized in traditional medicine practices.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Albizia lebbeck thrives in warm, tropical climates, ideally at temperatures between 20°C to 35°C. The plant requires moderate annual rainfall of 750 to 1500 mm and prefers well-drained sandy or loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
Chemical_Properties: The plant is rich in bioactive compounds, such as saponins, flavonoids, and phenolic compounds. These elements contribute to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, enhancing its medicinal value.
Morphological_Features: Albizia lebbeck is characterized by bi-pinnate, feathery leaves and white, fragrant flowers that attract pollinators. Its long, flat pods mature to release seeds, marking its distinct reproductive structure.
Medicinal_Value: Albizia lebbeck is traditionally utilized for its diverse medicinal properties, including antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, and antidiabetic effects. It also shows neuroprotective potential, with promising applications in managing neurodegenerative conditions like Parkinson's disease.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Albizia lebbeck grows extensively across South Asia (India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka), Southeast Asia (Thailand, Indonesia), and tropical regions in Africa, where it is widely cultivated.

Description: Echinacea purpurea, commonly known as the purple coneflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to eastern North America. It is a member of the daisy family (Asteraceae) and is known for its distinctive purple-pink flowers with a prominent central cone.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of the Echinacea purpurea plant, including the leaves, stems, and flowers, are commonly used for medicinal purposes. The roots may also be utilized in some preparations.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Echinacea purpurea thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained, moist soil. It can tolerate a wide range of soil types but performs best in rich, loamy soils. The plant is hardy and can withstand cold temperatures, making it suitable for growth in USDA hardiness zones 3-8.
Chemical_Properties: Echinacea purpurea contains a variety of bioactive compounds, including polyphenols, alkylamides, and polysaccharides. The plant is particularly rich in caffeic acid derivatives, such as cichoric acid and caftaric acid, which are believed to contribute to its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Echinacea purpurea is a herbaceous plant that can grow up to 1-2 meters tall. It has large, coarsely toothed leaves and distinctive purple-pink flowers with a prominent central cone. The flowers typically bloom from mid-summer to early fall.
Medicinal_Value: Echinacea purpurea has been used in traditional medicine for its immunomodulatory, anti-inflammatory, and wound-healing properties. Theextracts from the plant can enhance immune function, reduce inflammation, and promote wound healing.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Echinacea purpurea is native to the eastern and central regions of North America, including the United States and Canada. However, it has been successfully cultivated in various parts of the world, including Europe and Asia, where it is widely used in herbal medicine and cosmetic products.

Description: Allium ampeloprasum, commonly known as wild leek, is a biennial herb that belongs to the genus Allium. It is closely related to cultivated leeks (Allium ampeloprasum var. porrum) and elephant garlic (Allium ampeloprasum var. ampeloprasum). Unlike onions, wild leeks do not form bulbs but instead consist of sheaths of basal leaves that can grow up to 15-25 cm long and 5 cm in diameter.
Parts_Used: The edible parts of wild leek are the leaves and flowers. The leaves have a pleasant mild to strong garlic flavor and are available from late autumn to spring, although they can become tough and fibrous as they age. The flowers have a similar flavor to the leaves but have a somewhat dry texture and are best used as a flavoring in cooked foods.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Leeks thrive in temperate climates and require well-drained, loose soil for optimal growth. The ideal temperature for leek cultivation is around 20 °C (68 °F), and they are more cold-tolerant than many other Allium species, allowing for year-round production in suitable regions. While they can be seeded directly into the soil, they are often started in seedbeds and then transplanted after approximately 12 weeks when they reach a pencil thickness.
Chemical_Properties: Leeks are rich in various nutrients and bioactive compounds. They contain organosulfur compounds, which are known for their potential health benefits, including antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. Nutritionally, leeks provide vitamins A, C, K, and several B vitamins, along with minerals such as iron, calcium, and manganese. They are also a source of dietary fiber, contributing to digestive health.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, Allium ampeloprasum exhibits several distinctive features. The plant typically has a cylindrical stalk that can reach significant heights, with broad, flat leaves that grow from the base. The flowers, which appear in clusters, are usually spherical and can be white or purple, attracting various pollinators. The root system consists of a bulb that is often larger than that of other Allium species, which aids in nutrient storage and growth.
Medicinal_Value: Leeks have been recognized for their medicinal properties in various cultures. They are believed to possess antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial effects, making them beneficial for overall health. The consumption of leeks may support cardiovascular health, improve digestion, and enhance immune function. Additionally, the presence of vitamins and minerals contributes to their role in promoting general well-being.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Allium ampeloprasum is cultivated in many regions worldwide, particularly in temperate climates. Major producers include countries in Europe, such as France, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom, where leeks are a staple vegetable. They can also be found in parts of Asia and North America, where they are grown in home gardens and commercial farms alike. The adaptability of leeks to various soil types and climates makes them a popular choice for cultivation in diverse agricultural settings.

Description: Chenopodium ambrosioides, also known as epazote is an annual or short-lived perennial herb native to the Americas. It grows up to 1.2 m (3 ft 11 in) tall, with irregularly branched stems and oblong-lanceolate leaves up to 12 cm (4+1⁄2 in) long. The small green flowers are produced in a branched panicle at the apex of the stem.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of epazote, including the stem, leaves, and flowers, are commonly used as a condiment and for their medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Epazote grows well in warm temperate to subtropical areas. It can be found in its native range in tropical Central and South America.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil of ambrosioides contains terpene compounds, some of which have natural pesticide capabilities. The compound ascaridole is a major constituent of the essential oil.
Morphological_Features: C. ambrosioides is an annual or short-lived perennial herb with irregularly branched stems and oblong-lanceolate leaves up to 12 cm long. The small green flowers are produced in a branched panicle at the apex of the stem.
Medicinal_Value: Epazoate has been used in traditional medicines worldwide for its various medicinal properties. The essential oil has been commercialized to control greenhouse insects and mites.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: In addition to its native range in tropical Central and South America, C. ambrosioides is also grown in warm temperate to subtropical areas of Europe and the United States, sometimes becoming an invasive weed.

Description: Oenothera biennis, commonly known as the common evening-primrose, is a species of flowering plant native to eastern and central North America. It typically has a biennial life cycle, growing as a low, spreading herb in the first year with leaves in a rosette, and then reaching up to 1.6 m tall on a semi-woody stem in the second year before flowering and seeding. The yellow flowers are 2.5-5 cm in diameter with four bilobed petals, opening visibly fast in the evening.
Parts_Used: All parts of the Oenothera biennis plant can be used, including the leaves, stems, and seeds. Evening primrose oil is produced from the seeds.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Oenothera biennis prefers sunny areas with average moisture conditions, but it can also grow in less favorable conditions. It is a weedy species that favors disturbed environments and has been introduced and become established on all continents except Antarctica.
Chemical_Properties: Common components of all parts of Oenothera biennis plants are fatty acids, phenolic acids, and flavonoids. The seeds also contain gamma-linolenic acid (GLA).
Morphological_Features: Oenothera biennis grows to 1.6 m tall in the seeding year. The leaves are lanceolate, 8-18 cm long and 2-6 cm wide. The yellow flowers are 2.5-5 cm in diameter with four bilobed petals. The fruit is a capsule 2-4 cm long containing numerous 1-2 mm long seeds.
Medicinal_Value: Oenothera biennis has been indicated as beneficial in the treatment of many diseases. Evening primrose oil is used to assist with pain relief, osteoporosis, fertility, diabetes, acne and other conditions.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Oenothera biennis is native to eastern and central North America but has been introduced and become established on all continents except Antarctica. It has adapted to new areas and about 70 species are now present in Europe.

Description: Euphrasia officinalis, commonly known as eyebright, is a small annual herb that belongs to the Orobanchaceae family. It is native to Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia, and is widely used in traditional medicine for its medicinal properties. Eyebright is a small, semi-parasitic plant that grows to a height of 5-25 cm. It has a slender, erect stem that is often branched. The leaves are opposite, sessile, and oblong-lanceolate in shape, with toothed margins. The flowers are small, white or pale purple, and have a two-lipped corolla. The fruit is a capsule containing small, brown seeds.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of the Euphrasia officinalis plant, including the leaves, stems, and flowers, are the parts commonly used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Eyebright prefers cool, moist environments and grows best in well-drained, acidic soils. It thrives in areas with cool summers and mild winters, such as in mountainous regions or northern latitudes.
Chemical_Properties: Euphrasia officinalis contains a variety of bioactive compounds, including iridoid glycosides, flavonoids, tannins, and phenolic acids. These compounds are believed to contribute to the plant's medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has a slender, erect stem that is often branched. The leaves are opposite, sessile, and oblong-lanceolate in shape, with toothed margins. The flowers are small, white or pale purple, and have a two-lipped corolla.
Medicinal_Value: Eyebright has been used in traditional medicine for a variety of purposes, including the treatment of eye-related conditions, such as conjunctivitis, blepharitis, and dry eyes. It is also believed to have anti-inflammatory, astringent, and antiseptic properties, and has been used to treat respiratory conditions, such as sinusitis and bronchitis.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Euphrasia officinalis is native to Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia, and is widely distributed in these regions. It can be found growing in mountainous areas, meadows, and other cool, moist environments.

Description: Arecastrum romanzoffianum, commonly known as the queen palm, is a tall palm species native to South America. It features a slender trunk with feathery fronds that can reach lengths of up to 5 meters.
Parts_Used: The fronds are often used for ornamental purposes; the seeds can also be harvested for various uses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Queen palms thrive in warm climates with full sun exposure. They prefer well-drained soils and are typically grown in USDA zones 10-11.
Chemical_Properties: While not extensively studied for medicinal properties like other plants mentioned here, the seeds contain oils that may have potential benefits.
Morphological_Features: This palm has a smooth trunk topped with long arching fronds that give it an elegant appearance. The inflorescences produce small yellow flowers followed by black fruits.
Medicinal_Value: Limited research exists on the medicinal uses of queen palm; however, it may have some applications in traditional medicine among indigenous cultures.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to tropical regions of South America but widely cultivated in subtropical areas around the world for landscaping purposes.

Description: Foeniculum vulgare, commonly known as fennel, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Apiaceae (carrot) family and is characterized by its feathery, aromatic leaves and yellow flowers that form umbrella-shaped clusters.
Parts_Used: The entire plant of Foeniculum vulgare is utilized for various purposes. The most commonly used parts are the fruits (seeds), leaves, and roots.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Fennel thrives in warm, temperate climates and prefers well-drained, fertile soil. It can tolerate a wide range of soil types but performs best in full sun exposure. Fennel is drought-tolerant and can withstand moderate salinity levels.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil of Foeniculum vulgare is the primary source of its medicinal and aromatic properties. The oil is composed of compounds such as trans-anethole, fenchone, and estragole, which contribute to its carminative, antispasmodic, and antimicrobial effects.
