Morphological_Features: Fennel is a tall, branching herb that can reach up to 2 meters in height. It has feathery, finely divided leaves and hollow, grooved stems. The flowers are small and yellow, forming umbrella-shaped clusters. The fruits are oblong-shaped and contain numerous small seeds.
Medicinal_Value: Fennel has a long history of use in traditional medicine for its various therapeutic properties. It is known to have carminative (gas-expelling), antispasmodic, analgesic, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and mild diuretic effects. Fennel is commonly used to aid digestion, relieve gastrointestinal discomfort, and improve the functional state of the gastrointestinal tract.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Foeniculum vulgare is widely cultivated and naturalized in many parts of the world, including the Mediterranean region, Western Asia, Europe, and North America. It thrives in temperate climates and can be found growing in various habitats, such as roadsides, fields, and waste areas.

Description: Trigonella foenum-graecum, commonly known as fenugreek, is an annual herb that belongs to the Fabaceae family. It is a leguminous plant cultivated worldwide for its leaves and seeds, which are used as a vegetable, spice, and medicinal herb.
Parts_Used: The most commonly used parts of fenugreek are the seeds and leaves. The seeds are used as a spice and for medicinal purposes, while the leaves are used as a vegetable and for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Fenugreek thrives in warm climates and requires well-drained soil with a pH between 6.0 and 7.5. It can tolerate a wide range of temperatures, but the ideal temperature range for growth is between 20°C and 30°C. Fenugreek is sensitive to frost and requires adequate moisture during the growing season.
Chemical_Properties: Fenugreek seeds contain a variety of chemical compounds, including alkaloids, flavonoids, saponins, and volatile oils. The seeds are a rich source of proteins, fibers, and minerals such as iron, phosphorus, and calcium.
Morphological_Features: Fenugreek is an erect annual herb that can grow up to 60 cm tall. The leaves are trifoliate, with leaflets that are oblong or lanceolate in shape. The flowers are small, white or yellow, and are borne in clusters. The fruits are long, slender pods that contain small, angular, brownish-yellow seeds.
Medicinal_Value: Fenugreek has a wide range of medicinal properties. It has been used to treat various conditions, including diabetes, high cholesterol, digestive issues, and inflammation. Fenugreek seeds have been shown to have antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Fenugreek is cultivated in many parts of the world, including India, North Africa, and the Middle East. It is also grown in Europe, North America, and South America.

Description: Tanacetum parthenium, commonly known as feverfew, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Asteraceae family. It is a bushy, aromatic plant that can grow up to 60 cm tall. The leaves are alternate, pinnately divided, and have a strong, pungent odor. The flowers are small, daisy-like, and white or yellow in color, appearing in clusters at the top of the plant.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of the plant, including the leaves, flowers, and stems, are the parts most commonly used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Feverfew prefers well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade. It can tolerate a wide range of soil types and grows best in temperate climates.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil of feverfew contains a variety of compounds, with camphor, trans-chrysanthenyl acetate, camphene, and cis-isogeraniol being the dominant components. The plant also contains parthenolide, flavonoids, and phenolic compounds. The plant is rich in various bioactive compounds, including Sesquiterpene lactones, such as parthenolide, which are responsible for the plant's anti-inflammatory and anti-migraine properties, Flavonoids, such as luteolin and apigenin, which possess antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities and Essential oils, containing compounds like camphor, artemisia ketone, and 1,8-cineole
Morphological_Features: The plant has a well-developed taproot system and a branched, erect stem. The leaves are alternate, pinnately divided, and have a strong, pungent odor. The flowers are small, daisy-like, and white or yellow in color, appearing in clusters at the top of the plant.
Medicinal_Value: Feverfew has a long history of use in traditional medicine for treating various conditions, including fever, pain, inflammation, asthma, rheumatism, menstrual disorders, and migraine headaches. However, the efficacy of feverfew for migraine prevention is inconclusive.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Feverfew is widely distributed in various regions of Europe and other parts of the world. It is native to the Balkan Peninsula and has been introduced to other regions, including North America and Asia.

Description: Linum usitatissimum, commonly known as flax or linseed, is an annual plant in the family Linaceae. It is native to West Asia and the Mediterranean coastal lands, Asia Minor, Egypt, Algeria, Tunisia, Spain, Italy, and Greece. The plant grows to a height of 0.9 to 1.2 meters (3 to 4 feet) with slender stalks 2.5 to 4 mm (about 0.10 to 0.15 inch) in diameter.
Parts_Used:
Seeds which are used for linseed oil and flaxseed, which are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and lignans.
Fibers used to produce linen, a bast fiber known for its strength, durability, and moisture absorbency.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Flax is adaptable to a variety of soils and climates but grows best in well-drained sandy loam and in temperate climates. It requires few fertilizers or pesticides and can be grown in areas with cool, moist growing seasons.
Chemical_Properties: Linseed Oil (obtained from the seeds, it is a drying oil used in paints, varnishes, linoleum, and printing inks) , Flaxseed (rich in omega-3 fatty acids and lignans, making it a nutritious food and a health supplement).
Morphological_Features: Small and lance-shaped leaves, alternating on the stalk ,  Five-petaled flowers, usually blue but sometimes white or pink, borne on stems growing from the branch tips. Fruits which are small, dry capsules composed of five lobes, containing several glossy brown seeds shaped like apple pips.
Medicinal_Value: Flaxseed and its oil are generally recognized as safe for human consumption. They contain small amounts of cyanogenic glycoside, which is nontoxic when consumed in typical amounts.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Flaxseed is historically important in Europe for linen production, particularly in France, Belgium, and Russia. It is grown in parts of North America (Canada) for linseed oil and as an ornamental plant. Flaxseed is Cultivated in China and other regions for linseed oil and flaxseed.

Description: Agaricus muscarius, commonly known as the fly agaric, is a basidiomycete fungus that is one of the most iconic and recognizable mushroom species. It has a distinctive red cap with white spots and a white stipe (stem). The cap can reach up to 30 cm in diameter and the stipe can grow up to 20 cm tall.
Parts_Used: The entire fruiting body of the Agaricus muscarius mushroom is used, including the cap, stipe, and volva (the remnants of the universal veil at the base of the stipe).
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Fly agaric prefers cool, moist environments and is commonly found in coniferous or mixed forests, often in association with birch trees. It typically grows during the late summer and fall months when temperatures are moderate and precipitation is higher.
Chemical_Properties: The Agaricus muscarius mushroom contains several psychoactive compounds, including ibotenic acid and muscimol, which are responsible for its hallucinogenic effects. These compounds can be toxic in high doses and the mushroom is considered poisonous if consumed without proper preparation.
Morphological_Features: The cap of Fly agaric is bright red or orange-red in color and is covered with white, wart-like spots or patches. The stipe is white, cylindrical, and bears a ring or skirt-like partial veil. The gills are white to pale yellow and free from the stipe.
Medicinal_Value: Agaricus muscarius has a long history of use in traditional medicine, particularly in Siberian and other indigenous cultures. It has been used for its psychoactive properties, as well as for its potential anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and sedative effects. However, its use requires caution due to the toxicity of its active compounds.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Agaricus muscarius is found throughout the Northern Hemisphere, including North America, Europe, and Asia. It is particularly common in boreal and temperate forests, where it forms mycorrhizal associations with various tree species.

Description: Coleus forskohlii is a perennial plant in the mint family (Lamiaceae). It is commonly known as Forskohlii or Indian Coleus. The plant has a distinctive appearance, with its leaves being the most notable feature. The leaves are typically large, ovate, and have a distinctive shape with a pointed tip. The plant can grow up to 1 meter (3.3 feet) in height and has a branching stem.
Parts_Used: The parts of the plant used are primarily the leaves and the root. The leaves are used in traditional medicine and as a flavoring agent in food. The root is the primary source of the bioactive compound forskolin, which is used in various pharmaceutical applications.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Forskohlii grows best in warm and humid conditions. It prefers full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil. The plant can tolerate some drought but thrives in areas with regular rainfall.
Chemical_Properties: The most significant chemical compound found in Coleus forskohlii is forskolin, a diterpene that is extracted from the root of the plant. Forskolin is known for its various pharmacological activities, including its ability to stimulate the enzyme adenylate cyclase, which increases cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels in cells. This property makes it useful in various pharmaceutical applications, including cardiovascular and respiratory treatments.
Morphological_Features: Forskohlii has large, ovate, and pointed leaves, with a distinctive shape. The plant has branched stem, up to 1 meter in height. The primary source of forskolin is root which is used in pharmaceutical applications.
Medicinal_Value: Forskolin has been shown to lower blood pressure and improve cardiovascular health. It can help relax the airways and improve breathing. The extracts of Coleus forskohlii have been used in weight management supplements due to their potential to increase cAMP levels and stimulate lipolysis.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Coleus forskohlii is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, particularly in India and Nepal. It can be found in the wild in these regions and is also cultivated for its medicinal and ornamental value.

Description: Anemone coronaria, commonly known as the Poppy Anemone or Crown Anemone, belongs to the family Ranunculaceae. This perennial plant is native to the Mediterranean region and is characterized by its vibrant, cup-shaped flowers that bloom in various colors, including red, purple, white, and blue. The plant typically grows to a height of 25-60 cm and features finely divided leaves that are either alternate or whorled. The flowering period extends from mid-spring (April) to early summer (June), during which it produces showy blooms that are attractive to pollinators like bees and butterflies
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Anemone coronaria used in traditional medicine include the aerial parts of the plant, particularly the flowers and leaves. These parts are often prepared as decoctions for various medicinal applications. The tubers are also significant as they serve both as storage organs and for vegetative propagation
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Anemone coronaria thrives in USDA hardiness zones 7-10, preferring full sun to partial shade. It requires well-drained soil with good organic content and moderate moisture. The ideal temperature range for growth is between 10-20°C (50-68°F). The plant is sensitive to frost; thus, it is often treated as an annual in colder climates where temperatures drop below -6.5°C (20°F) during winter. In milder regions, it can survive if planted in a sheltered location that avoids winter wetness
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains several bioactive compounds, including protoanemonin, which is responsible for its toxic properties. Protoanemonin can cause skin irritation and gastrointestinal distress if ingested in large quantities. However, when dried, this compound converts into non-toxic anemonine. The medicinal properties attributed to Anemone coronaria include anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects, making it useful in traditional remedies for various ailments
Morphological_Features: Anemone coronaria exhibits distinctive morphological characteristics. This species typically reaches a height of 25 to 60 cm. Its leaves are finely divided and can be found either in an alternate or whorled arrangement. The flowers are notable for their cup-shaped structure, featuring multiple petal-like elements. These flowers come in a variety of colors, including red, purple, white, and blue. Following successful pollination, Anemone coronaria produces small achenes with plumose tails, which contribute to its reproductive process.
Medicinal_Value: purposes. It is believed to possess anti-atherosclerotic properties, contributing to cardiovascular health. Additionally, decoctions made from its aerial parts are applied topically to treat skin inflammation, showcasing its dermatological benefits. The plant is also noted for its anxiolytic effects, potentially helping to alleviate nervousness and promote mental well-being. Furthermore, Anemone coronaria has a history of being used to address other health issues, including dysentery and arthritis, demonstrating its diverse applications in traditional healing practices.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Anemone coronaria is primarily found in the Mediterranean region but has been cultivated globally due to its ornamental value. It grows well in various regions across Europe, North America, and parts of Asia where similar climatic conditions exist. Its adaptability allows it to naturalize in gardens and parks within suitable hardiness zones

Description: Dipsacus fullonum, commonly known as Fuller's teasel or wild teasel, is a biennial plant species in the family Dipsacaceae. It has a tall, prickly stem that can grow up to 2 meters in height. The leaves are sessile, lanceolate, and prickly on the underside along the midrib. The inflorescence is a dense, ovoid to cylindrical flower head with purple flowers. The bracts are linear-lanceolate, prickly, and curved upwards.
Parts_Used: The roots and seeds of Dipsacus fullonum are used for medicinal purposes. The dried roots are used in traditional Chinese medicine, while the seeds are used to make a tea.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Fuller's teasel grows best in full sun and well-drained soil. It prefers a pH range of 6.1 to 7.8 (slightly acidic to slightly alkaline). The plant is hardy in USDA zones 4 to 8.
Chemical_Properties: The roots of fuller's teasel contain iridoid glycosides, such as dipsacoside B and 8-acetylharpagide. The seeds contain fatty acids, including linoleic acid and oleic acid.
Morphological_Features: Dipsacus fullonum is a biennial plant that forms a rosette of leaves in its first year. In the second year, it produces a tall, prickly stem with opposite, sessile leaves. The inflorescence is a dense, ovoid to cylindrical flower head with purple flowers. The bracts are linear-lanceolate, prickly, and curved upwards.
Medicinal_Value: In traditional Chinese medicine, the roots of fuller's teasel are used to treat osteoporosis, fractures, and joint pain. The seeds are used to make a tea that is believed to have diuretic and tonic properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Fuller's teasel is native to Europe and Asia but has naturalized in many parts of the world, including North America, South America, and Australia. It grows well in temperate regions with well-drained soil and full sun.

Description: Gmelina arborea, commonly known as white teak or gumhar, is a medium-sized to large deciduous tree native to the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia. It can grow up to 30-40 meters tall with a straight, cylindrical trunk and a spreading, rounded crown.
Parts_Used: The various parts of the gumhar tree that are utilized include the leaves, bark, flowers, fruits, and wood.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Gamar thrives in tropical and subtropical climates with an annual rainfall of 1,000-2,500 mm. It prefers well-drained, fertile soils and can tolerate a wide range of soil types, including sandy, loamy, and clay soils. The tree is moderately tolerant of drought and frost.
Chemical_Properties: The leaves, bark, and fruits of gamar contain various phytochemicals, including flavonoids, tannins, saponins, and terpenoids. These compounds contribute to the medicinal properties of the plant.
Morphological_Features: Gumhar has a straight, cylindrical trunk with smooth, pale gray bark. The leaves are simple, opposite, and broadly ovate or heart-shaped, with a pointed tip. The flowers are yellow or orange, tubular, and arranged in terminal clusters. The fruit is a drupe, initially green and turning yellow or orange when ripe.
Medicinal_Value: Gmelina arborea has a long history of use in traditional medicine systems, particularly in Ayurveda. The bark, leaves, and fruits have been used to treat a variety of ailments, including fever, inflammation, liver disorders, and respiratory problems. The plant has anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and hepatoprotective properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Gmelina arborea is native to the Indian subcontinent, including India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka, as well as Southeast Asia, including Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam. It is also cultivated in other tropical and subtropical regions, such as Central and South America, Africa, and parts of Australia.

Description: Rumex acetosa, commonly known as sorrel, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Polygonaceae family. It features arrow-shaped leaves that are edible and has small greenish flowers that bloom from late spring to early summer.
Parts_Used: The leaves are primarily used for culinary purposes due to their tart flavor. Young leaves are preferred for salads, while older leaves can be used in soups or sauces.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Sorrel grows best in well-drained soil with moderate moisture. It prefers full sun but can tolerate partial shade. Ideal growing conditions are found in USDA zones 3-9.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains oxalic acid, which gives it its characteristic sour taste. It also possesses vitamins A and C, calcium, and iron. The presence of oxalic acid means that consumption should be moderated.
Morphological_Features: Sorrel has a rosette of basal leaves with long petioles and a tall flowering stalk that can reach up to 1 meter. The flowers are small and clustered in spikes.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for its diuretic properties, sorrel is also thought to aid digestion and provide vitamin C. However, excessive consumption should be avoided due to oxalic acid content.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Rumex acetosa is native to Europe but has spread globally and is commonly found in temperate regions worldwide.

Description: Allium sativum, commonly known as garlic, is a perennial bulbous plant that belongs to the Allium genus of the Amaryllidaceae family. It is widely cultivated for its distinctive flavor and numerous health benefits.
Parts_Used: The primary part of the garlic plant used is the underground bulb, which is composed of individual cloves. The leaves, stems, and flowers are also sometimes utilized for culinary and medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Garlic thrives in well-drained, fertile soil with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0. It prefers a cool, temperate climate and can tolerate a wide range of temperatures, from as low as -10°C (14°F) to as high as 30°C (86°F). Garlic requires full sun exposure and moderate rainfall, typically 20-30 cm (8-12 inches) per year.
Chemical_Properties: Garlic is rich in various sulfur-containing compounds, including allicin, alliin, and diallyl disulfide, which are responsible for its pungent aroma and numerous health benefits. It also contains vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, such as vitamin C, vitamin B6, manganese, and selenium.
Morphological_Features: Garlic plants grow to a height of 30-60 cm (12-24 inches) and have long, flat, linear leaves. The bulb is composed of several individual cloves, each enclosed in a thin, papery skin. The flowers are small, white, and form a spherical umbel inflorescence.
Medicinal_Value: Garlic has been used for its medicinal properties for centuries. It has been shown to have antimicrobial, antiviral, and antifungal properties, as well as potential benefits for cardiovascular health, immune function, and cancer prevention. Garlic is also used to treat various ailments, such as colds, flu, and high blood pressure.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Garlic is cultivated worldwide, with major production centers in China, India, the United States, and various European countries. It can be grown in a wide range of climates, from temperate to subtropical regions, as long as the soil and weather conditions are suitable.

Description: Agastache rugosa, commonly known as Korean mint, is an aromatic perennial herb belonging to the Lamiaceae family. Native to East Asia, particularly China, Korea, and Japan, it is recognized for its striking purple flower spikes and fragrant foliage. Agastache rugosa typically grows to a height of 40 to 100 centimeters (16 to 39 inches) and features square, branching stems. The leaves are oval-cordate, measuring 5 to 10 cm (2 to 4 inches) long and 3 to 7 cm (1.25 to 2.75 inches) broad, with serrated edges and a slightly hairy underside. The plant blooms from July to September, producing clusters of purple flowers that attract various pollinators, including bees and butterflies.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of korean mint used for medicinal and culinary purposes include the leaves and flowers. The leaves are known for their strong aroma and are often used in herbal teas and traditional medicine. The flowers are also utilized for their aesthetic appeal and potential health benefits.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Korean mint thrives in full sun and prefers well-drained soils. It is drought-tolerant but requires adequate moisture during prolonged dry spells. The plant is hardy in USDA zones 4 to 9, making it suitable for a range of climates. It dislikes damp conditions and needs excellent drainage to prevent root rot.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains various bioactive compounds, including estragole, which is predominant in its essential oils. Other constituents include menthone, pulegone, and various terpenes. These compounds contribute to its aromatic properties and potential medicinal effects, such as anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial activities.
Morphological_Features: Korean mint exhibits distinct morphological traits, including its erect growth habit, square stems, and aromatic leaves. The flowers are tubular and arranged in dense spikes, typically purple or lavender in color. The plant's foliage is light green and has a slightly serrated margin, contributing to its ornamental value in gardens.
Medicinal_Value: In traditional medicine, particularly within Chinese herbal practices, Agastache rugosa is used to treat various ailments, including digestive issues, respiratory conditions, and skin infections. It is believed to have warming properties and is often combined with other herbs to enhance its therapeutic effects. Scientific studies have indicated potential antiviral properties, particularly against HIV.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Korean mint is primarily found in East Asia, including China, Korea, Japan, and parts of Russia and Taiwan. It has also been cultivated in other regions, including North America and Europe, where it is appreciated for its ornamental and medicinal qualities. The plant adapts well to various soil types, including sandy, loamy, and clay soils, as long as they are well-drained.

Description: Tinospora cordifolia, commonly known as guduchi or giloy, is a perennial herbaceous vine belonging to the Menispermaceae family. It is widely used in Ayurvedic medicine for various ailments, including inflammatory conditions, autoimmune disorders, and cancer, as well as for promoting general health.
Parts_Used: The stem and leaves of the giloy are used for its medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Tinospora cordifolia grows in a variety of weather conditions, but it prefers warm to hot temperatures, Moderate to high humidity and Well-drained soil with adequate sunlight.
Chemical_Properties: Giloy contains several bioactive compounds, including Steroids such as withanolides and withaferin A, Terpenoids including withanolides and withaferin A, Flavonoids including quercetin and kaempferol and Alkaloids including withanine and withanolide A. The plant also contains various chemical constituents, including diterpenoid lactones, glycosides, sesquiterpenoid, phenolics, aliphatic compounds, and polysaccharides. Some of the major active compounds are tinosporide, cordifolide, cordifol, heptacosanol, clerodane furano diterpene, and 11-hydroxymustakone.
Morphological_Features: Tinospora cordifolia is a large, glabrous, deciduous climbing shrub. The leaves are simple, cordate at the base, and membranous. The flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in axillary or terminal racemes or panicles. The fruits are drupes, red in color when ripe.
Medicinal_Value: Tinospora cordifolia has been used in Ayurvedic medicine for centuries to treat various ailments. It has been reported to have immunomodulatory, antidiabetic, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antiallergic, and antipyretic properties. The plant is used to treat diabetes, fever, dyspepsia, urinary diseases, jaundice, and skin diseases.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Tinospora cordifolia is found throughout tropical regions of the Indian subcontinent, including India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka. It is also found in Southeast Asia and parts of Africa.

Description: Zingiber officinale, commonly known as ginger, is a perennial herbaceous plant that belongs to the Zingiberaceae family. It is a rhizomatous plant, meaning it has an underground stem or rhizome that is the primary edible part. The plant can grow up to 1 meter tall, with narrow, elongated leaves and small yellow-green flowers.
Parts_Used: The primary part of the ginger plant used for medicinal and culinary purposes is the rhizome or underground stem. The rhizome is harvested, dried, and used in various forms, such as fresh, dried, powdered, or as an essential oil.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Ginger thrives in warm, humid climates with well-drained, fertile soil. It requires an average temperature between 20-30°C and an annual rainfall of 1,500-2,000 mm. Ginger can be grown in tropical and subtropical regions, with the optimal growing conditions found in areas like India, China, Indonesia, and parts of Africa and the Americas.
Chemical_Properties: The primary bioactive compounds in ginger are the gingerols, shogaols, and zingerone. These compounds are responsible for the pungent, spicy flavor and aroma of ginger, as well as its various medicinal properties. Ginger also contains other compounds such as essential oils, vitamins, and minerals.
Morphological_Features: Ginger plants have a distinct appearance with long, narrow leaves that can reach up to 30 cm in length. The leaves are arranged alternately on the stem, and the plant produces small yellow-green flowers. The rhizome, which is the primary edible part, is thick, knobby, and branched, with a pale yellow or white interior.
Medicinal_Value: Ginger has a long history of use in traditional medicine systems, such as Ayurveda and Traditional Chinese Medicine, for its various therapeutic properties. Ginger has been shown to have anti-inflammatory, analgesic (pain-relieving), antioxidant, antimicrobial, and digestive-enhancing effects. It is commonly used to treat conditions like nausea, vomiting, indigestion, arthritis, and respiratory disorders.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Ginger is cultivated in many tropical and subtropical regions around the world, including India, China, Indonesia, Nigeria, Thailand, and parts of the Americas, such as Jamaica and Brazil. These regions provide the warm, humid climate and well-drained soil that ginger requires for optimal growth.

Description: Ginkgo biloba, commonly known as the maidenhair tree, is an ancient gymnosperm species that is the sole surviving member of the Ginkgoaceae family. It is a large, deciduous tree that can grow up to 40 meters tall and has a distinctive fan-shaped leaf structure. Ginkgo biloba is considered a "living fossil" as it has remained virtually unchanged for over 200 million years.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Ginkgo biloba that are used for medicinal and other purposes are the leaves, seeds, and fruits. The leaves contain high concentrations of bioactive compounds like flavonoids and terpene lactones, which are the focus of most research and commercial applications. The seeds and fruits are also used in traditional Chinese medicine, though to a lesser extent than the leaves.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Ginkgo is an adaptable species that can tolerate a wide range of environmental conditions, though it prefers a temperate climate. It can grow in full sun to partial shade and thrives in well-drained, slightly acidic soils. Ginkgo biloba is relatively drought-tolerant but performs best with moderate, consistent moisture. It can withstand cold temperatures down to around -20°C (-4°F) and is hardy in USDA Hardiness Zones 4-9.
Chemical_Properties: The primary bioactive compounds found in Ginkgo biloba are flavonoids (e.g. quercetin, kaempferol, isorhamnetin) and terpene lactones (e.g. ginkgolides, bilobalide). These compounds have been extensively studied for their antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective properties. Ginkgo biloba also contains other secondary metabolites like organic acids, sterols, and proanthocyanidins.
Morphological_Features: Ginkgo biloba has a distinctive fan-shaped leaf structure with dichotomously branching veins. The leaves are bright green in the summer, turning a vibrant yellow in the fall before dropping. The tree has a conical to columnar growth habit with a thick, fissured bark. Ginkgo biloba produces either male or female reproductive structures, with the female trees bearing fleshy, plum-like fruits that contain a single large seed.
Medicinal_Value: Ginkgo biloba has a long history of use in traditional Chinese medicine to treat a variety of conditions, including circulatory disorders, memory loss, and tinnitus. Modern research has focused on the potential therapeutic applications of Ginkgo biloba extracts, which have demonstrated antioxidant, neuroprotective, and vasoactive properties. Standardized Ginkgo biloba extracts are commonly used to treat cognitive impairment and dementia, as well as peripheral vascular disease.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Ginkgo biloba is native to China, where it has been cultivated for thousands of years. It has since been introduced and naturalized in many other parts of the world, including North America, Europe, and Japan. Ginkgo biloba is widely grown as an ornamental and street tree in temperate regions around the globe due to its adaptability and distinctive appearance.

Description: Trollius europaeus, commonly known as the globe flower, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Ranunculaceae family. It typically grows to a height of 30 to 90 cm and features bright yellow, cup-shaped flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of the plant, particularly the flowers and leaves, are used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This species prefers moist, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is typically found in temperate climates with cool summers.
Chemical_Properties: Trollius europaeus contains various phytochemicals, including flavonoids and saponins, which contribute to its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has palmate leaves that are deeply lobed and hairy stems. The flowers are characterized by their numerous yellow petals arranged in a spherical shape.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally, it has been used for its anti-inflammatory and diuretic properties. It is also thought to have potential benefits for digestive health.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Trollius europaeus is native to Europe and can be found in regions such as the Alps, Carpathians, and northern parts of Asia.

Description: Garcinia indica, commonly known as kokum, is a fruit-bearing tree belonging to the Clusiaceae family. This evergreen species is primarily found in the tropical regions of India, particularly in the Western Ghats, encompassing the states of Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, and Kerala. The tree can grow up to 18 meters in height and has a distinctive pyramid shape at maturity. The fruit, which is about the size of an orange, features a purple outer skin and contains five to eight seeds embedded in a tangy pulp.
Parts_Used: Various parts of Garcinia indica are utilized for different purposes. The fruit rind is often dried and used as a souring agent in culinary dishes, particularly in Indian cuisine. The seeds yield kokum butter, which is solid at room temperature and is used in confectionery and cosmetics. The fruit's oily extract is also used in medicinal applications, while the tree itself serves ornamental purposes due to its lush foliage and attractive young leaves.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Garcinia indica thrives in warm and humid tropical climates, preferring coastal regions that receive over 2,500 mm of rainfall annually. It grows well in evergreen forests but can also adapt to areas with lower rainfall. The plant does not require irrigation or the application of pesticides and fertilizers, making it relatively low-maintenance in suitable environments.
Chemical_Properties: The rind of Garcinia indica is a rich source of hydroxycitric acid (HCA), which is known for its potential to modify lipid metabolism. This compound has garnered interest for its possible health benefits, including weight management and appetite suppression. The seeds contain 23-26% kokum butter, which is primarily composed of fatty acids and is used in various industrial applications.
Morphological_Features: Garcinia indica is characterized by its evergreen nature and can reach heights of up to 18 meters. The leaves are dark green and glossy, while the young leaves have a reddish tint. The fruit is a purple berry with a fleshy endocarp, containing several seeds that account for a significant portion of the fruit's weight. The tree exhibits a dense canopy, making it visually appealing in landscapes.
Medicinal_Value: The medicinal applications of Garcinia indica are diverse. The fruit rind is traditionally used in herbal medicine for its anti-inflammatory and digestive properties. It is also employed in treating conditions such as constipation and cough. The oily extract, known as kokum butter, is utilized in skin care products due to its moisturizing properties. Additionally, the fruit is used in various traditional remedies across different cultures.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Garcinia indica is primarily indigenous to India, especially in the Western Ghats. However, it is also found in other tropical regions, including parts of Southeast Asia. The tree has been cultivated in various countries for its culinary and medicinal uses, though it remains most prevalent in India, where it is an integral part of local cuisine and traditional medicine.

Description: Salix caprea, or goat willow, is a deciduous shrub or small tree that can reach heights of 3 to 10 meters. It has coarsely fissured yellowish bark and thick, pubescent twigs.
Parts_Used: The bark is primarily used for medicinal purposes due to its salicin content, which is a precursor to aspirin.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This species prefers moist conditions and typically grows in streamsides and open deciduous forests at altitudes up to 2250 m.
Chemical_Properties: Salix caprea contains salicin, tannins, and flavonoids. Salicin has analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects.
Morphological_Features: Leaves are broadly ovate with a dark green upper surface and a soft grey-tomentose underside. Catkins appear before the leaves in spring.
Medicinal_Value: It has been used traditionally for pain relief and as an anti-inflammatory agent. Its bark extract is utilized in herbal medicine.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Europe and parts of western Asia, it thrives in temperate climates with adequate moisture.

Description: Lycium barbarum, commonly known as goji berry or wolfberry, is a deciduous shrub that can grow up to 3 meters tall. It features small purple flowers and bright red berries.
Parts_Used: The berries are primarily consumed for their nutritional value and medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers well-drained soils and full sunlight. It thrives in arid or semi-arid climates but requires some moisture during the growing season.
Chemical_Properties: Goji berries are rich in antioxidants, vitamins (especially vitamin C), and polysaccharides that contribute to their health benefits.
Morphological_Features: The plant has slender branches with small oval leaves. The berries are elongated and bright red when ripe.
Medicinal_Value: Lycium barbarum is known for its immune-boosting properties and is used in traditional medicine for its potential benefits in enhancing vision and longevity.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to China but now cultivated worldwide, particularly in regions with similar climates such as parts of the United States and Europe.

Plant_Name: Golden root / Arctic root / Rose root
Description: Rhodiola rosea, also known as golden root or Arctic root, is a perennial flowering plant that grows up to 30 cm tall. It has thick roots and fleshy leaves.
Parts_Used: The root is primarily used for its adaptogenic properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant thrives in cold climates with well-drained soils; it prefers rocky or sandy substrates often found at high altitudes.
Chemical_Properties: It contains rosavin, salidroside, and other phenolic compounds known for their adaptogenic effects.
Morphological_Features: Rhodiola rosea features greenish-yellow flowers clustered at the top of the stem. The leaves are thick and succulent-like.
Medicinal_Value: It is reputed for increasing resistance to stress, enhancing physical performance, and improving mood disorders.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Arctic regions of Europe, Asia, and North America; it grows well in mountainous areas with cold climates.

Description: Cassia fistula, known as the golden shower tree, is a large tree reaching heights of up to 10–15 meters. It features long racemes of yellow flowers that bloom in spring.
Parts_Used: The pods contain seeds that are used medicinally; the bark and leaves also have traditional uses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This species prefers tropical climates with well-drained soils; it requires full sunlight for optimal growth.
Chemical_Properties: Cassia fistula contains anthraquinones like cassin which have laxative effects. The pulp of the fruit is rich in sugars and tannins.
Morphological_Features: The tree has compound leaves with numerous leaflets. The flowers are bright yellow with five petals arranged symmetrically.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used as a laxative; it also has potential benefits for liver health and detoxification processes.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to South Asia but widely cultivated across tropical regions including Africa and parts of the Americas.

Description: Hydrastis canadensis, commonly known as goldenseal, is a perennial herbaceous plant that typically grows 10–30 cm tall. It features distinctive yellow rhizomes.
Parts_Used: The rhizome is primarily used for its medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant thrives in rich, moist woodland soils under partial shade; it prefers temperate climates with adequate rainfall.
Chemical_Properties: Hydrastis canadensis contains alkaloids such as berberine which exhibit antimicrobial properties.
Morphological_Features: It has large palmate leaves with a single white flower emerging from the center. The fruit is a cluster of red berries when mature.
Medicinal_Value: Used traditionally for its antibacterial properties; it may also aid digestive health and support immune function.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to North America; it predominantly grows in eastern woodlands but can be cultivated elsewhere under similar conditions.

Plant_Name: Gotu kola / Asiatic pennywort / Sheep-rot / Thankuni / Mandukparni
Description: Centella asiatica, commonly known as gotu kola or Indian pennywort, is a creeping perennial herb that can grow up to 30 cm tall. It features round leaves on long petioles.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts (leaves) are primarily used for culinary and medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers wet environments but can tolerate various soil types; it thrives best in warm tropical climates with partial shade.
Chemical_Properties: Centella asiatica contains triterpenoids such as asiaticoside which promote wound healing and skin regeneration.
Morphological_Features: It has fan-shaped leaves with prominent veins; small white or pink flowers grow on slender stalks above the foliage.
Medicinal_Value: Known for enhancing cognitive function, promoting wound healing, and reducing anxiety; widely used in traditional medicine systems like Ayurveda.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Asia but now cultivated globally in tropical regions due to its adaptability to various environments including wetlands and disturbed areas.

Plant_Name: Granado / Granatapfelbaum / Granatapfelstrauch / Grenadier / Mangrano / Pomegranate / Romanzeiro / Zakuro
Description: Punica granatum, commonly known as the pomegranate, is a deciduous shrub or small tree belonging to the family Lythraceae. It typically grows between 5 to 10 meters tall and is characterized by its multiple spiny branches and long lifespan, with some specimens living for over 200 years. The pomegranate is noted for its attractive trumpet-shaped flowers, which bloom in vibrant orange-red hues throughout the summer and give way to its distinctive fruit, which is round, leathery-skinned, and typically 5 to 12 cm in diameter. The fruit is filled with juicy, edible arils that surround the seeds, making it a popular choice for consumption and culinary uses, such as in jams and syrups like grenadine.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of the pomegranate that are utilized include the fruit, seeds, and juice. The fruit is known for its high antioxidant content and is often consumed fresh or processed into juice. The seeds, which are encased in juicy arils, are also edible and are rich in nutrients. Additionally, the bark and leaves have been used in traditional medicine for their astringent properties. Various extracts from the plant are employed in herbal remedies, particularly for their potential health benefits, including anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Pomegranates thrive in warm, semi-arid climates with long, hot summers and cooler winters. They are best suited for USDA hardiness zones 8 to 11 and prefer well-drained, fertile loamy soils. The ideal temperature for fruit production is above 90°F (32°C). Pomegranates require full sun to flourish, and while they can tolerate moderate frost, excessive moisture can lead to root rot. In regions with less favorable climates, such as those with high humidity, pomegranates may not produce fruit effectively.
Chemical_Properties: The pomegranate fruit is rich in polyphenols, particularly ellagitannins and anthocyanins, which contribute to its antioxidant properties. The juice has a low pH of around 4.4, giving it a sour taste, and is known for its high content of vitamin C, potassium, and dietary fiber. These chemical properties are believed to be responsible for various health benefits, including cardiovascular health support and anti-inflammatory effects. The fruit's pigments, primarily derived from anthocyanins, are also responsible for its deep red color.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, the pomegranate features glossy, narrow oblong leaves that are typically 3 to 7 cm long. The flowers are bright red, measuring about 3 cm in diameter, with three to seven petals. The fruit consists of a hard outer pericarp and a spongy mesocarp that houses the seeds. The seeds are surrounded by a fleshy sarcotesta, which is the edible part of the fruit. Pomegranate trees can develop a sculptural form with twisted trunks and are often used as ornamental plants in gardens due to their attractive flowers and unique fruit.
Medicinal_Value: Pomegranates have been valued in traditional medicine for centuries. They are believed to possess anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antimicrobial properties. Studies suggest that pomegranate extracts may help lower blood pressure, reduce cholesterol levels, and improve heart health. Additionally, the fruit has been linked to potential anticancer effects, particularly in prostate and breast cancers, due to its high levels of bioactive compounds. The juice is also used in various cultures for its health benefits and is often recommended for digestive health.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: The pomegranate is native to regions ranging from southern Europe to northern India and has been cultivated in various parts of the world, including the Mediterranean, the Middle East, and parts of the United States, particularly California and Arizona. It has adapted well to semi-arid climates and is commonly found in regions with hot summers and cool winters. The plant has also been naturalized in other warm climates, making it a widely cultivated fruit globally.

Description: Vitis vinifera, commonly known as the grapevine, is a climbing vine belonging to the Vitaceae family. It can reach lengths of 10 to 40 meters and produces small, self-pollinating flowers. The fruit is typically elliptical or globose, measuring 1.5 to 2 cm in diameter, with variations in color and size depending on the cultivar
Parts_Used: The primary parts utilized include the fruits (grapes), leaves, stems, and seeds. Each part has distinct applications in food, medicine, and cosmetics due to their rich phytochemical conten
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Vitis vinifera thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soil. It requires full sun exposure and is sensitive to frost. Optimal growing conditions include a temperature range of 15-30°C and moderate rainfall
Chemical_Properties: The plant is rich in polyphenols, including flavonoids, catechins, anthocyanins, and stilbenes like resveratrol. These compounds contribute to its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer properties
Morphological_Features: The grapevine features broad leaves with lobed margins, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in clusters, and fruits that vary in color from green to purple or black. The roots are extensive and help anchor the vine while absorbing nutrients
Medicinal_Value: Vitis vinifera exhibits various health benefits including antioxidant effects, cardioprotective properties, anti-diabetic activity, and potential anti-cancer effects. Extracts from different parts of the plant have been studied for their therapeutic applications in managing chronic diseases
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This species is cultivated globally, with significant production in Europe (especially France and Italy), the Americas (California), Australia, and parts of Asia. Approximately 10,000 cultivars exist worldwide

Description: Santolina chamaecyparissus, commonly known as lavender cotton, is a compact, evergreen subshrub native to the Mediterranean region
Parts_Used: The aerial parts, including the leaves and flowers, are the parts most commonly used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: It thrives in hot, sunny, well-drained conditions and tolerates drought and poor, dry soils but avoid excess moisture. It is hardy in USDA Zones 6-9.
Chemical_Properties: It contains volatile oils including camphor, cineole, and pinene which contribute to its medicinal properties  and also contains flavonoids, terpenes, and other polyphenolic compounds with antioxidant activity
Morphological_Features: It is compact, bushy habit growing 0.1-0.5 m tall and 0.5-1 m wide, narrow, silvery-gray, finely dissected leaves that are aromatic when crushed and button-like, bright yellow flower heads up to 2 cm wide, appearing in summer on long stalks
Medicinal_Value: It has demonstrated antimicrobial, antifungal, and anti-inflammatory properties. It is used traditionally to treat digestive issues, as an antiseptic, and for other medicinal purposes
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to the Mediterranean region, including southern Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East and widely cultivated as an ornamental and medicinal plant in temperate climates around the world

Description: Commonly known as burdock, Arctium lappa is a biennial plant characterized by its large leaves and purple flower heads. It can grow up to 2 meters tall and has a thick taproot
Parts_Used: The roots are primarily used for culinary purposes and traditional medicine. The leaves and seeds are also utilized for various health applications
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Burdock prefers well-drained soil with plenty of organic matter. It grows best in full sun to partial shade and requires moderate moisture levels
Chemical_Properties: The root contains inulin, phenolic acids, flavonoids, and tannins which contribute to its medicinal properties such as antioxidant effects
Morphological_Features: It features large heart-shaped leaves that can be up to 60 cm wide and purple thistle-like flowers that bloom from July to September
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for its diuretic properties, burdock root is also known for its ability to detoxify the body and improve skin health due to its antibacterial effects
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Europe and Asia, burdock is now widely distributed across North America as well. It thrives in disturbed areas such as roadsides and fields

Description: Alpinia galanga is a rhizomatous, perennial herb that belongs to the ginger family (Zingiberaceae). It attains a height of about 1.5–2.5 m. The plant has a very prominent and aromatic rhizome that is reddish-brown externally and reddish-white internally.
Parts_Used: The rhizome and seeds of kulanjan are used medicinally and as a spice. The rhizome is the primary part utilized.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Kulanjan requires a humid tropical climate and sandy loam soil for successful cultivation. It can be grown in open sunny areas with sufficient rainfall. With adequate irrigation, it can be cultivated at altitudes up to 1000 m.
Chemical_Properties: Alpinia galanga contains a large number of flavonoids and other compounds that contribute to its medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has leathery leaves that are 30–60 cm long and 10–15 cm wide, glossy on both surfaces, lanceolate in shape, and smooth with white margins. The flowers are greenish-white, about 3 cm long, and occur in dense panicles. The corolla has distinctly clawed lips. Flowering occurs in May and June, while fruiting occurs in August and September. The fruits are orange-red in color.
Medicinal_Value: In Unani medicine, Alpinia galanga is known as 'Khulanjan' and has been used to treat various ailments. The rhizome is carminative, aphrodisiac, febrifuge, and bronchodilator. It expels phlegm, improves voice, and is useful in treating sore throat and respiratory congestion. It is also used for rheumatism. The seeds have similar medicinal properties to the rhizome.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Kulanjan occurs naturally in shady and marshy lands in tropical areas, particularly in South India and Northeast India.

Description: Known as star anise, Illicium verum is an evergreen tree native to northeast Vietnam and South China. It is recognized for its star-shaped fruit containing seeds that have a strong anise flavor
Parts_Used: The fruit (star anise) is primarily used as a spice in cooking and traditional medicine. The essential oil extracted from the fruit is also utilized in perfumery
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers warm climates with high humidity. It thrives in well-drained soil under full sunlight or partial shade
Chemical_Properties: Star anise contains anethole, which gives it its characteristic flavor and aroma. It also possesses antimicrobial properties due to other compounds like shikimic acid
Morphological_Features: The tree can grow up to 10 meters tall with glossy green leaves. Its flowers are small and yellowish-green, followed by star-shaped fruits containing one seed each
Medicinal_Value: Star anise has been traditionally used for digestive issues and has antifungal properties. Its oil is also noted for potential antiviral effects against influenza viruses
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: While native to Asia, it is cultivated in various tropical regions around the world including India, Japan, and parts of the Americas

Description: Commiphora wightii, commonly known as guggul, is a flowering plant in the Burseraceae family. It typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 4 meters. The plant features thin, papery bark and thorny branches, with simple or trifoliate leaves that are ovate and irregularly toothed. Flowers are red to pink with four small petals, and the small round fruit turns red when ripe
Parts_Used: The primary parts used from Commiphora wightii include the gum resin harvested from the bark, leaves, and stems. The resin is known for its medicinal properties and is often processed into extracts like gugulipid
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Commiphora wightii thrives in arid to semi-arid climates. It prefers well-drained soils and can tolerate poor soil conditions. The plant requires full sunlight and is drought-resistant, making it suitable for regions with limited rainfall
Chemical_Properties: The resin of Commiphora wightii contains over a hundred metabolites, including steroidal compounds such as guggulsterone, which has been studied for its potential health benefits. Other notable components include quinic acid and myo-inositol found in the leaves and fruits
Morphological_Features: Commiphora wightii typically reaches up to 4 meters in height. It has a distinct thin, papery bark and leaves that are either simple or trifoliate, often ovate in shape. The plant’s flowers range in color from red to pink and feature four petals. Its fruit is small, round, and becomes red when ripe, marking its maturity.
Medicinal_Value: Commiphora wightii has been used in Ayurvedic medicine for over 3,000 years. Its extracts are believed to have various health benefits, including anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and lipid-lowering properties. Guggulsterone has been studied for its potential role in managing cholesterol levels
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This species is native to western India but has been introduced to other regions such as southern Pakistan and parts of the Middle East. It is cultivated commercially in India and Pakistan due to its medicinal properties

Plant_Name: Guggulu / Indian Bdelium / Mukul myrrh tree
Description: Commiphora mukul, also known as guggul or mukul myrrh tree, is a small tree or shrub that produces a fragrant resin. It typically grows between 1-3 meters tall and has a similar appearance to C. wightii, with thorny branches and papery bark
Parts_Used: The primary parts used include the resin (guggul) obtained from the bark, which is utilized in traditional medicine for its therapeutic properties
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Like C. wightii, C. mukul prefers arid climates with well-drained soils. It thrives in full sunlight and is resistant to drought conditions
Chemical_Properties: The chemical composition of Commiphora mukul includes guggulsterone and other steroidal compounds beneficial for health. The resin contains various bioactive metabolites that contribute to its medicinal uses
Morphological_Features: This plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 meters, characterized by thin, papery bark. Its leaves are either simple or trifoliate, giving it a distinctive appearance. Small, yellowish-white flowers adorn the plant, adding subtle color, while small drupe fruits develop, each containing seeds within. These features collectively define its unique morphology.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used in Ayurvedic medicine, C. mukul is known for its lipid-lowering effects and potential benefits in treating obesity, arthritis, and other inflammatory conditions
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This species is primarily found in India, particularly in Gujarat and Rajasthan, as well as in parts of Pakistan. Its cultivation has increased due to its demand in traditional medicine

Description: Gymnema sylvestre, commonly known as gurmar or sugar destroyer, is a climbing plant native to India. It features broad leaves that are ovate and can grow up to 10 cm long
Parts_Used: The leaves are primarily used for their medicinal properties, often consumed fresh or dried in teas
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant thrives in tropical climates with warm temperatures and requires well-drained soil. It prefers partial shade but can tolerate full sun exposure
Chemical_Properties: The leaves contain gymnemic acids which are responsible for their ability to suppress sugar absorption in the intestines. Other compounds include flavonoids and saponins
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, this plant exhibits a distinct climbing habit, often spreading extensively over nearby structures. Its leaves are broad with an ovate shape, adding lush greenery to its surroundings. The flowers, small and clustered, bloom in shades of white or yellow, providing a delicate contrast and flowering year-round.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for managing diabetes by reducing sugar cravings and absorption. It may also aid in weight loss efforts due to its appetite-suppressing effects
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to India but also found in tropical regions of Africa and Australia where it is cultivated for its medicinal properties

Description: Amaranthus caudatus, commonly known as love-lies-bleeding or tassel flower, is an annual flowering plant belonging to the Amaranthaceae family. It is characterized by its long, drooping inflorescences that can be red, green, or yellow in color. The plant can grow up to 1.5 meters tall and has broad leaves that can reach up to 25 cm in length.
Parts_Used: The leaves, seeds, and stems of Amaranthus caudatus are utilized in various culinary and medicinal applications. The seeds are particularly valued for their high protein content and nutritional value.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Amaranthus caudatus thrives in warm climates and prefers well-drained, fertile soils. It grows best in temperatures ranging from 20°C to 30°C (68°F to 86°F) and can tolerate drought conditions once established.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains several bioactive compounds including flavonoids, phenolic acids, and saponins. Notably, the methanolic extract has shown significant antioxidant activity and α-amylase inhibition properties, indicating potential health benefits such as blood sugar regulation
Morphological_Features: The plant exhibits a robust growth habit with alternate leaves that are ovate to lanceolate. The inflorescences are dense and spike-like, with small flowers that are typically clustered. The seeds are small, round, and can vary in color from black to brown.
Medicinal_Value: Amaranthus caudatus is traditionally used for its medicinal properties including anti-diarrheal, diuretic, and blood-purifying effects. It has also been studied for its potential in treating conditions like jaundice and amoebiasis
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This species is native to South America but is now widely cultivated in Asia (especially India), Africa, and parts of North America due to its adaptability and nutritional value.

Description: Camptotheca acuminata, known as the happy tree or cancer tree, is a deciduous tree native to China. It can grow up to 20 meters tall and features a broad crown with glossy green leaves that turn yellow in autumn.
Parts_Used: The bark, leaves, and seeds are used for medicinal purposes. The most notable compound derived from this tree is camptothecin, extracted from the bark.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This tree prefers a warm climate with well-drained soil. It thrives in USDA hardiness zones 7-9 and requires full sun exposure.
Chemical_Properties: Camptothecin is the primary alkaloid found in C. acuminata and has been extensively studied for its anti-cancer properties, particularly against various types of tumors by inhibiting DNA topoisomerase I
Morphological_Features: The tree has a straight trunk with smooth gray bark. Leaves are lanceolate with a glossy appearance. Flowers are small and fragrant, followed by drupes containing seeds.
Medicinal_Value: Camptothecin has shown effectiveness in cancer treatment, particularly for colorectal cancer. It serves as the basis for several anticancer drugs
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: While native to China, it is cultivated in various tropical and subtropical regions worldwide for its medicinal properties.

Description: Acanthus illicifolius L., commonly known as sea thistle or holly-leaved acanthus, is a perennial herb found primarily in coastal areas. It features spiny leaves that resemble holly.
Parts_Used: The leaves and roots are used traditionally for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers saline conditions typical of coastal marshes and estuaries. It thrives in warm climates with ample sunlight.
Chemical_Properties: Acanthus illicifolius contains various phytochemicals including flavonoids and tannins which contribute to its medicinal properties
Morphological_Features: The plant has large lobed leaves with spiny edges and produces tall flowering spikes adorned with white or purple flowers.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for its anti-inflammatory properties, it has also been studied for potential antimicrobial effects
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: It is primarily found along the coasts of Africa and Asia but can also be found in other tropical regions.

Description: Artocarpus lakoocha, known as the monkey jack or lakoocha fruit tree, is a tropical tree species belonging to the Moraceae family. It can grow up to 30 meters tall.
Parts_Used: The fruit is edible while the bark is used for its medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This species thrives in tropical climates with rich soil and adequate rainfall.
Chemical_Properties: It contains various phytochemicals including flavonoids and tannins which have antioxidant properties
Morphological_Features: The tree features large leaves that are heart-shaped with a leathery texture. Its fruit is round or oval-shaped when mature.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for treating digestive issues and skin ailments due to its antibacterial properties
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Southeast Asia but cultivated in tropical regions around the world.

Description: Corylus avellana, known as the common hazel or filbert tree, is a deciduous shrub or small tree recognized for its edible nuts.
Parts_Used: The nuts (hazelnuts) are widely consumed while the bark has medicinal uses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: It prefers temperate climates with well-drained soil; it thrives best in areas with moderate rainfall.
Chemical_Properties: Hazelnuts are rich in healthy fats, vitamins E and B6, magnesium, copper, manganese, fiber, and antioxidants
Morphological_Features: The shrub has rounded leaves with serrated edges; it produces catkins (flowering spikes) before leafing out in spring.
Medicinal_Value: Hazelnuts have been associated with heart health benefits due to their high unsaturated fat content
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Europe but cultivated globally where temperate conditions prevail.

Description: Conium maculatum, commonly known as poison hemlock, is a biennial herbaceous plant notorious for its toxicity.
Parts_Used: All parts of the plant contain toxic alkaloids but have historically been used for medicinal purposes despite their dangers.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: It thrives in moist soils across a range of climatic conditions but prefers disturbed areas such as roadsides or fields.
Chemical_Properties: The primary alkaloids include coniine which affects the nervous system leading to respiratory failure if ingested
Morphological_Features: Characterized by smooth stems with purple spots; it has feathery leaves resembling those of carrots or parsley.
Medicinal_Value: Historically used as a sedative or muscle relaxant; however, due to its toxicity, it is not recommended for modern use
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Europe but now found throughout North America due to its adaptability to various environments.

Description: Lilium polyphyllum, commonly known as the Himalayan lily, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Liliaceae family. It features multiple narrow, lanceolate leaves that can grow up to 30 cm long, arranged in a rosette at the base of the stem. The flowers are large, trumpet-shaped, and typically white or pale yellow with purple spots.
Parts_Used: The bulbs and flowers are primarily used for medicinal purposes. The bulbs are edible and can be used in traditional dishes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soil. It prefers partial shade to full sunlight and requires regular watering, especially during dry periods.
Chemical_Properties: The bulbs contain various phytochemicals, including flavonoids and alkaloids, which contribute to their medicinal properties.
Morphological_Features: Lilium polyphyllum can reach heights of up to 1.5 meters. The flowers are borne on tall stalks and can be quite fragrant. The leaves are elongated and can be clustered at the base or alternately arranged along the stem.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally, this plant is used for its anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. It is also believed to have diuretic effects and is used in treating respiratory ailments.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to the Himalayan region, particularly found in India, Nepal, and Bhutan, it also grows in other temperate regions with similar climatic conditions.

Plant_Name: Holy thistle / Lady's thistle / Milk thistle
Description: Silybum marianum, commonly known as milk thistle, is an erect annual or biennial herb that can grow up to 2 meters tall. It has shiny green leaves with distinctive white veins and spiny margins. The leaves are noticeably variegated, with white markings covering the upper surface. Solitary purple flower heads, 2.5-5 cm across, develop at the apex of the stems and are enclosed in a projecting, spiny involucre. The fruit are black and brown achenes about 0.3 in. (0.85 cm) long, slightly flattened with a ring of bristles at the apex.
Parts_Used: The parts of Silybum marianum used medicinally are the seeds and fruit. The seeds contain the highest concentration of the active compound silymarin.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Milk thistle is very adaptable to many different growing conditions. It can tolerate a wide range of soil types, from sandy to clay soils, as long as they are well-drained. The plant prefers full sun and warm temperatures. It is mainly confined to high fertility soils and frequently establishes on river flats, sheep camps, around stock yards and other areas with higher than normal soil nitrogen levels, especially if the area has been disturbed.
Chemical_Properties: The main active compound in holy thistle is silymarin, a flavonolignan complex. Silybin, a major component of silymarin, is the most active and well-studied compound. Silybin consists of two main units - a taxifolin unit and a phenylpropanoid unit linked together by an oxeran ring. Silybin has hepatoprotective, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties.
Morphological_Features: Lady's thistle is an erect, annual or biennial herb with a glabrous or slightly downy stem. The plant has a taproot and can grow from 2-6 ft. (0.6-1.8 m) tall. The basal leaves are 6-28 in. (15.2-71.1 cm) long with spiny margins. Much smaller stem leaves clasp the stem. The purple flower heads are solitary at the apex of the stems.
Medicinal_Value: Silybum marianum has been used for thousands of years as a remedy for liver and gallbladder disorders. Silymarin, the extract from the seeds, has been classified by the WHO since the 1970s as an official medicine with hepatoprotective properties. Research has demonstrated silymarin's antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-fibrotic effects on the liver. It is used to treat alcoholic liver disease, cirrhosis, and hepatitis.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: The origins of milk thistle lie in the region of Southern Europe, the Mediterranean and Northern Africa. Its current distribution includes most temperate areas of the world. It is common in the Western U.S. as a weed afflicting pastures, wastelands and irrigation banks. It is believed to have been introduced in cattle feed.

Description: Commonly known as the horse chestnut tree, Aesculus hippocastanum is a large deciduous tree that can grow up to 30 meters tall. It features palmate leaves with five to seven leaflets and produces large white flowers in upright clusters.
Parts_Used: The seeds (conkers), bark, and leaves are utilized for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This tree prefers well-drained soils in temperate climates with ample rainfall. It thrives best in full sun or partial shade.
Chemical_Properties: Contains saponins (aesculin), flavonoids, and tannins which contribute to its therapeutic effects.
Morphological_Features: The tree has a broad crown with thick branches. Its flowers bloom in spring and develop into spiky green seed capsules containing shiny brown seeds.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for treating venous insufficiency and hemorrhoids due to its anti-inflammatory properties. The seeds are also used in homeopathic remedies
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to the Balkans but widely cultivated across Europe and North America as an ornamental tree

Description: Solanum carolinense is a perennial herbaceous plant characterized by spiny stems and yellow star-shaped flowers.
Parts_Used: The berries and roots have been traditionally used for medicinal purposes despite being toxic if consumed improperly
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Thrives in well-drained soils under full sun exposure; it prefers warm temperate climates
Chemical_Properties: Contains alkaloids such as solanine which can be toxic at high concentrations
Morphological_Features: It features spiny foliage with lobed leaves; flowers typically bloom from late spring into summer
Medicinal_Value: Historically used for pain relief; however, caution is advised due to toxicity associated with improper use
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to North America but found across various temperate regions worldwide

Description: Commonly known as field horsetail, Equisetum arvense is a perennial plant characterized by its jointed stems that resemble bamboo. It has no true leaves but features whorls of scale-like structures at each joint.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of the plant are harvested for medicinal use.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Prefers moist soils and can thrive in a variety of conditions including sandy or clay soils. It often grows in disturbed areas or wetlands.
Chemical_Properties: Rich in silica (up to 70%), flavonoids, alkaloids, and other minerals which enhance its health benefits.
Morphological_Features: This plant can reach heights of up to 30 cm with hollow stems that bear small branches at each node. The reproductive structures appear as conical spikes at the top of fertile stems.
Medicinal_Value: Known for its diuretic properties; it is used for kidney ailments and urinary tract infections. Its high silica content also supports bone health
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Found throughout North America, Europe, and Asia in temperate regions

Description: Known as Huang Qi or milk vetch, Astragalus membranaceus is a perennial herb belonging to the Fabaceae family. It features compound leaves with numerous leaflets and produces yellowish flowers.
Parts_Used: The root is primarily used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Thrives in well-drained soils under full sun or partial shade; it prefers temperate climates with moderate rainfall.
Chemical_Properties: Contains polysaccharides (astragalosides), flavonoids, saponins which contribute to its immune-boosting effects
Morphological_Features: Can grow up to 1 meter tall; it has a deep taproot system which helps it access nutrients from deeper soil layers.
Medicinal_Value: Widely recognized for its adaptogenic properties; it enhances immune function and has anti-inflammatory effects
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to China but cultivated globally for herbal medicine applications

Description: Commonly known as hyssop, Hyssopus officinalis is a perennial herb belonging to the Lamiaceae family. It features square stems with opposite leaves that are aromatic when crushed.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of the plant are harvested for medicinal use.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Prefers well-drained soils in sunny locations; it thrives best in temperate climates with moderate rainfall
Chemical_Properties: Contains essential oils (thymol), flavonoids which provide antiseptic properties
Morphological_Features: Typically grows up to 60 cm tall with blue or purple flowers clustered at the top of stems; it blooms from mid-summer through fall.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for respiratory ailments such as coughs and bronchitis; it also has antimicrobial properties
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Europe but widely cultivated around the world for culinary and medicinal uses

Description: Aegle marmelos, commonly known as bael, is a tree belonging to the Rutaceae family. It is characterized by its aromatic leaves and hard, woody fruit. The tree can grow up to 15 meters in height and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions.
Parts_Used: All parts of the bael tree are utilized in traditional medicine, including the leaves, fruit, roots, and bark. The fruit pulp is particularly valued for its medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Bael thrives in warm climates and prefers well-drained soil. It can tolerate drought conditions but requires adequate sunlight for optimal growth. The plant is commonly found in dry lowland areas of India and Southeast Asia
Chemical_Properties: Aegle marmelos contains various bioactive compounds such as alkaloids (aegeline), flavonoids, terpenoids, and coumarins (marmelosin). These compounds contribute to its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial properties
Morphological_Features: The bael tree has a dense crown with trifoliate leaves that are dark green and glossy. The fruit is round to oval-shaped, with a hard shell and a sweet, aromatic pulp that contains numerous seeds
Medicinal_Value: Aegle marmelos is renowned for its medicinal properties, including anti-inflammatory, antidiarrheal, antimicrobial, and antipyretic effects. It is traditionally used to treat digestive disorders, respiratory issues, and skin diseases
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: This plant is predominantly found in India but also grows in other tropical regions such as Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia. It is cultivated for both its fruit and medicinal properties

Plant_Name: Indian Frankincense / Indian Olibanum-Tree / Kundur Luban / Salai / Salai Guggal / Salaki
Description: Boswellia serrata, commonly known as Indian frankincense, is a deciduous tree belonging to the Burseraceae family. It typically reaches heights of 10 to 20 meters and is characterized by its thin, greyish-green to reddish bark that exfoliates in papery flakes. The leaves are long, with 17-27 pairs of leaflets that are oblong-lanceolate in shape, measuring approximately 12-42 cm in length. The flowers are small and white or pinkish, growing in racemes, while the fruit is a drupe containing three pyrenes, each with a single seed
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Boswellia serrata used for medicinal purposes include the resin, bark, and leaves. The resin is particularly valued for its therapeutic properties and is often harvested for use in traditional medicine and aromatherapy
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Salai guggal thrives in specific climatic conditions, with ideal mean annual temperatures ranging from 12°C to 21°C and annual highs between 25°C and 35°C. The tree requires annual rainfall of 500 to 2000 mm, with optimal conditions occurring between 750 and 1500 mm, and benefits from a dry season lasting 6 to 9 months. It can tolerate humidity levels from 40% to 90% and prefers well-draining soils, often found on rocky ridges and hilly slopes, thriving in neutral to slightly acidic or alkaline soils.
Chemical_Properties: The resin of *Boswellia serrata* contains a complex mixture of phytochemicals, primarily comprising boswellic acids, including β-boswellic acid, acetyl-β-boswellic acid, 11-keto-β-boswellic acid, and acetyl-11-keto-β-boswellic acid, which are renowned for their anti-inflammatory properties and their ability to inhibit pro-inflammatory enzymes. Additionally, the resin includes various other compounds such as monoterpenes, diterpenes, triterpenes, glycosides, flavonoids, and phenolic compounds, all of which contribute to its medicinal efficacy.
Morphological_Features: Boswellia serrata is a tree that typically grows between 10 to 20 meters in height. Its bark is thin, greyish-green or reddish, and exfoliates in papery sheets. The leaves consist of multiple pairs of leaflets, featuring a greenish underside, with margins that may be either entire or crenate.
