Chemical_Properties: The roots of Rubia cordifolia contain an anthraquinone called purpurin (1,2,4-Trihydroxyanthraquinone) that gives it its red color when used as a textile dye. The plant also contains alkaloids, which are its major components, and anthraquinones that exhibit various biological activities.
Morphological_Features: Madder is a climbing plant with tiny hooks on its leaves and stems. The roots can be over 1 m long and up to 12 mm thick. The leaves are evergreen, usually lanceolate or ovate, 1.5–4 cm long and 0.5–1.5 cm broad, produced in whorls of 4-8 around the central stem.
Medicinal_Value: In Ayurveda, the roots of manjistha are used as a medicine commonly known as Manjistha. In Traditional Tibetan Medicine, it is known as btsod and is used to treat blood disorders, excess heat in the lungs, kidneys, and intestines, and reduce swelling. The plant also exhibits antimicrobial, antifungal, hypotensive, analgesic, antimalarial, antioxidant, antileukemic and mutagenic properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Rubia cordifolia was extensively cultivated in many regions of Asia, Europe and Africa from antiquity until the mid-nineteenth century. It is found growing naturally in the Bhadra Wildlife Sanctuary in India.

Plant_Name: Madhu Malati / Rangoon Creeper / Burma Creeper / Chinese Honeysuckle / Parijat
Description: Combretum indicum, commonly known as the Rangoon creeper or Burma creeper, is a ligneous vine that can reach from 2.5 to 8 meters in length. The leaves are elliptical with an acuminate tip and a rounded base, growing from 7 to 15 centimeters with an opposite arrangement. The flowers are tubular, consisting of oblong petals 6–8 mm long, fragrant, and have long receptacles to adapt for pollinators with long tongues. They change in color from white to pink to red with age, attracting different pollinators at different stages. The 30 to 35 mm long fruit is dark brown, ellipsoidal, and has five stiff and prominent wings. The seed tastes like almond or coconut when mature.
Parts_Used: The seeds are used for treating roundworm and pinworm infestations.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Combretum indicum is widely cultivated in tropical regions around the world, preferring tropical rainforest climates but also capable of growing in warm temperate climates. It can tolerate a range of soils from medium to heavy and prefers well-drained soils but can withstand cold spells. It has low tolerance for salinity and while it can tolerate partial shade, it prefers full sunlight. The species generally occurs at low elevations near sea level, but in China, it is found in a wide range of habitats from mountains to low rainforests and wastelands, anywhere between elevations of 0-1500 m.
Chemical_Properties: The seeds of this species contain the chemical quisqualic acid, which is an agonist for the AMPA receptor, a kind of glutamate receptor in the brain. The chemical is linked to excitotoxicity (cell death).
Morphological_Features: Combretum indicum is a vigorous climber with stems twining to the left. The flowers open at dusk, are initially white but gradually turn red during the next day, and are short-lived, lasting just three days. The plant blooms all year long in warm regions if the temperature remains high enough and enough water is available.
Medicinal_Value: In tropical Asia, Combretum indicum is considered an important medicinal plant. In the Philippines, the fruits are chewed as a remedy for coughs. The seeds have been used for treating roundworm and pinworm infestations.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Combretum indicum is native to tropical Asia and possibly tropical Africa where it is abundant, but the species is widely cultivated in the Neotropics. It has been cultivated and naturalized in tropical areas such as Burma, Vietnam, and Thailand.

Description: Adiantum capillus-veneris, commonly known as the southern maidenhair fern, is a deciduous, clumping fern with a drooping habit that grows to 12-18" tall and slowly spreads by short creeping rhizomes. It features bipinnate to tripinnate fronds with wiry, black stems that are distinctively arching to pendent. Small pinnae (each to 1/2" long) are fan-shaped, having wedge-shaped bases and irregular lobing at the apex. Sori (spores) appear in summer on the reflexed pinnae undermargins.
Parts_Used: The dried root is indicated as a medicine, and its leaves are used as a remedy for some diseases in throughout the world.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Adiantum capillus-veneris prefers light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils and requires well-drained soil. The plant prefers neutral and basic (alkaline) soils. It can grow in semi-shade (light woodland) and requires moist soil.
Chemical_Properties: Both crude extracts and extracted phenols of gametophytes and different parts of Adiantum capillus-veneris have demonstrated a spectrum of biological activities. Some of the identified chemical constituents include flavonoids such as kaempferol-3-sulfate and shikimic acid.
Morphological_Features: Adiantum capillus-veneris has a long history of medicinal use and was the main ingredient of a popular cough syrup called 'Capillaire', which remained in use until the nineteenth century. It is used in folk medicine in parts of the world to cure menstrual disorders, cold, cough, abdominal pain, fever, headache, bronchitis, hair loss, and diabetes. The plant is also used for blood cleansing, coughs, and as a diuretic.
Medicinal_Value: Adiantum capillus-veneris has a long history of medicinal use and was the main ingredient of a popular cough syrup called 'Capillaire', which remained in use until the nineteenth century. It is used in folk medicine in parts of the world to cure menstrual disorders, cold, cough, abdominal pain, fever, headache, bronchitis, hair loss, and diabetes. The plant is also used for blood cleansing, coughs, and as a diuretic.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Adiantum capillus-veneris is native throughout the world in tropical to temperate regions including South America, Europe, Asia and Africa. In the U.S., it is uncommonly found throughout the southern states north to California, South Dakota and Ohio. It is also found in the southern half of the United States from California to the Atlantic coast, through Mexico and Central America.

Description: Ziziphus oenoplia is a spiny shrub or small tree that can grow up to 10 meters tall. It features alternate, simple leaves that are ovate to elliptic in shape, typically measuring 2-7 cm in length. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that are clustered in axillary racemes, followed by small, fleshy fruits that turn reddish-brown when ripe. The fruit is edible and has been used traditionally for its nutritional benefits
Parts_Used: Various parts of makai are utilized for medicinal purposes: the leaves are valued for their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, the fruits are consumed for their nutritional value and potential health benefits, and the bark is employed in traditional medicine for its astringent qualities.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Makai thrives in warm, tropical climates. It prefers well-drained soils and can tolerate drought conditions, making it suitable for arid regions. The plant requires full sunlight for optimal growth but can also adapt to partial shade
Chemical_Properties: The phytochemical profile of *Ziziphus oenoplia* features several bioactive compounds, including alkaloids, which are recognized for their analgesic and anti-inflammatory properties; flavonoids, known for their antioxidant effects; and tannins, which contribute to its astringent qualities. These compounds have been associated with various pharmacological activities, notably antibacterial and antifungal effects.
Morphological_Features: Ziziphus oenoplia is characterized by several distinct morphological features. It possesses sharp thorns on its branches, offering protection against herbivores. The plant has glossy green leaves with a smooth texture. Additionally, it produces small flowers that develop into fleshy fruits, serving as an important food source for local wildlife.
Medicinal_Value: Ziziphus oenoplia has been traditionally utilized across cultures for its medicinal properties. It is recognized for promoting digestive health by treating diarrhea and other gastrointestinal issues, while its leaves and bark exhibit anti-inflammatory effects, effectively reducing inflammation. Additionally, the fruits of Ziziphus oenoplia are rich in vitamins and minerals, further enhancing overall health.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Ziziphus oenoplia is predominantly found in tropical regions across Africa, Asia, and parts of Australia. It is commonly cultivated in countries like India, where it is valued both as a food source and for its medicinal applications. The plant's resilience allows it to thrive in diverse environments, particularly in areas with low rainfall.

Description: Justicia adhatoda is a shrub with 10-20 lance-shaped leaves, 8-9 centimeters in length by four wide. The leaves are oppositely arranged, smooth-edged, and borne on short petioles. When dry, they are of a dull brownish-green color. The leaves are bitter-tasting. The trunk has many long opposite ascending branches, where the bark is yellowish in color. Flowers are usually white and the inflorescence shows large, dense, axillary spikes. Fruits are pubescent, and are with club-shaped capsules.
Parts_Used: The whole plant of Justicia adhatoda is used medicinally. The leaves, flowers, and stems are used in various traditional preparations and formulations.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Justicia adhatoda requires a lot of sunlight, at least 4 hours of sunlight per day. It also requires less water and can grow in a variety of climatic and soil conditions. Alluvial soils are suited for best growth, and it can also be cultivated as an intercrop in coconut and rubber plantations.
Chemical_Properties: The leaves of malabur nut contain phytochemicals such as alkaloids, tannins, saponins, phenolics, and flavonoids. The most important chemical is vasicine, a quinazoline alkaloid. The vasicine yield of the herbage has been measured as 0.541 to 1.1% by dry weight. Bromhexine, a serine protease inhibitor with mucolytic properties, was originally derived from Justicia adhatoda.
Morphological_Features: The plant has oval stomata surrounded by two crescent-shaped cells at right angles to the ostiole. The epidermis bears simple one- to three-celled warty hairs, and small glandular hairs. Cystoliths occur beneath the epidermis of the underside of the blade.
Medicinal_Value: Malabar nut is used in Ayurvedic medicine to treat respiratory tract disorders such as asthma, bronchitis, and cough. It is also used for its antitussive, bronchodilatory, cardioprotective, abortifacient, and antimicrobial effects. The plant's active compounds vary with geographical locations and altitude, affecting its efficacy in different biological activities.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Justicia adhatoda is native to Afghanistan, the Indian subcontinent (Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka), Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam. It has been introduced elsewhere.

Description: Malva sylvestris is a flowering plant belonging to the Malvaceae family. It is an annual or perennial herb that can grow up to 1 meter tall. The leaves are heart-shaped with 5-7 lobes and the flowers are large, pink with purple lines.
Parts_Used: The leaves and flowers are the most commonly used parts of Malva sylvestris. They are a rich source of phytochemical compounds and have numerous health benefits.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Mallow plant prefers to grow in moist areas near oceans, swamps, canals, waterways, and meadows. It is found worldwide as a weed and is native to North Africa, Southwest Asia, and South Europe.
Chemical_Properties: Mallow contains various bioactive compounds including malvin, malonylmalvin, the naphthoquinone malvone A, organic acids like malonate, malate, oxalate, fumarate, and citrate, and flavonoids like quercetin and kaempferol.
Morphological_Features: The leaves are simple, membranous, pubescent and velvety on both sides with long petioles. They have 3, 5, 7, or 9 shallow lobes and are palmar and orbicular to kidney-shaped. The venation is actinidrome with prominent and straight first-order veins.
Medicinal_Value: Mallow has been used traditionally to treat various ailments like coughs, colds, diarrhea, dysentery, hypertension, and skin diseases. Modern research has shown it has anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, wound-healing, immunomodulatory, antimicrobial and hepatoprotective properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Malva sylvestris is found worldwide, including North Africa, Europe, Asia, Australia, North and South America. Major areas of growth include Northeast and Central Iran, Siberia, Macaronesia, and the Mediterranean region.

Description: Mangifera indica, commonly known as mango, is a large evergreen tree that can grow up to 20 meters tall with a dark green, umbrella-shaped crown. The trunk is stout, up to 90 cm in diameter, with brown, smoothish bark that becomes darker, rough, and scaly or furrowed with age. The leaves are alternate, simple, and glabrous, with an acute apex and entire margin.
Parts_Used: The mango plant parts commonly used include the leaves, fruit, seeds, kernel, and bark.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Mangoes require a tropical or subtropical climate with a pronounced dry season to produce fruit. They can tolerate a wide range of rainfall patterns but are sensitive to frost and require temperatures above 20°C for growth and fruiting.
Chemical_Properties: Mangiferin, a pharmacologically active hydroxylated xanthone C-glycoside, is extracted from mango at high concentrations in the young leaves (172 g/kg), bark (107 g/kg), and old leaves (94 g/kg). The fruit peel also contains allergenic urushiols.
Morphological_Features: Mango is an irregular, egg-shaped fruit that is a fleshy drupe typically 8–12 cm long and greenish yellow in color. The interior flesh is bright orange and soft with a large, flat pit in the middle. The skin and pulp account for 85% of the mango's weight, and the remaining 15% comes from the stone (seed).
Medicinal_Value: Mango plant parts are reportedly used in ethnomedicine globally for the treatment of various diseases. Mango extracts possess antimicrobial properties and can be used in antimicrobial formulations.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Mangoes are originated from the region between northwestern Myanmar, Bangladesh, and northeastern India. They are now widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide, including India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Southeast Asia, South America, Central America, the Caribbean, and Africa.

Description: Althaea officinalis, commonly known as Marsh Mallow, is a species of flowering plant indigenous to Europe, Western Asia, and North Africa. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is a herbaceous perennial that grows to a height of 60-150 cm. The plant has soft, stellate-hairy leaves that are broadly triangular to oval, often with 3-5 shallow lobes, irregularly toothed, with cordate to cuneate bases. The leaves are present only in summer and fall in winter. The flowers are pinkish-white, bloom from July to September, and consist of 5 petals with a purple-colored center. The plant is upright and somewhat broad, with minimal branching.
Parts_Used: The parts of the Marsh Mallow plant used in herbalism and culinary applications include the leaves, roots, and flowers. The roots are particularly prized for their medicinal properties and are used to make herbal teas and other preparations. The leaves and flowers are also edible and can be used in salads or as a garnish.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Marsh mallow prefers moist, sandy soil with a constant water supply. It can tolerate occasional dry spells but does not thrive in drought or ongoing dry, hot conditions. The plant requires full sun and can grow in almost any conditions, from marshy areas to arid regions. It is hardy in coastal and relatively mild, sheltered parts of the UK, and can survive temperatures as low as -15°C to -20°C.
Chemical_Properties: The Marsh Mallow plant contains mucilaginous compounds, which are responsible for its soothing and healing properties. These compounds are present in the roots, leaves, and flowers. The roots are also rich in starch, which can be extracted to make a thick syrup or used as glue. The plant's essential oil is also used in skincare products for its ability to soothe, hydrate, and soften the skin
Morphological_Features: Althaea officinalis, commonly known as marshmallow plant, has several distinctive morphological features. The leaves are soft and covered with stellate hairs, broadly triangular to oval in shape, and have 3-5 shallow lobes with irregularly toothed edges. The base of the leaves can be either cordate or cuneate. The plant produces pinkish-white flowers with five petals and a purple-colored center, blooming from July to September. The roots are long, thick, tough, and have a mucilaginous texture.
Medicinal_Value: Marsh Mallow has been used for thousands of years to treat respiratory, skin, and digestive conditions. The roots are used to make herbal teas and other preparations that soothe and heal various ailments. The plant's mucilaginous compounds help to reduce inflammation and provide relief from irritation. It is also used to treat urinary tract complaints and soothe sore gums in teething children.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Althaea officinalis is native to Europe, Western Asia, and North Africa. It can grow in a variety of climates, including cold, temperate, subtropical, and tropical regions. It is found in humid and marshy places, as well as in arid regions. The plant is well-suited to grow in moist and well-draining soil, with a pH range of 6.0-7.5.

Description: Chenopodium ambrosioides, also known as Mexican tea or wormseed, is an annual or perennial herb native to tropical America. It is a flowering plant in the family Amaranthaceae. The plant grows up to 1 meter tall and has alternate, oblong-lanceolate leaves with toothed margins. The small greenish-yellow flowers are clustered in spikes at the ends of the stems.
Parts_Used: The entire plant, including the leaves, stems, and seeds, can be used medicinally. The essential oil extracted from the seeds is the most commonly used part.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Chenopodium ambrosioides thrives in warm, humid climates and can tolerate a wide range of soil types. It prefers well-drained, nutrient-rich soil and full sun exposure.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains several bioactive compounds, including ascaridole, limonene, and carvacrol. Ascaridole is the main active ingredient and has potent anthelmintic (anti-worm) properties.
Morphological_Features: The plant has a strong, pungent odor due to the essential oils present in the foliage. The leaves are oblong-lanceolate in shape with toothed margins, and the small greenish-yellow flowers are clustered in spikes at the ends of the stems.
Medicinal_Value: Chenopodium ambrosioides has been used traditionally to treat various ailments, including intestinal worms, respiratory infections, and skin conditions. The essential oil extracted from the seeds is the most commonly used medicinal part and has been shown to have anthelmintic, antibacterial, and antifungal properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Chenopodium ambrosioides is native to tropical America but has naturalized in many parts of the world, including North America, Europe, Africa, and Asia. It thrives in warm, humid climates and can be found in disturbed areas, roadsides, and waste places.

Description: Albizia julibrissin is a deciduous tree known for its feathery pink flowers resembling silk threads. It can grow up to 15 meters tall.
Parts_Used: The bark, leaves, and flowers are commonly used for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This tree prefers warm climates with well-drained soils. It thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade.
Chemical_Properties: Contains compounds such as flavonoids, which exhibit antioxidant properties.
Morphological_Features: The tree has a broad canopy with bipinnate leaves that give it a fern-like appearance. Flowers bloom in summer months.
Medicinal_Value: Albizia julibrissin has been used traditionally for its calming effects on the nervous system and potential anti-anxiety properties
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to Asia, it is now grown in many temperate regions worldwide including parts of North America

Description: Aconitum carmichaelii, known as monkshood or wolfsbane, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Ranunculaceae family. It can grow between 60-120 cm tall.
Parts_Used: The roots are the main parts utilized for medicinal purposes due to their potency.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers cool climates with rich, moist soils. It thrives in shaded areas but can tolerate some sunlight.
Chemical_Properties: Aconitum carmichaelii contains alkaloids such as aconitine, which are highly toxic but possess analgesic properties when used correctly.
Morphological_Features: The plant has distinctive hood-shaped flowers that are usually blue or purple and palmate leaves with deeply lobed segments.
Medicinal_Value: Despite its toxicity, it has been used in traditional medicine for pain relief and treating fevers; however, caution is advised due to its potential toxicity.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: It is native to East Asia but can be found in temperate regions of Europe as well

Description: Artemisia vulgaris, commonly known as mugwort, is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family Asteraceae. It is a herbaceous perennial plant that can grow up to 2.5 m tall and has a width of 75 cm. The plant has a thick main root and many small, fibrous lateral roots that remain in the upper layer of the soil at a depth of 7–18 cm. The stems are slightly wavy, straight, or branched, with a brown color at the lower end that becomes woody with age. The leaves are 5–10 cm long, set densely and alternately, primarily in the upper parts of the stem. The lower leaves have short petioles and are divided into segments, taking on a feathery shape, while the middle and upper ones are smaller and single or double pinnate. The dorsal side of the leaves has a dark green color, while the ventral side is whitish and tomentose.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of A. vulgaris—Artemisiae vulgaris herba—are usually used as a pharmaceutical raw material, while the roots—Artemisiae vulgaris radix—harvested in early winter, are less frequently used.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Mugwort plant is a very common plant growing on low-nitrogen soils, such as waste places, roadsides and other weedy and uncultivated areas. It prefers temperate climates and grows well in areas with moderate rainfall.
Chemical_Properties: A. vulgaris houses a variety of phytochemicals which are responsible for its pharmacological properties. The phytochemicals belong to classes including flavonoids, essential oils, phenolic acids, coumarins, sterols, carotenoids, vitamins, and sesquiterpene lactones. Examples of the phytochemicals include vulgarin, artemisinin, scopoletin, camphene, camphor, sabinene, and some derivatives of quercetin and kaempferol.
Morphological_Features: Mugwort plant is characterized by having pinatissect or bipinatissectas leaves, with lanceolate or oblong segments, soft, white‐silver dorsally. The aerial parts, roots, and other parts of the plant have a characteristic intense aroma that is readily released when the leaves are crushed.
Medicinal_Value: Historically, A. vulgaris has been widely used in traditional Chinese, European, and Hindu medicine. It possesses a wide range of supposed pharmacological uses, including anticancer, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, hepatoprotective, antispasmolytic, antinociceptive, antibacterial, antihypertensive, antihyperlipidemic, and antifungal properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: A. vulgaris is native to temperate Europe, Asia, North Africa, and Alaska, and is naturalized in North America, where some consider it an invasive weed.

Description: Terminalia chebula, commonly known as Haritaki or Chebulic Myrobalan, is a deciduous tree belonging to the Combretaceae family. It is native to South Asia and is widely recognized for its medicinal properties and use in traditional Ayurvedic medicine. The tree can grow up to 30 meters tall, characterized by its smooth bark and oval leaves that are arranged alternately. The fruit of Terminalia chebula is a drupe, typically yellow to brown when ripe, and is known for its astringent taste.
Parts_Used: The fruit of haritaki contains several bioactive compounds, including tannins, flavonoids, and phenolic acids. The primary active constituents are chebulagic acid, known for its antioxidant properties; gallic acid, which exhibits anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial effects; and tannins, which contribute to its astringent taste and offer various health benefits. These compounds are responsible for the medicinal value of the plant, particularly in promoting digestive health and detoxification.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Terminalia chebula thrives in warm tropical and subtropical climates. It prefers well-drained sandy or loamy soils and can tolerate drought conditions. Ideal temperature ranges for its growth are between 25°C to 35°C. The tree requires moderate rainfall, ideally between 750 mm to 1500 mm annually, and does best in areas with a distinct dry season to promote fruit ripening.
Chemical_Properties: The fruit of haritaki contains several bioactive compounds, including tannins, flavonoids, and phenolic acids. The primary active constituents are chebulagic acid, known for its antioxidant properties; gallic acid, which exhibits anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial effects; and tannins, which contribute to its astringent taste and offer various health benefits. These compounds are responsible for the medicinal value of the plant, particularly in promoting digestive health and detoxification.
Morphological_Features: Terminalia chebula is a tree that can grow up to 30 meters in height. It has simple, elliptical leaves that are glossy green and measure between 5 to 15 cm in length. The tree produces small, yellowish-white flowers that appear in axillary spikes. The fruits are small, round drupes about 2 to 4 cm in diameter, which change color from green to yellowish-brown as they ripen.
Medicinal_Value: Haritaki is highly esteemed in Ayurvedic medicine for its wide array of health benefits. It serves as a digestive aid, helping to alleviate constipation and enhance overall digestive health. The fruit is known for its potent antioxidant properties, which protect cells from oxidative stress. Additionally, Haritaki exhibits anti-inflammatory effects, making it useful in reducing inflammation and pain. Its antimicrobial activity is effective against various pathogens, making it beneficial for treating infections. Often referred to as a "superfruit," Haritaki is celebrated for its extensive range of health advantages.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Terminalia chebula is predominantly found in several regions across South and Southeast Asia. In India, it is particularly prevalent in the Himalayan region and the southern states. In Nepal, it commonly grows in the Terai region, while in Bangladesh, it can be found in various forested areas. Sri Lanka provides a habitat for Terminalia chebula in both dry and moist deciduous forests. Additionally, this species is found in Southeast Asia, including countries like Thailand and Myanmar. The adaptability of Terminalia chebula to various climatic conditions allows it to thrive across these diverse regions, contributing significantly to local ecosystems and traditional medicine practices.

Description: Caesalpinia decapetala is a climbing shrub or small tree characterized by bright yellow flowers that bloom in clusters.
Parts_Used: The bark and seeds are commonly utilized for medicinal purposes.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This plant prefers warm climates with adequate rainfall but can tolerate drought conditions once established
Chemical_Properties: Contains various phytochemicals including flavonoids that may have antioxidant effects
Morphological_Features: It features compound leaves with leaflets arranged oppositely along the stem. The flowers have five petals with a distinct yellow color
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally used for its anti-inflammatory properties and potential use in treating skin ailments
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to tropical Asia but found in various regions including Africa and South America due to its ornamental value

Description: Cyperus rotundus, commonly known as purple nutsedge or nut grass, is a perennial sedge native to Africa, southern and central Europe, and southern Asia. It can grow up to 140 cm (55 in) tall and has a triangular stem that branches into three antenna-like stems with purple seedpods. The plant dies back to the ground in fall and new shoots emerge in spring from underground tubers.
Parts_Used: The tubers, rhizomes, and leaves of C. rotundus are used. The tubers are nut-like in appearance and are a staple carbohydrate in tropical regions. They are also used homeopathically.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Nutgrass grows best in wet sites, prefers warm weather and full sun conditions, but will grow in a diversity of sites and environments. It is particularly resistant to drought. The plant grows all year if the soil is moist, and emergence of young plants starts at the beginning of the rainy season. It prefers sunny and humid areas and cannot tolerate shading or competition from other species.
Chemical_Properties: Several chemical substances have been identified in nut grass, including cadalene, cyprotene, flavonoids, sesquiterpenes, terpenoids, mustakone, isocyperol, α-cyperone, rotundene, valencene, kaempferol, luteolin, quercetin, patchoulenone, isopatchoulenone, sugeonyl acetate, cellulose triacetate and sugebiol. A sesquiterpene called rotundone, originally extracted from the tuber, is responsible for the spicy aroma of black pepper and the peppery taste of certain Australian Shiraz wines.
Morphological_Features: Purple nutsedge  has leaves that sprout in ranks of three from the base of the plant, around 5–20 cm (2–8 in) long. The flower stems have a triangular cross-section, and the flower is bisexual with three stamina and a three-stigma pistil. The inflorescence has three to eight unequal spikes, and the fruit is a three-angled achene. The plant has fibrous roots that branch prolifically, rhizomes, tubers, bulbs, and irregular compound umbel inflorescences.
Medicinal_Value: Extracts from the leaves and tubers of nutgrass have been shown to increase adventitious rooting in different plant species. These extracts contain a large amount of auxins and phenolic compounds that promote the rooting of cuttings and seedlings. The tubers have nutritional value and were eaten by humans between Mesolithic and Neolithic periods.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: C. rotundus is found in more than 90 countries, infesting at least 52 different crops. It is prevalent in damp areas but well-drained. The species is extremely common in the Comoros Islands, French Guiana, Mauritius, Mayotte, New Caledonia, Reunion, and the Seychelles. It is also widespread in the West Indies.

Description: Anemone narcissiflora, commonly known as the Narcissus Anemone, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Ranunculaceae family. It features lobed leaves and produces white or pale yellow flowers that resemble those of daffodils.
Parts_Used: The whole plant is utilized for medicinal purposes; however, caution is advised due to its toxic properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: This species prefers cool climates and well-drained soils. It thrives in partial shade and can tolerate a range of soil types.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains toxic alkaloids that can be harmful if ingested.
Morphological_Features: This plant typically reaches a height of 15–30 cm and is recognized for its basal, lobed leaves. The flowers, usually white or pale yellow, have a distinct cup shape, adding to the plant's unique aesthetic.
Medicinal_Value: While some cultures use this plant for its supposed medicinal properties, it is primarily recognized for its toxicity.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Anemone narcissiflora is found primarily in temperate regions of Europe and Asia, particularly in alpine areas.

Description: Azadirachta indica, commonly known as neem, is a fast-growing evergreen tree that can reach a height of 15-20 m, occasionally up to 35-40 m. It has a fairly dense, roundish or oval crown that may reach a diameter of 15-20 m in old, free-standing specimens. The tree has a woody, thick, furrowed bark, attractive rounded crowns, evergreen and broad compound leaves, small fragrant white and bisexual flowers, and small, smooth, yellow-green fruits with a sweet-flavoured pulp.
Parts_Used: Nearly all parts of the neem tree are useful, including the leaves, bark, fruits, seeds, oil, and twigs. The seeds are the source of neem oil, while the leaves, bark, and twigs have various medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Neem is a hardy tree that can tolerate a wide range of environmental conditions, except for freezing temperatures. It grows well in poor and rocky soils and is resilient to drought. Neem can be produced from seed and can also be propagated from cuttings or root suckers.
Chemical_Properties: Neem contains a complex of various constituents, including nimbin, nimbidin, nimbolide, and limonoids. These ingredients play a role in disease management through the modulation of various genetic pathways and other activities. Quercetin and ß-sitosterol, two polyphenolic flavonoids, were first purified from fresh neem leaves and are known to have antifungal and antibacterial activities.
Morphological_Features: The opposite, simple pinnate leaves are 20-40 cm long, with 20-31 medium to dark green leaflets about 3-8 cm long. The leaf stalks (petioles) are short. Very young leaves are reddish to purplish in color. Azadirachta indica is sometimes confused with closely related species of Melia, but the two genera can be distinguished by leaf and ovary morphology.
Medicinal_Value: Neem has numerous therapeutic implications and is used to treat various diseases. It has antibacterial, antifungal, anti-inflammatory, antiarthritic, antipyretic, hypoglycemic, antigastric ulcer, and antitumor activities. Neem leaves have been used as a traditional treatment for diabetes, and there is some clinical evidence suggesting that it may help control blood sugar levels.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Azadirachta indica is native to the Indian subcontinent and parts of Southeast Asia but has been widely introduced elsewhere in tropical and subtropical regions, from South America to Indonesia. It is considered invasive in parts of Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda, where it is a serious problem along parts of the Kenyan and Tanzanian coasts and is spreading rapidly.

Description: Avena sativa, commonly known as oat, is a species of cereal grain that belongs to the Poaceae family. It is an annual grass that can grow up to 1.2 meters tall. Oat plants begin forming their generative parts, blossoming and bearing fruit at temperatures between 10 to 12°C, with the most active processes occurring at 16 to 22°C.
Parts_Used: The seeds of the oat plant are commonly harvested when a milky liquid can be squeezed from the seed pods. The green herb oats have been cultivated for over 4,000 years.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Oats are most demanding cultivated variety of this crop as regards daylight duration. Northern cultivars need longer daylight for their development than southern ones. With 14 hours of daylight, they do not head. The vegetation period of Russian cultivars lasts for 75 to 120 days. Optimal conditions for growing oat are in soils ranging from loam to clay loam with adequate drainage. Light or heavy soils that are properly moist are also suitable. Oats can tolerate low-nutrient and acid soils.
Chemical_Properties: Oat grain, oat bran, and oatmeal contain soluble dietary fiber known as β-glucan, which can lower total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels in the blood. It is also useful for controlling blood sugar levels. Oats contain nutrients like fiber, vitamins, and minerals. Steroidal glycosides from the aerial parts of Avena sativa L. have been found to have cytotoxic activity.
Morphological_Features: Oat plants grow thickly and vigorously, allowing them to outcompete many weeds. Compared to other cereals, they are relatively free from diseases.
Medicinal_Value: Oats have been proven in tests to be a possible agent for preventing the onset and progression of cancer, intestinal malfunction, obesity, celiac disease, and other disorders. They can help treat nervous disorders, insomnia, reproductive issues, depression, obesity, and more.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Oat has the largest natural habitat of all the known species, encompassing Europe (except the Mediterranean coasts), North and Southeast Asia. It is cultivated in North and South America, Africa, Australia, Tasmania, and New Zealand. Oat occupies a prominent position among grain and forage crops in Australia. Large areas are sown with oat plants in North America (the USA and Canada) and in some European countries (Poland, Germany, Sweden, Spain, France, Finland). In Russia, oat plants are cultivated from the northern limits of feasible agriculture to the subtropics in the South, with the bulk of the lands sown located in Non-chernozem areas, in the Urals, in Siberia, and in the Far East.

Description: Olea europaea, commonly known as the olive tree, is a small evergreen tree belonging to the Oleaceae family. It is renowned for its edible fruit, the olive, which has been cultivated for thousands of years, particularly in the Mediterranean region. The tree typically grows to a height of 8 to 15 meters and features a thick trunk with multiple branches. Its leaves are leathery, oppositely arranged, and have a distinctive silvery-green color. The olive tree is notable for its longevity, often living for over a thousand years, and is adapted to thrive in arid conditions.
Parts_Used: The olive tree is highly valued for its various parts, each serving a unique purpose. The fruit, known as olives, is essential for oil production and is also consumed as table olives. Olive leaves possess medicinal properties and are often used in traditional remedies. Additionally, the wood from the olive tree is dense and durable, making it an excellent material for furniture and crafts.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Olea europaea thrives in a Mediterranean climate characterized by warm, dry summers and cool, wet winters. It is well-suited to regions with average annual temperatures between 10°C and 30°C. The tree requires well-distributed rainfall, ideally between 400 to 800 mm annually, with a dry period during the summer. Olive trees prefer well-drained, sandy loam soils, although they can tolerate poor and rocky soils.
Chemical_Properties: Olives and olive oil are notable for their rich chemical composition. They are particularly abundant in monounsaturated fatty acids, with oleic acid comprising 55-83% of the fatty acid content. In addition to their healthy fats, olives contain phenolic compounds, which act as antioxidants and contribute to their health benefits. Furthermore, olives are a valuable source of vitamins E and K, essential for various bodily functions.
Morphological_Features: The olive tree exhibits several distinct morphological characteristics. It typically reaches a height ranging from 3 to 12 meters. The leaves are dark green on the upper side and silvery beneath, measuring between 4 to 10 cm in length. The tree produces small, whitish flowers that bloom in late spring, arranged in clusters. The fruit, known as an olive, is a drupe usually 1 to 2.5 cm long, changing color from green to black as it ripens.
Medicinal_Value: Olea europaea, commonly known as the olive tree, possesses significant medicinal properties. Olive oil, derived from the fruit, is renowned for its benefits to heart health, particularly its ability to improve cardiovascular function and lower cholesterol levels. Additionally, the phenolic compounds found in olives exhibit anti-inflammatory effects, which can help reduce inflammation in the body. Olives are also rich in antioxidants, which are crucial for combating oxidative stress. Beyond these benefits, olive leaves have been traditionally used in herbal medicine for their potential to enhance immune function and promote relaxation.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Olea europaea, commonly known as the olive tree, is predominantly found in the Mediterranean region. However, its cultivation has expanded globally, making it an important agricultural product in various parts of the world. The Mediterranean Basin remains the primary region for olive production, with countries like Spain, Italy, Greece, and Turkey being major producers. In North America, California is notable for its significant olive oil industry. South America also has a presence in olive cultivation, particularly in Argentina and Chile. Additionally, Australia and South Africa have developed olive farming industries, benefiting from suitable climatic conditions.

Description: Citrus sinensis, commonly known as sweet orange, is an evergreen flowering tree native to Asia. It typically grows 9-10 m tall with large spines on its branches. The leaves are alternate, with narrowly winged petioles (3-5 mm wide, 6.5-15 cm long) and elliptical to oval blades that emit a strong citrus odor due to the presence of oil glands. The flowers are axillary, borne singly or in whorls of 6, with five white petals and 20-25 yellow stamens. The fruit is globose to oval (6.5 to 9.5 cm wide) and ripens to orange or yellow. Anatomically, the fruit consists of the pericarp (peel, skin or rind) and the endocarp or pulp with juice sac glands.
Parts_Used: The sweet orange fruit is commonly used for its juicy pulp and aromatic peel (rind). The flowers, leaves, and wood of the tree also have various uses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Sweet orange trees are sensitive to frost and have adapted to a variety of climates. They thrive in warm, subtropical regions with well-distributed rainfall throughout the year.
Chemical_Properties: Sweet orange fruit and leaves contain indole alkaloids, including N,N-DMT. The peel is rich in essential oils, flavonoids, carotenoids, steroids, terpenoids, alkane groups, and ethyl esters. The fruit is also a good source of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants such as ascorbic acid, flavonoids, and phenolic compounds.
Morphological_Features: The sweet orange tree is an evergreen with large spines on its branches. The leaves are alternate, with narrowly winged petioles and elliptical to oval blades that emit a strong citrus odor. The flowers are axillary, with five white petals and 20-25 yellow stamens. The fruit is globose to oval and ripens to orange or yellow.
Medicinal_Value: Sweet orange has numerous medicinal properties, including antioxidant, antibacterial, antidiabetic, antifungal, antiosteoporosis, hypocholesterolemic, and antiobesity effects, due to its phytochemical composition. The peel is rich in protein (7.15%) and crude fiber (12.79%), which can be used as ingredients in processed food.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Sweet orange trees are widely cultivated in warm, subtropical regions around the world, including Asia, the Pacific, and warm areas of the Americas. They are the largest citrus cultivar group, accounting for about 70% of the total annual production of Citrus species.

Description: Origanum vulgare, commonly known as oregano, is a perennial herb belonging to the mint family, Lamiaceae. It is renowned for its aromatic leaves and is a staple in Mediterranean cuisine. The plant typically grows to a height of 20 to 80 cm (8 to 31 inches) and features opposite, oval leaves that are covered with glandular trichomes, giving them a distinctive texture. The flowers, which bloom in summer, can be white, pink, or light purple and are borne in clusters.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Origanum vulgare that are utilized include the leaves and flowering tops. These parts are harvested for culinary use, often dried for preservation. The flavor profile of oregano can vary significantly based on its growing conditions and the specific cultivar, with some types, like Greek oregano, being particularly prized for their strong aroma and taste.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Oregano thrives in full sun and prefers well-drained soils with moderate moisture. It is tolerant of heat and drought, making it suitable for a variety of climates, particularly in temperate regions. The optimal soil pH for oregano cultivation ranges from 6 to 7, and it benefits from some shade during the hottest parts of the day, especially for certain cultivars with variegated leaves.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil of oregano contains significant compounds such as thymol and carvacrol, which contribute to its flavor and medicinal properties. These compounds are known for their antimicrobial and antioxidant effects. Oregano also contains phytonutrients like quercetin, beta-carotene, and ascorbic acid, which may vary in concentration depending on environmental factors.
Morphological_Features: Oregano is characterized by its bushy, rhizomatous structure with square stems. The leaves are typically rounded to ovate, measuring about 1 to 4 cm (1/2 to 1 1/2 inches) long. The plant produces tiny, two-lipped flowers that are usually pinkish-purple or white, which attract various pollinators. The foliage is aromatic and can revert to a green color if not properly maintained.
Medicinal_Value: Oregano has been used in traditional medicine for its potential health benefits, including anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antioxidant properties. Its essential oils are often utilized in herbal remedies and aromatherapy. The plant is also recognized for its ability to support digestive health and may aid in respiratory conditions due to its anti-inflammatory effects.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Originally native to the Mediterranean region, oregano has been widely naturalized in various parts of the world, including North America, Mexico, and parts of Asia. It is commonly cultivated in temperate climates and is a popular herb in many cuisines, particularly Italian, Greek, and Spanish. Regions with suitable growing conditions include southern Europe, the Middle East, and northern Africa, as well as areas in the United States where the climate is conducive to its growth.

Description: The papaya is a small, sparsely branched tree, usually with a single stem growing from 5 to 10 m (16 to 33 ft) tall, with spirally arranged leaves confined to the top of the trunk. The lower trunk is conspicuously scarred where leaves and fruit were borne. The leaves are large, 50–70 cm (20–28 in) in diameter, deeply palmately lobed, with seven lobes. All plant parts contain latex in articulated laticifers.
Parts_Used: The leaves, fruit, seeds, and latex of the papaya plant are used for various medicinal purposes. The leaves are used for the treatment of fever, pyrexia, diabetes, gonorrhea, syphilis, inflammation, and as dressing for foul wounds. The fruit and seeds also possess medicinal properties.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Papaya is a tropical plant that grows best in temperatures ranging from 21 - 33°C in frost-free areas. It requires a monthly rainfall of about 4 inches and well-draining soils with a pH between 5.5 and 6.5. Water-logged soils should be avoided as papaya trees are extremely sensitive to flooding. Tall trees can easily topple in high winds, so planting should be avoided in windy areas.
Chemical_Properties: Papaya skin, pulp, and seeds contain a variety of phytochemicals, including carotenoids and polyphenols, as well as benzyl isothiocyanates and benzyl glucosinates. The carotenoids, lutein and beta-carotene, are prominent in the yellow skin, while lycopene is dominant in the red flesh. Papaya seeds also contain the cyanogenic substance prunasin. The green fruit contains papain, a cysteine protease enzyme used to tenderize meat.
Morphological_Features: Papayas are dioecious, with male and female flowers borne in the leaf axils. The male flowers are in multiflowered dichasia, and the female ones are in few-flowered dichasia. The fruit is a large berry about 15–45 cm (6–17+3⁄4 in) long and 10–30 cm (4–11+3⁄4 in) in diameter, ripe when it feels soft, with an amber to orange hue and numerous black seeds attached to the walls of the large central cavity.
Medicinal_Value: Papaya possesses anticancer, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and hypoglycaemic properties. It also contains the enzyme papain, which helps in the treatment of traumas, allergies, and sports injuries by boosting digestive motility and transit time. The leaves, among other plant components, have been utilized as therapeutic cures for several ailments.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Native to tropical America, papaya originates from southern Mexico and Central America. Papaya cultivation is now nearly pantropical, spanning Hawaii, Central Africa, India, and Australia. Wild populations of papaya are generally confined to naturally disturbed tropical forests.

Description: Petroselinum crispum, commonly known as parsley, is a biennial herb belonging to the Apiaceae family. It is widely recognized for its culinary uses and nutritional benefits, particularly its high vitamin C, vitamin A, and iron content. This herb typically grows to about 0.6 meters in height and features a rosette of dark green leaves that can be either flat or curly, depending on the variety. The plant produces greenish-yellow flowers in compound umbels during its second year, followed by small, ridged seeds.
Parts_Used: All parts of Petroselinum crispum are utilized, including the leaves, stems, and seeds. The leaves are the most commonly used part, while the seeds can be distilled to extract essential oils. The two primary varieties cultivated are neapolitanum (Italian parsley) and crispum (curly-leaved parsley), each offering distinct flavors and culinary applications.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Parsley thrives in temperate climates and can tolerate a range of weather conditions. It prefers well-drained, rich soil and requires consistent moisture for optimal growth. The seeds may take several weeks to germinate, particularly in cooler, wetter soils, and should be kept evenly moist. Parsley can be planted in spring after the last frost, with the option for fall sowing in milder regions. It can also be grown indoors in pots, provided it receives adequate light and water.
Chemical_Properties: Petroselinum crispum is rich in essential oils, particularly in the flat-leaf varieties, which contribute to its characteristic aroma and flavor. The leaves contain various vitamins and minerals, making them a nutritious addition to diets. The plant's chemical composition includes flavonoids and other antioxidants, which may offer health benefits, including anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties.
Morphological_Features: Morphologically, parsley exhibits a taproot system, with spiral, exstipulate leaves that vary in shape depending on the variety. The plant's petioles can reach lengths of up to 10 cm, and the flowers are arranged in compound umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. The aromatic quality of the plant is strongest in the roots, while the leaves and stems also possess a distinct fragrance.
Medicinal_Value: Traditionally, parsley has been used for its medicinal properties, including its role as a diuretic and digestive aid. It is believed to support kidney function and may have anti-inflammatory effects. The high vitamin content, particularly vitamin C, also contributes to its reputation as a health-promoting herb. Additionally, parsley has been used in folk medicine for various ailments, although scientific validation of these uses is still ongoing.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Petroselinum crispum is believed to have originated in the eastern Mediterranean but has since been cultivated worldwide. It is particularly popular in Europe, where it has been grown since the Middle Ages, and is commonly found in gardens across North America and Asia. The plant adapts well to various climates, provided the growing conditions are favorable.

Description: Mitchella repens, commonly known as Partridge Berry, is a low-growing, evergreen ground cover native to Eastern North America. It is characterized by its creeping habit and is often found in shady, moist environments. The plant produces distinctive white flowers in pairs, which are crucial for its reproductive process, as they require cross-pollination to produce berries. The berries are edible, though they are noted for having a mild flavor reminiscent of wintergreen.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Mitchella repens that are utilized include its leaves and berries. The leaves are often brewed into a tea, traditionally used for medicinal purposes, while the berries can be consumed directly, although they are not particularly flavorful.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Mitchella repens thrives in acidic, moist, well-drained soils and is best suited for shaded to partially shaded areas. It can tolerate some drought but performs optimally in environments that retain moisture without becoming waterlogged. The plant is hardy in USDA zones 3 to 9, indicating its adaptability to various climates within this range.
Chemical_Properties: While specific chemical properties of Mitchella repens are not extensively documented, it is known to contain compounds that have been traditionally used for medicinal purposes. The leaves and berries have been utilized by various Indigenous peoples for their diuretic and analgesic properties, among others. The exact phytochemical constituents remain less explored in scientific literature.
Morphological_Features: Partridge Berry typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 inches (3-5 cm) and spreads 6 to 12 inches (15-30 cm). The leaves are glossy and dark green, providing an attractive ground cover. The plant produces small, tubular white flowers that bloom in pairs, featuring a unique dimorphic structure that promotes cross-pollination. The scarlet berries are produced in clusters and persist into winter, providing visual interest and food for wildlife.
Medicinal_Value: Mitchella repens has a rich history of medicinal use among Native American tribes. The leaves were brewed into a tea to assist in childbirth and to treat various ailments, including insomnia and reproductive issues. Its use as a diuretic and for reducing fever or swelling has also been documented, highlighting its significance in traditional medicine.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Mitchella repens is primarily found in Eastern North America, ranging from Nova Scotia to Florida and westward to parts of the Midwest. It thrives in natural habitats such as woodlands, shaded areas, and along forest edges. The plant is well-suited for cultivation in gardens designed for shade and is often used as a ground cover in landscapes that mimic its natural environment.

Description: Mentha pulegium, commonly known as pennyroyal, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Lamiaceae family. It is native to Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East, and is recognized for its strong minty aroma and traditional medicinal uses. Mentha pulegium typically grows to a height of 30–80 cm and features erect, branched stems that can be either hairless or densely hairy. The leaves are narrowly oval, measuring about 2–3 cm long and 1 cm wide, and are arranged in opposite pairs. The plant produces small lilac flowers, approximately 6 mm in size, which are grouped in whorls along the stem. The flowering period occurs from June to mid-summer, although it may extend into September in cooler climates. The fruits consist of a cluster of four brown, one-seeded nutlets.
Parts_Used: The aerial parts of Mentha pulegium, including leaves and flowers, are primarily used for their aromatic and medicinal properties. The leaves are often crushed to release their strong fragrance, which is similar to spearmint. The essential oil extracted from the plant is also utilized in various applications, including culinary and medicinal uses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Pennyroyal thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers moist, well-drained soils. It is adaptable to various soil types, including chalk, clay, loam, and sand, and can tolerate a range of soil pH levels from acidic to alkaline. The plant is hardy in USDA zones 6 to 9 and can grow in diverse climates, making it suitable for cultivation in many regions worldwide.
Chemical_Properties: The primary active compound in Mentha pulegium is pulegone, a ketone known for its potential medicinal properties. Pulegone acts as an enzyme inhibitor at the cellular level, influencing various biological processes. Other constituents of the essential oil include menthone, piperitenone, and isomenthone. However, it is crucial to note that high concentrations of pulegone can be toxic to the liver, necessitating caution in its use.
Morphological_Features: Mentha pulegium exhibits distinctive morphological traits, including square stems and downy leaves with sparse teeth towards the tip. The flowers have a ribbed calyx and a corolla with mauve lobes. The plant's strong fragrance is a notable feature, and it is often used in gardens for its aromatic qualities and as a companion plant.
Medicinal_Value: Historically, pennyroyal has been used as a folk remedy for various ailments, including digestive issues, pain relief, and as an insect repellent. It is considered an emmenagogue and has been used in traditional practices to stimulate menstruation. However, due to its potential toxicity, particularly in large doses, it should be used with caution and under professional guidance.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Mentha pulegium is widely distributed across Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East. It has also been introduced to North and South America, Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. In many regions, it is regarded as a weed, particularly in agricultural settings, but it is also cultivated for its aromatic and medicinal properties.

Description: Mentha piperita, commonly known as peppermint, is a hybrid plant belonging to the Lamiaceae family. It is a sterile hybrid of spearmint (Mentha spicata) and water mint (Mentha aquatica). Peppermint is widely recognized for its aromatic properties and is cultivated primarily for its essential oil, which contains menthol, a compound responsible for its characteristic flavor and cooling sensation.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Mentha piperita used in various applications are the leaves and stems. The leaves are harvested for their essential oil, which is extracted for culinary, medicinal, and cosmetic uses. The essential oil is rich in menthol and menthone, making it valuable in flavoring, fragrance, and therapeutic products.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Mentha piperita thrives in moist, temperate climates. It prefers well-drained, fertile soils and can tolerate a range of pH levels, although slightly acidic to neutral soils are ideal. The plant requires consistent moisture and benefits from partial shade, especially in hotter climates. It is typically grown in areas with moderate rainfall, as excessive waterlogging can adversely affect its growth.
Chemical_Properties: The essential oil of Mentha piperita is characterized by its high menthol content, which can range from 30% to 55%. Other significant components include menthone, pulegone, and menthofuran. The oil has a specific gravity of 0.900 to 0.916 g/cm³, a refractive index of 1.457–1.467, and an acidity number of less than 1.4 mg KOH/g. These chemical properties contribute to its aromatic and therapeutic qualities, making it suitable for various applications in food, cosmetics, and medicine.
Morphological_Features: Mentha piperita is an erect herb that can grow 2 to 3 feet tall. It features a square, reddish stem that is smooth or slightly hairy. The leaves are dark green, opposite, and can be oblong to lanceolate in shape, with serrated edges. The plant produces purple flowers arranged in whorls, with each flower having a two-lipped corolla. The fruits contain 1 to 4 seeds and are covered with a stony layer. The overall morphology of the plant allows it to spread through underground stolons, contributing to its invasiveness in suitable environments.
Medicinal_Value: Mentha piperita has been utilized in traditional medicine for its various health benefits. Its essential oil is known for its analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antispasmodic properties. It is commonly used to relieve digestive issues, headaches, and respiratory problems. Additionally, peppermint oil is often employed in aromatherapy for its calming effects and ability to enhance mental clarity. Research indicates that the plant's bioactive compounds may also possess antimicrobial and antioxidant properties.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Mentha piperita is cultivated in many regions worldwide, particularly in temperate climates. Major producers include the United States, India, China, and several European countries. In the U.S., significant cultivation occurs in states such as Oregon and Washington. The plant's adaptability allows it to thrive in various environments, making it a popular choice for both commercial and home gardening.

Description: Catharanthus roseus, also known as the Madagascar periwinkle or rosy periwinkle, is a small, upright evergreen shrub or herbaceous plant that typically grows 30-100 cm tall. It has cylindrical, longitudinally ridged stems that are green or dark red and may be pubescent when young. The leaves are opposite, elliptical to obovate in shape, 2.5-9 cm long, green with paler veins, and usually pubescent. The flowers are borne singly or in pairs in the leaf axils on short stalks. They have a long, narrow tube with 5 spreading, perpendicular lobes that are pink to white or pinkish purple, 1-2.8 cm long. The fruit is a follicle 2-4.7 cm long containing numerous small black seeds.
Parts_Used: All parts of the plant, including the leaves, roots, shoots, and stems, contain over 200 alkaloids, with the leaves and roots being the most important parts used medicinally.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Catharanthus roseus has no specific climatic requirements and can grow in tropical or subtropical regions. It thrives in hot and humid environments and tolerates hot temperatures in summer, drought, and heavy rainfall. However, it cannot withstand frosts and is best grown indoors in temperate climates.
Chemical_Properties: The plant contains over 200 alkaloids, with the most important being vinblastine and vincristine, which are used to treat various cancers.
Morphological_Features: The plant has glossy oval leaves with a white center vein, borne in opposite pairs on slender stems. One or more flowers are produced at the stem tips throughout a flowering period that generally lasts from mid-spring to early autumn. Each flower has a 1 cm long tube flattened out into five lance-shaped petals at the mouth, which is up to 4 cm wide. Flower color is usually soft rose-pink or occasionally mauve.
Medicinal_Value: Catharanthus roseus has immense medicinal importance due to its alkaloids. The plant has anti-cancer effects and is traditionally used to treat diabetes. Derivatives from periwinkle are used in a variety of pharmaceutical preparations.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Catharanthus roseus is native and endemic to Madagascar but has been naturalized in practically all tropical countries. It is commonly associated with coastal habitats, bushland, and disturbed natural vegetation near urban areas. In East Africa, it is cultivated as an ornamental in most districts and frequently escapes to inhabit roadsides, abandoned quarries, and farmland.

Description: The kaki tree, also known as the persimmon, is a deciduous tree that can grow up to 12 meters tall. It has a shape similar to an apple tree, with medium to dark green, broadly lanceolate leaves that are stiff and equally wide as long. It is a deciduous tree that can grow up to 12 meters tall. The tree is similar in shape to an apple tree, with medium to dark green, broadly lanceolate, stiff leaves that are equally wide as long. The leaves typically fall off the tree when the fruits ripen in October and November (Northern Hemisphere).
Parts_Used: The fruit of the kaki tree is the primary part used, as it is a popular food crop. The leaves and other parts of the tree may also have medicinal uses.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Kaki trees grow best in areas with well-distributed rainfall, though they are surprisingly tolerant and can succeed in semi-arid areas with as little as 300mm of rainfall per year. They require temperatures between 16-22°C to grow.
Chemical_Properties: The leaves of Diospyros kaki contain flavonoids such as astragalin and kaempferol-3-0-glucoside, which have been traditionally used for the treatment of hypertensive diseases in Japan.
Morphological_Features: The kaki tree typically bears flowers when it is 3 to 6 years old. The flowers are 2.0 to 2.5 cm wide, appear in late spring or early summer, and have a creamy white color. Female flowers grow singly, while male flowers sometimes have a pink tint and tend to appear in clusters of three. The fruits ripen when the leaves have mostly fallen off the tree, typically in October and November.
Medicinal_Value: The plant is traditionally used to treat various ailments like gonorrhoea, leucorrhoea, menorrhoea, diabetes, cough, and also in the treatment of herpes.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Diospyros kaki is grown worldwide, with 90 percent of the total production in China, Japan, and Korea. It is also cultivated in other parts of Asia, as well as in some regions of Europe and the Americas.

Description: Ananas comosus, commonly known as pineapple, is a tropical plant belonging to the family Bromeliaceae. It is characterized by its rosette of long, spiky leaves and a thick, stocky stem that can grow between 1 to 2 meters tall. The plant produces a single, large, edible fruit that develops from a cluster of flowers, forming a multiple accessory fruit with a unique sweet and tangy flavor. The fruit's surface features small "eyes," which are the remnants of individual flowers, and it can vary in color from yellow to golden brown when ripe. Pineapples are perennial plants that can take up to two years to produce fruit after planting, depending on the growing conditions.
Parts_Used: The pineapple plant offers several useful parts. The fruit is edible and rich in vitamins, minerals, and enzymes, especially bromelain, which provides various health benefits. The leaves are valuable for fiber production, used in making textiles like piña cloth and paper. The crown, or the top part of the fruit, can be used to propagate new plants. The stems also contain bromelain and have culinary applications, such as in meat tenderizing.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Pineapples thrive in warm, tropical climates and require specific environmental conditions for optimal growth. The ideal temperature range for growing pineapples is between 20°C to 30°C (68°F to 86°F), as they are sensitive to frost and cannot withstand temperatures below 0°C (32°F). They prefer well-drained, sandy loam soil with a pH between 4.5 and 6.5, rich in organic matter to support healthy growth and prevent root rot. Pineapples need full sun exposure, ideally receiving at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While high humidity levels are beneficial for pineapple plants, they can also tolerate some drought once they are established.
Chemical_Properties: Pineapples are rich in various bioactive compounds, including vitamins, minerals, enzymes, and antioxidants. They are particularly high in vitamin C, which is essential for immune function and skin health. Pineapples also contain important minerals like potassium, magnesium, calcium, and manganese. One of the unique components of pineapples is bromelain, an enzyme known for its anti-inflammatory properties. Bromelain aids in digestion and may help reduce swelling and bruising. Additionally, pineapples are a source of antioxidants, such as flavonoids and phenolic acids, which help combat oxidative stress in the body.
Morphological_Features: The morphological characteristics of Ananas comosus, commonly known as pineapple, include distinctive features in its leaves, stem, inflorescence, and fruit. The leaves are long, narrow, and fleshy, typically reaching up to 30 cm in length, with sharp spines along the edges, forming a rosette around the stem. The stem itself is short and stocky, supporting the inflorescence. The inflorescence is a spike-like structure that can grow up to 15 cm long and contains numerous spirally arranged flowers. The color of these flowers can vary depending on the variety, ranging from purple and red to lavender. The fruit of Ananas comosus is a large, compound fruit formed from the fusion of multiple flowers, characterized by its sweet, juicy flesh and unique texture.
Medicinal_Value: Pineapple is renowned for its medicinal properties, largely attributed to its rich nutritional content and bioactive compounds. One of the key components, bromelain, is known for its anti-inflammatory properties, which can help alleviate pain and inflammation, particularly in conditions such as arthritis. Additionally, pineapple promotes digestive health due to its high fiber content and the presence of bromelain, which aids in protein digestion. The fruit is also a good source of antioxidants, which protect the body from oxidative stress and may lower the risk of chronic diseases.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Ananas comosus, commonly known as pineapple, is cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions around the world. Its primary region of origin is Central and South America, particularly Brazil and Paraguay. In Asia, it is widely grown in countries like the Philippines, Thailand, and Indonesia. Africa also has significant cultivation, with countries such as South Africa and Kenya playing major roles. In the United States, pineapple is primarily grown in Hawaii and southern Florida.

Description: Erythrina berteroana is a small deciduous tree belonging to the Fabaceae family, commonly found in regions of Mexico, Central America, and northern South America. Known by various names such as elequeme and gallito, this tree typically grows to a height of 12 to 15 meters (40 to 50 feet) and can have a trunk diameter of up to 20 cm (8 inches). Its branches are smooth and thorny, and it features trifoliate leaves that are ovate or rhomboidal in shape, with large, tubular flowers that are pink or red, blooming primarily from December to March. The tree produces woody pods containing several bean-like seeds, and it is often pollinated by hummingbirds.
Parts_Used: Various parts of pito are utilized for different purposes. The shoots and unopened flowers are consumed as vegetables, while young foliage serves as fodder for livestock. The bark and seeds contain toxic alkaloids, which can be used to create poisons. Additionally, the tree's timber is lightweight and can be carved, and a yellow dye can be extracted from the bark. The leaves are also used in traditional medicine, highlighting the tree's multifaceted utility.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Pito thrives in areas with annual precipitation ranging from 1,500 to 4,000 mm (60 to 160 inches) and can be found at altitudes of up to 1,800 meters (6,000 feet). It prefers acidic soils with a pH of around 4 and is tolerant of high aluminum levels in the soil. The tree is frost resistant and flourishes in a variety of temperature ranges, making it adaptable to different climatic conditions.
Chemical_Properties: The bark and seeds of Erythrina berteroana contain toxic alkaloids, which are significant for their potential medicinal and psychoactive properties. These compounds can be used in traditional medicine but require careful handling due to their toxicity. The tree also has nitrogen-fixing capabilities, enriching the soil in which it grows, which is beneficial for agricultural practices.
Morphological_Features: Pito is characterized by a broad, spreading crown and stout spines on its branches. The leaves are alternate and trifoliate, while the inflorescence is terminal and racemose, featuring large, tubular flowers. The tree's pods are woody and can reach lengths of up to 30 cm (12 inches). Its morphological adaptations allow it to thrive in drier regions, making it a common sight in lowland areas of Central America.
Medicinal_Value: The medicinal uses of pito are varied. The leaves, flowers, and bark are employed in traditional medicine for their health benefits, which may include anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. However, due to the presence of toxic alkaloids, caution is advised when using parts of this plant for medicinal purposes.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Pito plant is native to southern Mexico, Central America, and parts of northern South America, including Guatemala and Venezuela. It is commonly found in the drier regions of these areas, where it serves both ecological and agricultural roles. The tree's adaptability to various soil types and climatic conditions further supports its widespread distribution in these regions.

Description: Phytolacca americana, commonly known as pokeweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to North America. Pokeweed is a tall, branched perennial herb that can grow between 80 to 250 cm in height. It features a large taproot and has alternate, egg-shaped to lanceolate leaves that can reach up to 30 cm long and 10 cm wide. The plant produces terminal racemes of small white flowers that eventually develop into dark purple berries. The stems of pokeweed are often red or purple, and all parts of the plant contain toxic compounds, particularly in the berries and roots, making it potentially dangerous if consumed improperly.
Parts_Used: The primary parts of Phytolacca americana that are used include leaves, berries, and roots. Young leaves can be cooked and consumed, though they must be properly prepared to remove toxins. The ripe berries, although toxic, have historically been used to produce dyes and inks. The roots contain potent compounds but are also toxic and should be handled with care.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Pokeweed thrives in a variety of weather conditions but prefers disturbed sites with ample sunlight. It can grow in a range of soil types, though it generally favors moist, well-drained soils. The plant is resilient and can tolerate poor soil conditions, making it adaptable to various environments, including waste areas and no-till fields.
Chemical_Properties: Pokeweed contains several toxic compounds, including saponins, alkaloids, and pokeweed mitogen. Saponins are present in all parts of the plant and can cause gastrointestinal distress if ingested. The berries contain toxic alkaloids that can be harmful to humans and animals. Additionally, pokeweed mitogen, a lectin that stimulates B-cell proliferation, has potential applications in immunotherapy and diagnostic tests for immunodeficiencies.
Morphological_Features: Pokeweed is a distinctive plant characterized by several features. It typically grows to a height of 80 to 250 cm. The leaves are large, lanceolate, and glabrous, with either entire or wavy margins. The flowers are white and borne in racemes, which eventually develop into dark purple berries. The stems are often red or purple, further contributing to the plant's unique appearance.
Medicinal_Value: Despite its toxicity, pokeweed has been used in traditional medicine. The young shoots, when properly prepared, have been consumed as a salad green in the Southern U.S. The plant has been studied for its potential immunological benefits due to the presence of pokeweed mitogen, which is used in laboratory settings to stimulate immune responses. However, caution is advised due to the toxic nature of the plant.
Worldwide_regions_Support_their_Growth: Pokeweed is native to eastern North America, particularly found from southern Canada to Florida and west to Texas and Minnesota. It has also been introduced to other regions, including parts of Europe and Asia, where it often grows as a weed in disturbed habitats, forest edges, and agricultural fields.

Description: Cucurbita pepo is a cultivated plant of the genus Cucurbita that yields varieties of winter squash, pumpkin, and summer squash. It has been domesticated in the Americas for thousands of years. The plants are typically 0.30–0.76 metres (1–2.5 ft) high, 0.61–0.91 m (2–3 ft) wide, and have yellow flowers. The leaves have three to five lobes and are 20–35 cm wide. Cucurbita pepo includes a wide assortment of varieties and cultivars such as acorn squash, pattypan squash, zucchini, and ornamental squash.
Parts_Used: The pumpkin flesh, leaves, and flowers can be cooked and eaten in a variety of dishes. The seeds are also edible and are commonly roasted and eaten as a snack. The seeds are widely used as an anthelmintic, and the complete seed, together with the husk, is used to remove tapeworms. The fruit and seed decoctions have been reported to be used as diuretics and to reduce fevers, and are used for curing indigestion. The pulp is applied to burns, scalds, inflammation, abscesses, and boils, and is also used in the treatment of migraine and neuralgia.
Weather_Conditions_Required_to_Grow: Cucurbita pepo is grown in the tropics from the lowlands up to 2500 m altitude. They are warm-season crops adapted to monthly mean temperatures of 18-27°C. C. pepo has long been cultivated in temperate regions. Pumpkins and squashes respond very well to medium to heavy applications of compost or well-decomposed manure. They can be cultivated on almost any fertile, well-drained soil with a neutral or slight acid reaction (pH 5.5 to 7). They are drought-tolerant, require relatively little water, and are sensitive to waterlogging. Excessive humidity is harmful because of the development of leaf diseases, so C. pepo does not do well in the humid tropics.
Chemical_Properties: The chemical composition of Cucurbita pepo includes a variety of nutrients such as vitamins A and C, potassium, and dietary fiber. The seeds are particularly rich in oil and protein, making them a valuable food source. Additionally, the plant contains phytochemicals with potential health benefits, including antioxidants and compounds with anti-inflammatory properties.
Morphological_Features: Cucurbita pepo is a sprawling vine with yellow fruit-bearing flowers. The plants vary widely in appearance, primarily in regards to their fruits.
